Excellent exploration game. Making these little excursions out into the sea to fish, dredge and explore while slowly upgrading your ship is a very satisfying, tight gameplay loop.
Simple story but told very well. Piecing together the overarching mystery over the course of the game was great, and it culminated very well, with a genuinely surprising twist if you go for the alternate ending. Probably the closest I've come to playing a Lovecraft novel. This contributed to the atmosphere, which is a big highlight - the way it can switch in a second from cosy relaxation to tense paranoia is fantastic.

Dark and mysterious. Scary but always fair. But much like Subnautica there's only so much preparation you can do before you need to brave uncharted waters to progress. Wound up 100%ing the fishing log just for fun, though I think the Anchovy could be a little easier to find!
good game though no size 2 fish :(
This game gave me a great fear of fish

[b]A neatly packaged game.[/b]

DREDGE‚Äôs scope is strongly defined, its aesthetic is consistent, and its gameplay is well-realised.

You awaken in Little Marrow after crashing your boat into the rocks that flank the town, indebted - both metaphorically and financially - to the townsfolk who rescued you. What follows is a dozen hours of fishing mini-games, inventory management, and exploration, guided by the game's story - an understated, mysterious, lovecraftian tale of tragedy, which is intriguing if a little conventional.

The gameplay is enjoyable enough - checking off the list of sea-dwellers in the encyclopaedia is satisfying, and the seafaring is pleasantly tactile - but it doesn't take long for the fishing mini-game to become a repetitive task. Creatures have one or more aberrational variants, each a manifestation of the eldritch forces that loom over the world, and further variety is added through the different biomes, requirements for catching specific fish, and how well you are able to maintain your sanity in the wake of witnessing otherworldly abominations.

Creaking pontoons, clacking winches, and swelling waves help deliver the atmosphere of the game effortlessly, along with the often serene and occasionally unsettling score. Depictions of strange fish reveal the unspeakable terrors from the deep: voids where eyes should be, blistered and bubbling scales, and grotesque many-mouthed beasts.

On a technical level the game performs wonderfully. It's evident that the resources required aren't anything remarkable but it's still nice to see such a smooth experience. I played on Steam Deck mostly, with a little time spent on PC, and never ran into any issues. Despite Steam telling me otherwise, the game worked perfectly with a DualSense controller and displayed the correct button prompts.

Though the majority of your time is spent engaging with 'cosy' gameplay mechanics, they coalesce effortlessly with the horror aspects to deliver a rewarding experience that makes DREDGE a game well worth playing.

A cool experience for people who enjoy a more relaxing game experience. The world has nice light storytelling, the art direction fits well with the tone, and there's enough direction for the player to progress without feeling obligated to sprint through it without exploring.

Excellent game designed very well. The gameplay loop was fun yet intense in a very relaxed way. It scratched the itch for organising an inventory, chasing achievements, and got me engaged in fishing despite typically having no interest in fishing. In new areas and situations it had me on the edge of my seat in an almost scared way, but that wasn't persistent throughout the game necessarily so I wouldn't put it in the horror category. Would absolutely buy & play again at full price.

I've tossed and turns with regards to my feelings about this game.

The game itself is well made, I encountered no technical issues during my play-through and it overall was a pleasant experience. The fishing mechanics all worked well and the boat itself was fun to pilot around the various environments.

I think there are 3 main areas that disappointed me about this game

1: The eldritch horror elements were much less intrusive than I expected based on the media + hype. Don't go into this thinking that Horror is a big part of this game, it isn't, the madness mechanic is extremely easy to avoid altogether. But the mechanic also doesn't seem to actually do much.

2: Upgrades overall were not particularly interesting. Most of the upgrades in the game consisted of very linear progressions that didn't present the player with many meaningful choices as to what they should invest in. There are certain fishing mechanics that overall felt like they could be avoided if all you are wanting to do is finish the main story.

3: Upgrades largely rely on you randomly finding certain resources. Mechanics like these frustrate me in general as I do not feel like they are entirely rewarding. While it may be thought that "random drops" can be a fun player experience, for me personally, they just present a source of frustration as I attempt to find whatever it is I need to obtain the next upgrade and progress through the game.

Additionally there were a few quests that asked you to find a particular fish. However there is no way to actually locate which fish you would like to target, contributing to this issue of randomness that I have with the game. It really feels like a lot of the random elements of the game were primarily put in place to somewhat artificially extend the length of the overall experience. The game could have just as easily been half the length with the random elements toned back. I believe this would have made the overall package tighter and more cohesive.

With these being said, I do not believe that a non-recommendation is warranted. I did in general enjoy my time with the game, although as I got closer to the end I found myself focusing more on just finishing the game to move onto other things. 

Overall, yes the game is worth a play, just make sure your expectations are tempered with the knowledge that most of the hype (as always) has somewhat warped what this game actually is. Dredge is a game where you fish in some weird places, meet some odd individuals, fish up some normal and not-so normal fish. While sometimes seeing things that make you ask if you're really seeing them at all.

This game is so much fun and the story line is interesting and heartfelt. The gameplay is easy enough for beginners while still being engaging for more seasoned ones. The soundtrack is a thing of beauty and I never need to mute the game, even if I play for several hours at a time.
Incredible game and achievements were pretty fun to do. The only thing I didn't like is that some achievements are locked behind DLC.

Excellent game! One of very few games I have ever felt the need to 100%. 

You play as a fisherman in an archipelago beset by Lovecraft-inspired horrors from the deep. Gameplay switches between relaxing fishing on the high seas, to intriguing exploration, to tense monster attacks, often without much warning.

The game is pleasantly short - it ended just as it started to outstay its welcome, and was generally well-paced throughout. If you're looking for something to sink a lot of time into, this probably isn't the game for you. I beat the main campaign + dlc in about 10 hours then stuck around to catch every fish and find collectibles I missed. 

I didn't encounter a single bug, graphical or gameplay, at any point so it's very well polished. The visual style, although not exactly original (for an indie game) is charming. The music never really stood out apart from the accordion stuff that plays on the traders shanties, but was pleasant throughout. 

The game can be surprisingly atmospheric - although it never quite achieves genuine 'horror', I genuinely got the shivers a few times out in the open ocean, wondering what might be lurking below. Sadly, the game kinda shoots itself in the foot on its horror by (very minor spoilers) putting a big red glow on every monster, so nothing ever sneaks up on you in the dark foggy nights. I'm not entirely sure why the devs made that descision, as I think the game would be legitimately frightening otherwise. I guess they didn't want to commit to making a true horror game, which is fine, as the fishing and exploration is very fun even without the Lovecraft stuff. 

Story was meh, very much what you'd expect for the genre, but piecing it together was nonetheless pretty fun. 

tl;dr

a relaxing fishing game that occasionally tries (and usually fails) at being spooky. I think a few tweaks and a couple new monsters would do it wonders, but nonetheless a strong recommend so long as you aren't explicitly looking for a horror experience.
i love eldritch fish jenga

Fun game, doesn't take too many hours to complete. 

17 hours for me to get all of the achievements, could have gone faster but I wasn't rushing anything. None of the achievements felt like a boring grind which I really appreciated.
Caught fish, dredged items, spoke to the depths.

This game has one of the best first hours I've ever played. In terms of setting tone and getting into things, this game kills it. Plus, the fish lineup is top tier. We stan Barreleyes and Coelocanths.

I didn't like it as much as most players but it was good enough. Did a decent amount of stuff (not everything) and finished the main story but was underwhelmed overall. Going to give it a thumbs up since I think it's worth buying and playing, but was a little to slow for me.
8.5/10 game, very pleasant and engaging game considering that it's basically one big 6 hour fetch quest.

Fishing + Eldritch/Cosmic Horror = an oddly calming, yet scary good time....this game really perfected that sense of calm, only to be interrupted by the darkness that strikes at ya...i've only gotten the bad ending however, and I do plan on replaying it for that sweet sweet good ending.
i loooved it, the one thing is that the ending is a little abrupt but the lore leading up to it is really good

Amazing game that 'hooks' you hard, leaving you wanting to explore all it has to offer. Quickly bought all the DLC to support these devs that did a great job. Excited to see what else might be in store for the future.
Lovely game.
Worth every dime and time. Good: both on gameplay and storyline
I loved it.

As someone who's growing tired and bored of videogames, Dredge did something for me that many other games failed to do: it reignited my passion and interest for playing games. The gameplay is simple, yet fun and amazing, and the story is quite compelling too.
I feel this game suffers from two drawbacks keeping it from being even greater: length and lack of replayability.

1. Game is just too short even with the Pale Reach DLC, yet it has a great implicit lore which has great potential for expanding. A DLC expanding on the lore would be awesome.
2. After you beat the game there is simply nothing to do other than side quests and maybe catching trophy fishes, which gets old quickly. Things such as a skyrim-inspired radiant quest system, a challenge mode and/or a biome specific random event/encounter would neatly complement the open ocean exploration theme in the game. 

Looking forward to what this game has to offer in the future. Can't wait for the Iron Rig DLC as well!

Sunless Sea meets Subnautica. Short, fun fishing adventure.

Pros:
- Plot is good enough to hook player :)
- "World" has some biomes variety, with different conditions\mechanics
- Exploring is rewarding via side quest and loot
- Nicely done, not annoying insanity mechanic, with variety of events
- Thicc Lovecraftian atmosphere with unbeatable horrors

Cons: 

- Side-quests won`t affect the world.
- Fishing mini-games, crab traps, aberrations collecting becomes boring really fast
- Lategame is almost nonexistent - nowhere to spend money, no additional ships, not even portable fixing kit for equipment. 
- Unstoppable banishing torpedo at last hull
- Done 100% main game at 18h, 2 more hours for icy DLC. Yet feels like some potential was wasted (cultists, obelisks, big crabs, possible hidden locations, etc)
- Teleportation anchor? Ice cubes? Both DLC should be in game by default.

chill game to relax and play. easy 100% completion I finished with 26 hours not trying to rush and just having fun there is a little bit of rng to the fish you need to catch as well. try and snag the bundle on sale!

this game RULES, dude.

the art style is phenomenal, the story really hooked me (haha get it), and the gameplay itself failed to completely lose me to my short attention span! it's also made by an indie dev team in New Zealand/Aotearoa, which is super cool and an even bigger reason to support this game.

sure, it had its drags (devil's spine was not my favourite place to be, but it was doable! it's rather short if you really lock in) but it was overall a fun experience. the story and its lovecraftian elements are incredible, and even though i watched a playthrough before i played it myself, i still thoroughly enjoyed looking into the details in my own game.

i loved this game personally; i can't recommend it enough it's so cool!!! also justice for the dockworker in little marrow i'm so sorry for delivering that package king you were chill.

Context of the negative review: It's not a bad game. I was looking for something more than what this is. If you're looking for a horror experience in the vein of HP Lovecraft, this is not it. This is an HP Lovecraft inspired story but captures none of the dread or malevolence of his horror works, it'd be on the same shelf as a Cthulhu plushie.

As for the game...it's okay. Not terribly exciting. There are a lot of seeds for interesting gameplay but ultimately it doesn't do much with it. You sail around, you fish with QTEs, you bypass a handful of simple puzzles, you win the game. It looks pretty, it's fun sailing the boat sometimes, the artwork is nice, the music's nice but everything is pedestrian.

I think my overall criticism of this game is that it's boring. It's good enough that you might finish it, but you may ask yourself afterward why you bothered.

(NB. If wondering why I have 25 hours in it, I left it running on my PC in the background, actual play time was something like 5 hours.)

perfect art direction with a simple yet impactul storyline - one of the best lovecraftian stories i¬¥ve seen. I really wish there were more subplots to be explored, there are some characters that seem interesting but only give you a basic fetch quest
the fishing is fun, the exploring is fun, and the game does not overstay its welcome. excellent game!
da best. 10/10, loved the alternate endings.

Dredge is absolutely amazing. You're a trawler-person who washed up on strange island and your goal is to fish.

I absolutely HATE fishing in every single game I have ever played.  But in this game it was fun.  As you fish and zoom around in your boat, you'll discover all sorts of fish and slowly discover the secret to the mysterious island where not all is as it seems.

Sometimes these games can feel grindy, but not once did I feel like I was needing to farm endless resources or trapped in a time sink doing some other meaningless activity.  As I progressed through the story, the boat gets upgraded, and at no point did anything feel significantly out of reach.

It's a great little game and at 12 hours for me from start to finish - it felt like the perfect amount of time.  

Sometimes you just need a game that you can switch off to and enjoy.  This game was that for me, and I truly recommend anyone who wants to enjoy a casual game with some fun don't starve-esque vibes.

Try it, enjoy it and whatever you do, don't fall overboard :)

first indie game that i was hooked enough to beat in years. a nice eldritch horror story fused with fun gameplay loop and a strong atmosphere, definitely worth a look for the lovers of lovecraftian horror.

1 part cozy fishing sim 1 part horror/mystery game. Pretty winning combo. I don't usually like horror games but the story is intriguing and the mix of mundane with horror elements works well. 

The game is full of beautiful scenery and you can choose just to chill in the day in the safe zones watching orcas, dolphins, and turtles pass by while you fish (though to complete the story you'll need to venture into dangerous zones too).  

Day time fishing will also reflect real world weather (thunderbolts and lighting not very very frightening for me!)

At night it gets creepier with ghost boats, giant angler fish, and other potential hazards. Some areas will be annoying until you learn the tricks but there's lots of helpful guides. Unlike some games with a horror element it's not usually trying to kill you; it just wants to provide challenge and some thrills.
Very relaxing - I like not being rushed to complete things. Very interesting - the way the story unfolds i wonderful.
10/10 would recomend

I'm not one to write a review about a game but this one i think i will . first off I have a small fear over the open ocean, something about something being underneath you having the ability to swallow you . for sure this game after dark the seas get horror movie quality scary. The fishing, crabbing, and dredging are kinda relaxing . trying to make it back to a dock to be safe gets the nerves wiggling . kinda a bummer its a single player game but like a said the day time activities are nice a chill . 9/10 only because nothing is perfect .......Game on!!!

I was hesitant to purchase this game, but quickly feel in love with it. If you like exploration and Lovecraftian, this is a game for you. The developer did a great job of delivering a polished product with minimal bugs.

If you are looking for a game that can become your next short term addiction this is it. Upgrade your ship from something that is slow and inefficient to a boat that zips through the seas and catches fish just about instantly. Dredge's music makes this game very atmospheric it helps to build wonder, fear, and calmness. As someone who has done everything in the game I'm sure that this game has something for anyone looking for a game that can be your next hyper fixation.

I may or may not have decided to play this because of gem in hermitcraft season 10...and I loved it! The graphics and music are stellar. The gameplay progression is also very well done. It was a very fun game to play.

Ok, I really like the idea of a scary fishing game, and this game was it.
I was really excited when I first saw this game and I decided to buy it. It starts of promising, with a bunch of slightly repetitive side quests, all with deeper mysteries intertwined with them-or so I thought. As I continued playing, I got all the upgrades, but basically none of the quests done. My ship was tier 4, max everything, and I was a little bit bored. I found myself only playing for a little bit before struggling to find something to do. Maybe I progressed wrong? Whenever I try to complete a side quest, I have to get a certain fish, or certain item, and sometimes it's really hard to get them. Why am I leaving a positive review even though I am not enjoying this game very much? Well, the game really redeems itself with its beautiful graphics, and intriguing main story. I like the idea of the game being peaceful during the day, but dangerous at night, and it does that part well. The monsters are... good. They can deliver a good jumpscare sometimes, and you really always feel like you need a new engine to run away from them. After finishing the upgrades, I don't dredge very often anymore, but I will still to complete a quest. I like the idea of the game, I just have a few problems here and there.
I will update my review once I finish this gem of a game. The fishing mechanics are lots of fun! There is a good variety of types, and I find myself striving to be better at them. Abilities are fun, unlocking new ways to play as you progress through the story. They are pretty cool, and I use them quite often.
Overall, I recommend this game. I love the idea behind it, but the upgrading and progression system seems lacking to me. It can be a good "kick-back-and-relax" game, if you only go out at day. It is a good horror game if you go out at night! I recommend this game to those who like fishing games with twist! Hey, and at least it gets frequent updates.
-Ari

Atmospheric, creepy and bleak. If you're a general fan of horrors and the strange and unexplained, you'll love Dredge

I wanted Dredge from the GO, but then spent a few months looking at it thinking "hmm...is it really for me?".  I watched a play through of it and my answer became a resounding YES!!  I have spent almost 24 hours on it and I am by no means done.

It is a cozy, curl up and enjoy on a rainy evening sort of game with great "horror" elements that I think are perfectly placed.  If you want some adventure, but not too much combat - this is for you.  Half the time I just had fun "fishing" and spent hours just doing that and searching for new types of fish.  Once I completed the game, if you can call it that, now I am going back to fill in some holes...complete some side quests and just have fun with it.

I played with a controller (highly recommended) and found the gameplay and UX was pretty darn good.  Intuitive, fun and never becoming boring or tedious.  I also think that some of the game has superb replay ability - I am still finding quests that I missed the first time.  Even if you complete them all, it's still a fun - and animal safe - fishing game that can be enjoyed for a long time.

At the time of this review, I am 7.7 hours into the game, and that means I am barely into the story and quest-lines.

I love the artwork.
I love the music and sound effects.
I love that I can play in short sessions and not feel like I won't remember where I was when I get back. 
I love the slow burn, and build up of dread as the sun starts to go down, but I just have to try for one more fish or one more piece of scrap metal.

The economy is tight- but not unbalanced. If you are low on cash for upgrades or repairs you can go close to home to fish or throw out crab pots and make money at a decently fast pace.
I don't feel rushed into doing anything- the quests have no timers, I finish one whenever and the next one unlocks.
I can explore and get to know the map at my own pace.
End up smashing my boat to smithereens? The game lets me load up my last save or start over again- my choice.
You can turn off the scary stuff if you want to. I don't want to- the encounters add to the creepy Lovecraftian atmosphere. But if you don't like jump scares, or you have a younger child who wants to watch you play or wants to try it themselves- it's a nice option to be able to turn off the really freaky scary stuff.

The game has some good accessibility options, though the color palette the game uses *may* be an issue for people with certain forms of color-blindness.
The story and dialogue is all in text with no voice-overs, so it should be quite playable for Deaf and HoH gamers, though you will miss some subtle audio clues or prompts before monster attacks or wildlife encounters.
The story is delivered in small bits- no lengthy walls of text to deal with. It helps to click through every dialogue option, but they are all fairly short, easy to read and using language that doesn't require an advanced college degree.
The puzzles vary from easy to slightly challenging- trying to get things to fit neatly in your inventory or at shrines. But none have been brain-melters.

It runs really well on an older gaming laptop (with a discrete GPU), an older mid-range desktop, and a beefy newer desktop. I suspect it would run smoothly on a toaster, but I don't have one to test it on. As long as you have a dedicated discrete GPU, and you meet minimum specs (though I always recommend exceeding them, even just a little). No idea how it will run on a laptop with only a integrated chipset.

The only thing that bothers me is how quickly the day cycle runs- day to night a little too quickly. So you'll have to really think about how long fishing or dredging takes if you don't want the nighttime stress and madness to hit you. Remember to dock and sleep to stay sane.

Really enjoying the game, and I can and will whole-heartedly recommend it to anyone who wants a game that isn't high action, is a slow-burn kind of game, requires a little brain power, but isn't overly complex, and that has a really great immersive atmosphere that lets the dread settle in slowly and deeply.

(quick edit to fix some typos only- no changes to the text.)

The only thing I am disappointed is that there isn't more for me to do now that I've finished the game almost twice now.

Dredge has a dark and dreary atmosphere with a great artistic styling and a short, but fun gameplay loop.  The music was subtle which fits the game well, but probably wouldn't stand on its own for most.  The collection mechanics are engaging for those that like multiple aspects to their collections.  The quests were fun but rather guided, being told exactly what to do and where to go most of the time which it seems like a missed opportunity in a game that has you exploring the open ocean for different objectives.  I was surprised the map was completely charted for you which would've added something a little extra for the exploration piece of the game so go into it knowing that geographic discovery is not the focus of this game.  All in all, Dredge was enjoyable, but the gameplay loop became a bit of a slog towards the end as the gameplay varies very little after a few short hours into the game.  

I'd recommend it mostly to people who like collecting things and don't mind managing inventory and a darker theme to their games.

Dredge is a fairly enjoyable game with a low amount of tedium despite it being a fishing game. Fishing in games is a difficult thing to get right, and I feel that Dredge does it pretty well. Progression and pacing is good, and nothing feels out of reach. The art style of the physical world and the portraits of the characters are all beautiful.
All of that being said, I have some problems with Dredge. Night fishing rarely feels worth it beyond what you need for quests early and mid game, and crab pots are somewhat annoying to work with for me. 
The story and world of Dredge starts strong, having the player ask many questions and giving few answers. But it's that "few answers" that doesn't change throughout the game, with only more questions popping up as the game goes on and fewer answers. The whole story just feels as though it is lacking something, not everything needs to be explained, but it would be nice to get more than we got. Why are the fish corrupted? What made the night so dangerous in the first place? What is the deal with the collector? Too much is left up to the imagination which leads to the ending being extremely confusing and underwhelming.
The DLC, The Pale Beach, shows all of this clearer than anything else. There are a total of 5 quests and each is rather underwhelming, isolated from the rest of the story, and grants exactly 1 answer to any of the questions asked during the DLC. 
Overall, I would recommend Dredge if you enjoy more relaxing games and/or fishing games, though do be aware of the game's shortcomings.

It can be hard to create a game with lovecraftian themes given that eldritch horror relies so much on the fear of the unknown, but Dredge manages to pull it off exceedingly well. The world feels like a place where people just have to deal with all the scary stuff that washes up from the sea, and that just lends to the creeping horror that can slowly overtake you as you venture out into the endless blue.

This game isn't for everyone. I'm going to get the negatives out of the way first. 

Whilst I do enjoy the simplicity of the game, I'm personally not much of a reader and much prefer voices. Not necessarily a bad thing, but not for me. 

The story line left me with a lot of questions that I felt were unanswered.

Now on to the good stuff. 

I loved the story! I was wondering what the townsfolk were talking about when speaking of what I believed was a familiarity to someone else. It was until later in the story line when a startling revelation came to light. 

The graphics are fun and almost cutesy, where they could've been grotesque or gothic. I find the graphics to be a stark contrast to the story and I really do have to remind myself that this is a 'horror' game. 

My main love for this game is the collect-a-thon, which I know isn't everyone's cup of tea, including me, but Dredge really made me want to complete my journal, finish all quests and everything else. 

I've played through the game three times now, and I've thoroughly enjoyed it each time. I do highly recommend, but check out some videos first before investing. 

I recommend the devs release a demo to help curb some of these negative reviews.

Probably the best fishing boat game there is. It made me a completionist.
Jokes aside, this game has solid mechanics and dynamics that work together, giving the right amount of progression, customization, exploration and danger. I definitely recommend it.

However, If you go in expecting a high dose of Lovecraftian horror (like I did), you might be disappointed. If I had to criticize anything, it would be the weird - almost conflicting - relationship of this game's mechanics and its fiction/context. Sure, this can be said for a great deal of games, but it is extremely glaring here.

Suffice to say: you might get sucked into optimizing this game's systems and enjoying a great fishing boat game without really realizing it has a story with fictional horror elements. 

My point being: the devs did an amazing job, that I thoroughly recommend, but did they achieve the experience they intended?

It took 28 hours for me to hunt down all the various aberrations in the game. I thought the open ocean fish were going to be the hardest... at the end I had 10 crab pots going to get the Volcano Snail aberration. I was getting a ton of money every day but it took close to 7-10 days in-game for the RNG to produce what I needed. So there are some RNG mechanics that come with collecting everything. 

You could probably finish much quickly than this but I ended with roughly $35.8k, all flags and paints unlocked, all achievements completed and a vessel with a Boat Speed of 121.5 kn, Fishing Speed of 569%, Lights 5k lm, Aberration Bonus 12%, Running only fishing rods to get 7 Fish Types but could swap to Trawl Nets and Crab Pots.

[h3]Game Review Score[/h3]
That being said here is my score for the Cthulu-lite fishing game and why:

- The music and audio were fantastic (10/10). The cues for danger were on point and the transitions between zones felt seemless even though the Open Ocean areas add a huge buffer which makes it easy. Still there is a reason I bought the soundtrack to the game!

- Animation was on point (8/10). Other nautical games can go overboard on how much a boat rocks but the fishing aspect to the game wasn't affected really at all because it was nautical in comparison to games like Sea of Thieves. The only reason I picked that was that the 3D nature of the game. Since everything happens from the boat or in narrative form, there is no time that you really need to animate a character. I did wish there were cutscenes for the vision portions (described more later).

- There was enough variety in the types of fish (7/10) that you were collecting or catching that the mini-games had variety. Still I didn't love it enough to pick up the DLC to get 100% on Steam for achievements. FYI - 83% Steam Achievement Completion is equivalent to 100% completion for the base game. The aberration forms were super fun and great additions. Reading the descriptions really was great. The RNG wasn't the best so you did have to farm the open ocean fish (Sunfish, Moonfish, Sailfish) and some of the crab pots (Volcano Snail).

- The story or plot throughout is really narrative driven (8/10). If you want everything like all the visions (again narrative, no cutscenes) then you have to lean into the Cthulhu nature of the game to empower the black basalt altars. I wasn't following a guide so I didn't know this until much later on. The clues you get for what actually happens/happened are connected in the NPCs you talk to, the notes and letters you recover. This isn't a fighting game so typically if it is bigger than you, run away... Conceptually it fits the genre but it does get boring after a while. Won't get into much detail to avoid spoilers and spoiler tags.

- Other mechanics were generally good (6/10). Using your spyglass to locate the right fish was huge. There was a treasure map (3 pieces) in-game that was underutilized. Conceptually great but it was used only once and reward was forgettable which was sad. After completing the game and looking at other guides and reviews, I realized that I am grateful that I waited until later to do the timed optional side quests with the 4 cloaked figures.  If you don't time them right, you can lose the perks you get from them and then lose the optional side quest achievement unlocked. The cloaked figures don't play an overly important role but their narrative descriptions were the most Lovecraftian in nature in game so I felt like there was a missed opportunity to lean the MC more towards or away from the various sides in this story but that wasn't a thing even though there are two possible endings.

Overall - (7.8/10) Fits the genre but wish there was more to it than just fishing and collecting. Due to that, this game feels like it fits more into the cozy game genre than other Cthulhu or Lovecraft horror games. Music, art, narrative were all good to great. RNG always sucks but as you upgrade your boat as quickly as possible the world becomes easier to transverse so it starts to feel like a time sink which is never good but it didn't ruin the game. If you don't want to take your time and you want to speed through, probably not the game for you. Does it require a ton of time? No but like I mentioned, this is more cozy game than traditional horror. Also, cut scenes would have been appreciated similar to the endings themselves but the writing made up for it.

100% main game plus the Pale Reach DLC in 20.6 hours. 

Fun ride. Might just be the most stylish Lovecraftien game made so far. With great art, music and a genuinely creepy story. Any horror fan needs to check this out. The ocean is just a great setting for this type of tale. 

It's a bit shallow, no pun intended, though. And you'll run out of stuff to upgrade, find and buy many hours before the end if you're going for 100% completion like I did. With quite a few of those hours for me being just the RNG nature of... well, fishing up all varieties of fish. 

Still, that was mostly a mild nitpicks. This game is going to stick with me for quite a while, and I'd buy a sequel in a heartbeat. 

Oh, and one tip? Do Pale Reach early if you buy it. Its a neat expansion, and gives you some gear that's going to make the rest of your journey quite a bit less frustrating. Personally saved it for last, and was a bit frustrated with all the cool stuff I unlocked I had basically nowhere left to use it all on.

Thanks for helping me build a house!"

The nicest thing I can say is that, if you just play the main story, it's quite a short and compact experience that doesn't feel padded at all (~8h). It just also doesn't feel quite complete or filling. I hit 14h because I was in the mood to zone out and complete all the quests and catch all the fish.

Dredge, the highly anticipated video game of 2023, has made waves in the gaming community with its unique approach to storytelling, stunning visuals, and innovative gameplay mechanics. Developed by a talented team at Horizon Games, Dredge takes players on an unforgettable journey through a captivating and mysterious world.

Visually, Dredge stands out with its breathtaking graphics and attention to detail. The game's environments are beautifully crafted, from sprawling landscapes to intricate, otherworldly structures. The attention to atmospheric elements, such as lighting and weather effects, adds an immersive layer to the overall experience. The character designs are equally impressive, showcasing a diverse range of creatures and characters that contribute to the game's rich narrative.

One of Dredge's standout features is its narrative complexity. The game weaves a deep and intricate storyline that unfolds as players progress, keeping them engaged and invested in the fates of the characters. The writing is thought-provoking and filled with unexpected twists, creating an emotionally charged atmosphere that resonates with players.

In terms of gameplay, "Dredge" introduces innovative mechanics that set it apart from other titles in the genre. The game combines elements of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat seamlessly, creating a dynamic and well-rounded gaming experience. The controls are intuitive, allowing players to navigate the challenging terrain and execute complex maneuvers with ease.

The soundtrack of Dredge deserves special mention, as it enhances the overall experience. The hauntingly beautiful music complements the game's atmosphere, adding an extra layer of emotion to key moments. Sound effects are meticulously crafted, contributing to the immersive nature of the game.

While Dredge undoubtedly delivers an exceptional gaming experience, it is not without a few minor flaws. Some players may find certain puzzles to be overly challenging, potentially leading to frustration. Additionally, the game's ambitious narrative may be a bit overwhelming for those seeking a more straightforward experience.

In conclusion, Dredge is a triumph in modern gaming, offering a fresh take on storytelling and gameplay. Its stunning visuals, compelling narrative, and innovative mechanics make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Despite a few minor issues, the overall experience is one that will leave a lasting impression and spark discussions within the gaming community. Horizon Games has truly raised the bar with "Dredge," setting a new standard for excellence in the video game industry.

I have never been a fan of fishing games, but something about Dredge caught my eye. I had seen the artstyle and some of the creatures, and I was sold. I bought the game, and it was an amazing experience. Like I said, the artstyle was very unique. It was really... grungy? That how it feels when I look at it. It looks ugly in some parts but I mean that in the best way possible. It looks ugly on PURPOSE, that's the point. I think what kept me around was the world. It felt so real. Conflicts between people, rescuing people, or just chatting with people on the docks. Not to mention the creative monster designs. one of my favorites being the angler fish that disguises itself as the boat. The atmospheric tracks as well really help set the mood of each area. That calming Greater Marrow dock theme, to the wonderfully mysterious "The Path To The Door" (my favorite track in the game), the game does leaps and bounds on world building. The game play loop is also addicting as hell. It became a bit grindy in some areas when I was trying to max out my ship, but even then I was discovering new species and aberrations, so it wasn't too bad. I highly recommend this game. Even if you think it isn't for you, give it a try. I probably wouldn't have myself, discounting it by saying "its not for me" had I not seen some prior game play. 9/10, goated game.

More of a 5/10 than a true "thumbs down" but, as others have said, I was disappointed by the game given the overwhelmingly positive rating. 

The main issue is that the game feels so dead. I'm roughly 2/3rds through the game and I've never seen another boat at sea. Of the various biomed only the starting town felt like a real "locale". The others are all dead except for the same ubiquitous merchant that shows up everywhere. 

The biomes, including the pale reach DLC, are all the same formula. Complete a fetch quest to unlock navigation, which allows you to complete more fetch quests. 

Fishing is fun but you only ever sell to the same merchant unless you go back to the merchant. 

The "lovecraftian horror" is baby lotion soft. The night is daunting until you realize it's 90% harmless. The other 10% is easy to avoid. 

The sea itself is pretty bland too, it's pretty but generally very calm. I've encountered a few storms that were no challenge, but hinted at what the game *could* have been. As it is the only "challenge" in navigating is the dreadfully slow starting engines and dodging phantom rocks at night. 

It's a beautiful, polished game that just feels boring after the first few hours. I don't regret buying but I wouldn't recommend paying full price.

Dredge is a storytelling game about a fisherman getting lost in a thick fog and finding himself in unfamiliar territory and uncharted waters. What starts as a "find your way back home" scenario immediately turns into a "why is everyone so strange around here?" scenario, and you have to discover the mystery about this place.

[b] The Good: [/b]

- [i] The gameplay loop. [/i] You must catch fish to sell them to earn money. You then use this money to purchase upgrades for your ship, such as new fishing rods, which then allows you to go catch more fish in different environments. Once you unlock the dredging ability, you can find materials to increase the capabilities of your ship, such as extra space, speed, etc. The gameplay loop is simple, straightforward, and just long enough to not be a major grind.

- [i] The story. [/i] The story is a fun mystery that matches the atmosphere well. It's short enough that players that are in just for the main story will complete it quickly, but it has some deep moments as you get to the end.

- [i] The atmosphere. [/i] The graphics, music, and overall artistic expression in this game is great. The graphics look beautiful, especially at Stellar Basin at night, while not being demanding for the PC. The music gives sea shanty vibes at some points while setting a dark tone at others. These all combine together to give this game its uniqueness.

[b] The Bad: [/b]

- [i] The 100% grind. [/i] My only real complaint with the game is the slight grind needed to 100% it. One of the achievements involves catching all unique fish in the game. By the time you complete the story, unless you play with this achievement in mind since the start of the game, you'll need to do plenty of double-backing to catch everything you missed. It only amounts to a few extra hours of gameplay, but it becomes a bit boring after a while.

[b] Final Verdict: [/b]

- 10/10. Buy DREDGE and The Pale Reach, its main DLC. Both are fun, casual, and something to remember. Buy the additional DLCs if you want to support the developers.

[b]Here are the issues:[/b]

[list]
[*] The game was polished and QA-tested only for the first couple of hours at the beginning. For the rest, developers don't seem to bother testing/QA-ing the game properly.
[*] The game lacks game design polish, evident in a bug related to selecting objects. For instance, if you throw a crab pot near a pier, the game won't allow docking due to the presence of the crab pots.
[*] Various visual glitches are apparent with the trees.
[*] There is no explanation provided on how to unlock the "Bottomless Lines" rod; you simply can't unless you Google it.
[*] If you for some reason happen to crash or just simply touch by 1px with rocks or with sand, oh boy pray that your fast-going maxed boat won't turn into a snail, until your reach to the repairing shop.
[*] Bad UX, you can easily accidentally buy stuff from the merchant by accidentally clicking on items, and then you're either forced to reload the game, or just refund it with a half of the price.
[*] The XP system is also a mess:
[list]
[*] There is no point in upgrading lights when you can easily obtain an "overpowered" hidden treasure, which is 3,500 lumens, while maxed out light is very hard to obtain and it's only 3,000 lumens (even tho the light element is almost indistinguishable at some point). 
[*] You can literally deploy crab pots everywhere, and it always says "plenty", have you though t a little bit on that?
[*] I'm wonder what devs were thinking by adding "Travelling Merchant" in the game with her capabilities. You do realize that putting all the functionality together makes the game's experience gaining process useless. You literally can deploy crab pots, rest, wake up collect the goods, sell them, then buy research parts and repeat, are you that lazy?
[*] The game is designed to require hours of grinding. If you want players to enjoy your game, make it enjoyable. If you've included a grinding system, it either means you have high expectations for your game or it should be some form of online multiplayer. Your creation should not last forever or feel dragged out; it should promptly deliver the intended message.
[/list]
[/list]

10 out of 10. Do I like fishing games? not really. Do I like horror? Yes. This game surprised me. I only purchased it because of the overwhelmingly positive reviews and seeing it on the game awards 2023. It truly is a fun and relaxing game (during the day) while being tense and scary (at night). Love the sense of exploration and the art style. I liked the Pale Reach DLC as well. I hope they release more DLC.

I tentatively recommend Dredge as a game you should pick up on sale. While it is enjoyable and the fishing can be quite addicting, I think the mechanics feel somewhat unfinished. There's no control on pacing, meaning that if you're like me, you'll probably wind up barely halfway through the game by time you've fully upgraded your vessel. The gear progression is woefully short. Since equipment can only be swapped out at a handful of specific ports, you'll probably tend towards the most general layout which can catch any kind of fish, but leaves no space for things that increase aberration chance or fishing speed or do other fun stuff. This isn't such a big negative, due to another negative which is that these other aspects are so unimpactful as to be effectively meaningless.

Night quickly becomes completely non-threatening, and can be skipped by sleeping at a port. Fishing for aberrations is fun, but with certain fish, particularly the ones only available during the day (when aberrations are much rarer), it becomes incredibly tedious, until you unlock an ability that just gives you an aberration at a button press, which trivializes the quest entirely.

The story is interesting and compelling, though one of the game's endings is somewhat hampered by the appearance of a 'character' that I, at least, never even encountered during my playthrough. Nonetheless, there is much to enjoy in Dredge, and I would recommend giving it a try if you can get it for cheap.

All in all, it is a solid game, but don't expect more than 20-25 hours of gameplay, nor replayability.

Very captivating and chill game. You have a collection of fun mechanics as the game's skeleton and a fishing boat as the aesthetics and theme of the game. It's kind of like Pokemon Yellow with a few grinding mechanics, as long as you aim at enjoying the full content. You have to capture all fishes via 'mini games', make money, upgrade your boat to make your life easier and also having a sense of accomplishment and reward and finish several cool side quests that end up being an invitation for you to get to know every little aspect of the game that will leave you with a sensation of surprise.

But it isn't all sunshine and rainbows. There's a dark side to it. At night, specially, you'll see things and they'll keep you own your toes. The game gives you enough cool ways to deal with them. So there's a little push-back to introduce some resistance and make the game fun instead of easy-going/boring.

Edit: I played the DLC after already having gotten 100% of the achievements. They added new ones for DLC. I played it, it wasn't great. I formatted my PC and I forgot about it. In my mind I got the 100% again. And now I just remembered: I didn't. And I have zero desire of playing this again. The main campaign had a purpose and all the spark of a new and excited relationship with all its milestones. Thinking of the DLC is like trying to keep on gringing a relationship that already expired. And going for the last achievements would be like f'ing my ex. Bruh, it's over. No more.

Dredge is a cosmic horror fishing game that manages to pull off both genres exceptionally well despite the wild discrepancy between them. You play as an amnesia ridden fisherman that travels the seas of a series of islands where something always feels slightly off. 

At times, Dredge is a very cozy game that is easy to pick up and put down with simple but fun fishing mechanics. Yet at others, Dredge can be unsettling, disturbing, and terrifying. I've never before played a game that pulls off two incredibly different genres as well as Dredge does. You'll be fishing in an area of the map and all will be fine as you play fish-tetris with your catches to fit as many as possible onto your boat. Then suddenly, you lose track of time and the sun sets and now every unknown terror in the deep wants nothing more than to kill you. 

Another great surprise in this title was the story. Every interaction you have with the characters or message bottles of this game help to reveal shreds of a very murky and mysterious world. It's all fantastic. And without exaggeration, the big twist near the end had my jaw on the ground in the best way possible. 

I went into this title expecting a decent time and it thoroughly exceeded my expectations in almost every way.

This is not a typical game for me but I love it.  It is very casual and easy but has a lot of depth in just doing minor things. You can really get caught up in tasks or just do your own thing to farm money or items for upgrades. The upgrade system is very fast and easy. The mini games are made simple enough to master. It does have some creepy night mechanics and freaking birds steal your catches sometimes plus you can damage your boat with ramming object or getting attacked by some big ass monsters. The variety of items to get for quests is a little overwhelming at first but you get used to it after a few hours of fishing. This is a solid buy if you want to kill some time or if you have a Steam Deck, Probably the best game I have played on the Deck. Didn't really expect much from the game. Quickly became my favorite. The story is beautiful, the atmosphere is very engaging and there are tons of game mechanics to work around. Unlike many other modern games, it is very beginner friendly. I was shocked by how intuitive everything is. Most games create puzzles which are out of this world, impossible to figure out without opening wiki. But this game? Throughout my entire gameplay I only opened wiki once which is a great statistic in my opinion. 

Let me expand my argument for the intuitive part of the game. For instance, I talk to an NPC, that NPC talks about another NPC, or about the hobby/occupation/looks of another NPC. The game never really tells you to go to that NPC. But who cares, open world game = I go wherever I want to. So I go to the NPC that was 'supposedly' talked about. Guess what, that NPC has a problem needed solving (there you have it, a beautifully planned side mission that is in pace with the gamer.). This part of the game is what impressed me the most. Wanting the player to do something without explicitly stating it.

I recommend everyone to give this game a try.

Video games make fishing fun. Also, the psychological horror aspects of this game are incredible. I feel like at this moment I'm about halfway through the game, maybe a bit more, but in the beginning I was terrified of everything. Now I'm just setting sail through the ocean, only freaking out a little bit at whales or a giant monster that lives under a beached boat.
Pure gem to be played on handheld.

I played [b]DREDGE[/b] for about 20 hours, including 2-3 hours on 'The Pale Reach' DLC and some time spent catching all the fish for achievements. The game has a [i]creepy[/i] but interesting [i]Lovecraft-style graphics[/i] that add a cool, disturbing edge that enhances the game's unique atmosphere. The [i]fishing[/i] in the game is really well arranged. In each place,[spoiler]you need different tools to catch different fish, and each one has its own mini-game[/spoiler]. This makes every catch feel new and exciting. This game stands out as an excellent choice, combining a [u]great story and mystery[/u] with a distinctive theme. I enjoyed how it mixes being a bit scary with being fun to play. 

[h3]This game is a standout indie gem, definitely worth your time and attention.[/h3]

Simple fishing sim mechanics combined with eldritch horrors makes for an incredible juxtaposition, and even grinding for those last fish doesn't feel any more than a fun kind of tedious. The DLC is even reasonably priced and worth the extra items you get out of it, which for a game released in the last year says a lot. As a longterm appreciator of the Lovecraftian lore, this does an excellent job at portraying it without getting into his deeply racist crap. 10/10.

And, in the end, the game manages to deliver a poignant ending that leaves you sitting through the credits with a sense of awe. Absolutely recommend - 10/10 experience.

[h1]Dredge - Extremely Chilled, With Extreme Chills. 9/10[/h1]

Dredge is a single-player fishing game, where you explore an archipelago, while collecting artifacts and selling your fish to upgrade your boat. The game is surprisingly user-friendly, as while the fishing minigame is based around a skill-check system, making said checks only reduces the time spent fishing. This is a nice way to balance risk with reward during the main gameplay loop.

The setting is great. A collection of ports across the map contain a wide variety of different characters to interact with. The horror elements are also implemented very well; while there are no typical jumpscares per se, the game does an excellent job at making you feel uneasy when out fishing at night for too long.

My ONLY issue with this game was the rather large amount of going backwards and forwards I found myself doing for the sake of all the side content. With the length of the game being a lot more manageable than other titles for full completion, I didn't mind as much, but it did start to get a bit repetitive. Aside from this, a fantastic game, and I'm keen to see the next work from Black Salt Games.

I spent two days on this game, and it was phenomenal, I've nowhere near 100%ed it but oh man is it addictive. The fishing by itself is honestly a whole separate game, let alone some of the mechanics themselves. The story will get you by the hook (pun intended) and the world is expansive and diverse. The characters are intriguing and get you thinking about the world, special shout out to Dog. I loved all the range of fish, seethed at the sight of an ocean sunfish but that's a personal vendetta. Exploring, uncovering, fishing. This game covers everything in an atmosphere that Lovecraft would adore. Once I've achievement hunted this game and gotten everything done, I would come back to this to chill and have fun. I chose this on my one weekend off, over Genshin Impact and I have over 2000 hours on that game, just to clarify whether I'm kidding about how addictive the game play is.

Dredge is a fun fishing adventure game. It is basically "Fishing Minigame - The Game". I am really into these kinds of games, exploration, story, fishing minigames. While it is advertised as a horror story ar at least spooky, I found the game to be more relaxing than the cause of nightmares.
It ends really quicky, the main quest, I think, took me around 10 hours to complete the rest of my 19 hours were fishing the rest of the fish, aberrations and completing all other achievements. While I would say that the length of the game is a problem, I think it is actually good for this game since the gameplay does not evolve a lot during the playthrough and, as such, Dredge could become either boring or repetitive if the story were to be prolonged.
If you want to play a relaxing fishing game with an interesting story, I do recommend Dredge, but I think you should buy this at a discount rather than the full price.

I would have chosen a neutral option if Steam had it. I was interested in this game since it released and got it on sale.

However, I refunded it after one play session. The fishing is a joke and it's fetch quests essentially. The atmosphere is cool and I like the lovecraft feel. Gameplay wise this is bordering close to visual novel levels of nothingness. 

I was hoping it would have a better gameplay loop like Dave the Diver for instance. Unfortunately, story and atmosphere can't carry a game for me if the gameplay it's sold on is a timed button press chore minigame.

It gets repetitive really fast, each quest is simply a fetch quest flavoured to one of three NPCs, there's little challenge to it, and I never really figured out what was so scary about being out at night? A critique of the game is that the day goes by too fast, but I think the intent was to make you have to navigate through the night at least a little bit. But there was hardly ever any consequence for doing so. Once that was realised, the game lost a lot of allure for me. I beat it in about 10 hours, so it's a short game too.

I really enjoy the basics of the game but my main complaints are: (SPOILERS)

A: you can abuse crab trapping to no end drop all kinds of traps right in front of the dock sleep and just keep checking them especially when you get the upgraded traps.

B: If your engine gets damaged out at sea or even at any of the other islands where you cant repair you have to proceed at a snails pace and hope that you can somehow limp back to the center of the map for 10 minutes. Even if you have the haste skill it takes forever. Died 3 times trying to get back

C: You can fill up your hold, dock at the nearest town, transfer all fish to storage, repeat for the duration of the day/into the night until your storage, net, and hold are all full, and sell way more than you're meant to quickly. It is especially easiest in the starting town because you can just go back and forth across the bay cleaning up every single fishing spot.


EDIT: (I agree it is priced a bit high. Wait for a sale.)

EDIT 2: (They have since allowed you to have multiple saves which solves the original C and was the main reason for my negative review. However I still consider the game repetitive and a bit too easy to abuse, see B and C above. Also with how easy it is you would think it would be nice and relaxing except it's a horror game; so it doesn't really fit the relaxing genre.)

[strike](Formerly) C: you can only reload at the last place you docked not before so if you docked somewhere and got yourself stuck you have to start a new game entirely

I really want to leave a positive review but knowing that you can lose all your progress and can't reload kind of ruins it for me. If these things are fixed/adjusted I will absolutely purchase the game again and change my review.[strike]

As someone extremely horror-averse, I wouldn't consider this game particularly horrifying. Lovecraftian horror is the horror of the unfathomable. I say this because any fear you have dissolves as you encounter previously unknown threats and they become entirely understood and fathomable. It's a game that gets notably less scary as you play, and by the end, I felt like I had all encompassing knowledge of the world and its mechanics, unafraid to do anything. With that being said, being horror-averse, I did quite enjoy the game. It's a short play that you can take a long time to complete.

Dredge is a straight up fantastic game. 

With inventive mechanics and gameplay it's one of the few games of 2023 that offers something "new".
Great pacing, and a lack of pressure, allow you to sail through the game at your own pace - enjoying the journey (fishing and dredging) as well as the destination (upgrades and advancement). 

The setting is fantastic.  The map is enjoyably different, offering multiple biomes each with their own unique hardships and rewards.  The soundtrack adds to the ambience, and shifts seamlessly between the scare free day, and the horrors of the night.  You will feel your pulse quicken as you rush to the safety of a dock for the first time, I can assure you.

Going from a peaceful day to the nights (with a subtle addition of a cosmic horror) shows how they really created something that will keep you on your toes, with a vested interest in moving forward, and when combined with the rest of the work the devs put in you'll get a great replay value.

This is the PERFECT horror game.  You load in to a mega-hyped game with an open world, and as night after night falls, you upgrade your unremarkable boat, cartoonish spooky creatures surface from the deep, you slowly come to the creeping realization that you're playing A SHITTY WINDWAKER WITH BAD INVENTORY MANAGEMENT IN PLACE OF GAMEPLAY!!!

The "fishing" is hitting spacebar, the "crab pots" are leaving loot containers and waiting for them to fill, the completely unscary nightfall is simply to keep you from playing through the entire game in an hour, the dialogue and action "choices" are 1 dimensional and you can mass-sell quest items without even knowing they were ever important or why they were clogging up your godawfully tiny inventory.  Get the game 90% off and waste half a day seeing what kind of Blinky from Simpsons fish you can find but can't fit in your inventory then never look at it again.
Great game! Simple gameplay but enjoyable. The music and sound design is awesome for the things that lurk in the depths.

Dredge: an apparatus usually in the form of an oblong iron frame with an attached bag net used especially for gathering fish and shellfish...

Dredge mixes Diablo style loot sorting with progression fishing and a Lovecraftian story in the most beautiful way. In short, make your way from dock to dock selling fish and finding horrific artifacts. Be immersed in the lulling music and ambiance while hunting down nightmare creatures.

The core gameplay loop has you maneuvering your boat through rocky waters to find fishing spots. These spots will engage you in one of three different quick time events to catch a fish. Make sure you have the right gear and collect various fish of all shapes and colors. Sort these fish in your inventory to maximize your haul, and then return back to a dock to make a profit. With your new money, buy new fishing equipment, better lights to fend off the fog, a faster motor to escape the horrors of the deep, or expand your ship with more space and slots for aforementioned equipment. Along with fishing you will be tracking down artifacts that grant you supernatural powers that add more QoL abilities than direct progression. You will also dredge for materials that will allow you to make upgrades to your vessel.

For those that enjoy fishing games Dredge is definitely one to check out. Personally, I am addicted to uncovering all the creatures a game has to offer and sit back as you fish codex completes. Progression feels well paced and the story keeps gameplay entertaining. 

My complaints with the game is that while hunting for all of the different fish, you are tasked with also finding Aberrations of these fish. These are often nightmarish versions of previous fish and are found by chance or guaranteed with the Atrophy ability. However certain species are only obtainable by trawling. This is a mechanic that has you drag a net behind your ship to catch fish passively while travelling. Atrophy does not work on trawl-only fish and so get ready to spin to catch the last few Aberrations you need to finish your codex. My other complaint comes in the form of the "unlock all X research" category of achievements. The game does not really give you enough research parts to do this without extra grinding. Thankfully there is a way around this by save/load scumming shops to get parts easily. These two things were what kept me from 100%'ing the game a couple hours earlier. All of the other achievements are very reasonable and take little time out of just playing the game.

I'd still recommend this game even if you want to 100% it. The fishing gameplay is something I am quite fond of, and the eldritch story is very intriguing. Not all games have to have 300 hours of content, although I would not be against some expansions for Dredge.

Fun little fishing game with a spooky twist. The game starts out slow, but once you get better equipment, the game starts to open up more. Also, if you get the dlc, i recommend doing that area 2nd or 3rd as the equipment you get will help in base game.

If you're scrolling through Steam looking for a game that'll hook you faster than a fish in a cartoon, let me tell you about "Dredge." This game is like finding a treasure chest in your backyard ‚Äì unexpected and ridiculously exciting!

First off, I've been glued to my screen, unable to stop myself from collecting everything in sight. It's like being in a candy store, but instead of sweets, you're grabbing side quests, new fish, and upgrading your boat. The sense of achievement you get is better than finding extra fries at the bottom of your takeout bag.

And let's talk about the night adventures. Imagine sipping an espresso shot while riding a roller coaster ‚Äì that's the level of adrenaline rush you get floating through the dark, spooky waters. It's like a caffeine-fueled ghost ship experience, and I'm all for it.

I stumbled upon this gem because of the game awards, but what really reeled me in was the 'Dave the Diver' free addon ‚Äì the Dredge DLC. It's like attending a party and discovering your favorite TV characters are there too. The collaboration is seamless and adds an extra layer of excitement to the game. Kudos to the devs for this genius move!

In short, "Dredge" is a boatload of fun (pun intended). It's a perfect blend of humor, challenge, and quirky adventures. If you haven't tried it yet, you're missing out on a hilariously good time.

The more I think about this game, the more it feels like an incomplete experience. While the premise is interesting, in execution there's just not enough there for a fishing game or a horror game. By the time I hit credits with a near perfect completion rate, I couldn't help but feel disappointed. This is a game with no real payoffs, and not much in the way of suspense. This applies to both the gameplay and the story. Even after seeing all the endings, I still feel like this is the case.

It's certainly much more of a chill experience than I was hoping for, as danger is barely a thing with safety always being within visual range and enemies providing next to no threat. This isn't helped by the fact that the game is insultingly easy, with little in the way of challenge hidden anywhere on the map. Because there is no time pressure to get things done quickly, any setbacks you might have can be mitigated by simply making some money and going back to even the riskiest play styles (which in this game means keeping your player character up for days at a time and going out to fish every night).

Everyone else will find much more satisfaction with games like Subnautica and Dave the Diver for sea exploration, and almost any other horror game for spooky thrills. It's cool to see a game attempt to do both, but Dredge does both of those things poorly. I think if it looks like something you'd enjoy, go ahead. Everyone else, this probably won't do it for you. 2 out of 5.

- The ship starts off too slow
- Upgrades take too long to farm and farming for the same 3 materials over and over gets boring fast
- Not enough interesting treasures to find, a few basic rings etc...
- The rocks that appear out of nowhere in front of your ship in the dark is a ridiculous mechanic and annoying
- The "good / secret ending" is a chore to get and not fun
- There are 5 main areas of the game, they all look the same, all the islands are bland with no variety
- There is a steep learning curve to navigating the menus and upgrading your ship.  I didn't know I could upgrade a few things until about 3 hours in

I have always loved Lovecraftian horror, but some of Lovecraftian horror games that are really good are rarely seen. But, Dredge really nailed it! The graphics, art style, soundtrack/sound effects, and gameplay are really relaxing but still made me spooked by the Lovecraftian aspect of it. This game took me 21 hours to 100% achievement, AND I DO NOT REGRET IT! In fact, it was ONE OF THE BEST 21 hours of gameplay. To make it even more perfect, I played this game when I smoked my pipes with some of my favorite tobacco blends I had at the moment, so, it was like I was fishing and digging the cosmic horror of the Dredge's verse. Long story short, I recommend this game if you want a good time, 10/10 for game play and 11/10 for story. Kudos to the devs for creating a really good Lovecraftian horror!

DREDGE was good fun but not worth the full price. I upgraded my ship fully, did the majority of the main quests and clocked 12 hours total.

The atmosphere the game creates in the early hours was great, I had fun upgrading, learning and unlocking new powers, all whilst avoiding the perils of the night. After a certain point though, the game became a lot easier and really lost its spark.

One of the biggest failings is the lack of an engaging narrative, most quests are similar and meeting characters only served purpose to advance the completion of the story and unlock new equipment. There are also few cosmetic upgrades to your fishing vessel, something which feels like a bit of a missed opportunity.

One of the games saving graces (for fans of a grind) is the variety of fish you can collect and update in your journal. This however, isn't really my jam and after around 6-8 hours I'd grown tired of the core gameplay loop. I pushed through the remainder of the main quests (aside from the robed figure ones) and finished the story.

Net this on sale for a tasty catch, reel it in at full price and you'll feel a bit seasick.

PROS:
- Runs amazing on Steam Deck
- Beautiful art style
- Relaxed, simple gameplay

CONS:
- Uninspired story (aside from the Lovecraft influence)
- Lack of customisation
- Grows repetitive quickly

Oh what a lovely day to be a fisherman in an eldritch sea.

Dredge is a lovecraftian "Horror" game about finding mysterious artifacts and uncovering the origins of the misty fog that blankets the seas at night.

All in all, it was a pretty good experience. Fishing for new species and revoltingly delightful aberrations of said species provides a calming gameplay loop that is made a little scarier by the light horror aspects provided by the threats that the sea throws at you. 

The artstyle plays into the lovecraftian feel perfectly by making every character just a little bit ugly in some way. There isn't a single character in this game that has any features that could be considered "Cute".

Grid based inventory systems are always nice. And the fact that your equipment such as your fishing poles and your boat's engines are worked into the grid based inventory system is genius. This makes it so the slightest bit of damage to your boat could possibly render you unable to fish, see, or even move quickly, and by extension it keeps you on edge during the horror-y bits.

I do wish that the horror was dialed up a little bit, and that some of the monsters had some more interesting designs. Specifically the ones in the Gale Cliffs and the Devil's Spine. 

If you're looking for a bit of eldritch fantasy without having to put up with Cthulhu, start Dredging the depths today.

[h1]What will we do with a Chthonic Sailor?[/h1]
[b]Simplicity at its Best[/b]
Key features:
[list]
[*]Lovecraftian
[*]Easy to play
[*]Interesting RNG-based fishing[/list]
DREDGE isn't difficult to master. Navigate from one port to another, avoid riffs, catch fish and escape from giant beasts (if you can).
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3148213870
[b]Authentic Upgrades[/b]
Your ship needs improvements - more spaces, better fishing gear and engines. It makes sense to collect wood, metal scraps and linens, which are either bubbling in the waters or retrieved from shipwrecks. 

Enhancements also apply to fishing rods, crab pots, nest. Moreover, all come in different variety - one gear works only in shallow waters, other will operate in deep. That's where fishing fun begins.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3148207169
[b]Plenty of Fish[/b]
The Ocean. It's beautiful and dangerous. A sign of dolphins quickly changes for attacking underwater Colossus. Your precious cargo is picked by birds and a hurricane breaks remaining free slots. 

Capturing fish is a mini-game. So is lifting crafting materials and treasures. Anything you find then placed to the ship. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3148341536
The catch may be mutated and this type is much more rare. Hunting down all species is no joke - following specific conditions requires serious preparations. Baits, installation of unique rods, waiting for day or night, nets, particular depths for crabs... Did I say there are 5 biomes to explore? 

In the end, when you examine rare multiple eyed fish, deformed bodies and grinning fins, you know - it was worth it. 
[b]Wonderful game![/b]

I hadn't played a game quite like this before and I really enjoyed the novelty of a gotta catch 'em all eldritch sea creatures adventure. The general progression of the game is satisfying and as someone who enjoys collecting things and completing encyclopedias I felt right at home in Dredge. That said, I do see some room for improvement. 

There is minimal story going on here, but in a way that might be an intentional nod to the Lovecraftian style of 'show don't tell'. Still, the ending has a nice twist that I wasn't expecting and overall I was satisfied. Where it is lacking slightly is in side quests, which are few and mostly "catch this and bring it here" in nature. The fishing mechanic itself could use more diversification and added challenge considering how integral it is to the gameplay. It gets a bit repetitive after a while. 

I also think paranoia could have been utilized and incentivized more creatively. Generally it's presented as a liability, but some of the game's coolest visual effects and encounters happen when the meter is high. Adding quests and encounters that require high paranoia, aberrations that only appear while the meter is full, and perhaps the ability to hunt some of the terrors it attracts would be cool as well. The creep-factor definitely exists in Dredge, but I feel like they could have played to this strength even more.

Upgrading your boat is fun but still left me wishing there were more ways to customize. Also, being able to buy infinitely restocked upgrade items from the vendor makes upgrading too fast and easy. Money feels scarce at first, but will quickly cease being of any concern if you're fishing as much as they seem to expect you to be. Getting these upgrade items exclusively as quest rewards or from exploring would improve the pacing of progression. Given how small the map is, it would also be helpful if the DLC were better integrated with the main quest line. 

I strongly recommend giving Dredge a try if you're a horror-lite fan with a passion for collecting. An impressive first release!

I'm of two minds about giving this a negative review but I think I have to given the hype that sold me on this game was really misplaced.

To start with the good, the vibe and the aesthetic and the chill light-music set a really cool ambiance, the game does feel like sailing the stormy seas at night while the spookiness of the ocean is ready to take you under.

Unfortunately I think the game is mechanically super boring. The very first time you catch a fish is exactly the same as the last fish you catch. Every time they change the catching pattern up it doesnt do much to make it more interesting. The game feels perpetually like someone played outer wilds and thought "What if we took a bunch of bespoke planets and instead made 5 unique zones of puzzles to solve" but the puzzle is just get to the island, dont die to the thing that will kill you, and catch the unique fish in that zone. 

I thought about getting the DLC to see if it added anything more but by the time I finished the game I figured it was gonna be like 5 bucks to play more of exactly the same stuff. If this developer put out another game or a sequel and learned and added interesting mechanics that expand as you play I might be more interested. 

TL;DR; The game is a great aesthetic and vibe but it's not very interesting or fun to play

Pros:
-Very atmospheric and beautiful setting
-Well crafted progression system
-Gameplay consists of simplistic minigames for fishing and collecting other various equipment, doing various quests, and exploring which I found pretty enjoyable and relaxing (most of the time)
-The "horror" aspect is mostly in the ambience around you that the developers clearly put a lot of care and effort into. Plus some other silly little fellows you meet sooner or later :)
-Sound design pretty good
-I also fairly enjoyed the story and the ending(s).

Potential Cons :
-Gameplay loop could get boring as it gets quite repetitive but leads you to different locations to navigate in order to make up for it. It also throws new dangers your way to keep you on your toes. 
-Story outside of quests isn't really connected with the gameplay.
-Grinding is almost completely optional and tends to result in QOL changes compared to the main quests which give you essential abilities/upgrades 
-Storage Management was a real pain sometimes with some really large and odd shaped fish/supplies
-DLC locked achievements (Pale reach only to my knowledge)
-100 percenting the game was a real pain as some fish would spawn in very few and specific locations that I would never have been able to find without google
-On the shorter side if you rush through the entire thing.  

DLC:
 
Pale Reach:
ill update the review once i play through it but from what I've seen its more an early-mid game expansion as it adds another "main location." That wouldn't really change up anything for late game players or give them a super large advantage that's essential to beating the game. It being worth the 6 dollars is up to you. 

Blackstone Key:
Gives you 2 decent items. Good way to support the devs along with the artbook dlc but items aren't really worth it imo.
