Dredge immediately hooked me with its eerie atmosphere and consistently compelling loop of fishing, upgrading your ship, and exploring. Despite this strong beginning the game's sense of danger and tension steadily ran out over my roughly 10 hour playthrough. Side quests and other plot threads start off unsettling but start to feel disconnected and inconsequential. In a similar way the threats posed by mental stress and various sea monsters eventually become trivial as you learn to navigate them and your ship becomes fast enough to easily escape. Despite these flaws the overall package is short and sweet enough that I eagerly played until I'd seen all there is to see.

Now this is a proper game it's very relaxing when it wants to be and very intense when it wants to be and is very rewarding. Ignore all the people saying that it feels like an unfinished game, it feels as tho people just can't let some things be simple without over complicating it, which is unfortunate. I don't find it a $30 game more of a $20 game but either way you're still going to get your money's worth.

It's a very neat little fishing game, but it wants too much money for too little content.

Let's start with the good: The mood is set very well, the game is very stylish and the core gameplay is kept simple and rewarding. Fishing is a dexterity minigame, inventory management a la grid based is pleasant and an upgrade tree keeps you excited to bring back the next big haul. Setting wise the game shines, warning you of the dangers of the sea, and dangerous it is indeed. You're a tiny fisherman boat, and you will never be anything else. One hit to your boat may incapacitate your engine at every point in the game. 

The bad, however, is mostly that the game is very short. The main story can be finished in what appears to be just about 5-6 hours depending on whether or not you have a compulsive need to max out your gear. Map wise there are about 5 major regions in the game (which make the game feel very episodic), with each being able to be completed in about an hour. The game does feature hidden quests, secrets and bits and pieces of lore scattered around the map which can help with this. But for the vast majority of players who are not completionists it is questionable whether they will have the motivation to go for the side stuff.

Moving on to spoilers about the core gameplay and what does not work very well: [spoiler]The game successfully hints at eldritch horrors leaking beneath the surface, but they gradually lose their intimidating force. In the aforementioned episodic sections of the game one specific horror is introduced each time each with their specific weakness. These weaknesses are unfortunately easily recognized and exploited. Most can be straight up outrun given you have the gear, and even if you are caught you mostly get damaged a bit and trot home disgruntled. It's a bit perplexing that the game continuously introduces new gameplay ideas only to let you off the hook a minute later without requiring you to work around them, or awarding you massively powerful tools that neutralize every threat. Conceivably many of the issues of being able to breeze through the game would be solved by the possibility of a gruesome graphic death following a major slip-up.[/spoiler]

If you plan to [u]play[/u] this game, PLEASE read this minor spoiler! [spoiler]Even if you find the good end, do yourself a favor and watch the bad end first. It has immensely more impact. Wait to throw it back.[/spoiler]

Man, what a fantastic game. A wonderful bit of exploration, atmosphere, narrative, and audio all rolled into one. Good at keeping your attention and focus through the breadth of the game, with the openness to discover, travel, and complete at your own pace. A very complete experience that I won't soon forget, and that I enjoyed tremendously, especially the [spoiler]very haunting[/spoiler] ending (minor spoiler: [spoiler]Worth noting that I really mean the [b]bad[/b] ending[/spoiler]).

It has a few downers for certain. The game is (perhaps unsurprisingly) more horror [i] themed [/i] than truly horrifying, and the horror elements are really only surprising the first time you see them, after which they just become nuisances. Not the fault of the developers, it's clear the intent was that [i] the connotations of what is happening are the scary part [/i], not so much the gameplay, but something worth noting. Not all the achievements are particularly fun ([spoiler]Catching all the aberration fish can be a nightmare, even with your modifier built as high as it can go[/spoiler]), but achievements seldom are. 

As for the ending, [spoiler] ([b]endings[/b]), I found that the bad ending was far, far better than the good one. I appreciate that the reason the good ending fell with so much less impact was that the decision to what ending you make only happens in the final moments of the game, though you spend the entire game working towards the bad ending. A big win for the game is that the underlying forces for both of these endings is very well written and alluded to in the notes you discover throughout your journey, and you only really find the bad ending through decently thorough exploration of the game world, which realistically makes it less likely you will experience it. Also, the visuals, implications, and [i]especially[/i] the music are far more impactful in the bad end, making it feel both more like the ending I earned and the ending I would rather see from a production standpoint, especially a horror game. I actually feel like by trying the good end first, I really softened the impact of the ending, as when I immediately saw the bad ending after, I thought "wow, this ending is so much better!"[/spoiler]

Before you read my review, just one disclaimer: The game's horror vibe didn't click with me. The game satisfied a certain itch, but I would not recommend it.

[h3] The story [/h3]
From my perspective the by far weakest part of the game. Starts out interesting, but round-about mid-game there's basically nothing to keep you [i]hooked[/i]. Most of the side-quests just end without any real revelation, even those that would have an interesting story.
After completing the third (out of five) biomes, I mostly rushed the remaining part of the game to see its conclusion.

I found this aspect particularly frustrating as the mystery setting starts out strong.

[h3] "Quests" [/h3]
There are only fetch-type quests, nothing else. Some side-quests have you guessing what you have to fetch.

[h3] The horror aspect [/h3]
As written, it did not work for me. You quickly find out how to manage the horror, and at that point, it just falls over board to never return.

[h3] Controls [/h3]
I played the game entirely with a controller. Initially on the steam deck, but since the default button mapping isn't optimal and cannot be changed on the deck, I switched to PC.

In the game, there are basically three relevant areas for the controls:
[list]
    [*] The tetris-inspired inventory. Could not have been done much worse. I understand that this is the main focus of the game - but couldn't they implement it a little less clunky? I'm not asking for hand-holding, but why is a new item not placed on a free area if there is one? Or could the cursor at least remember its position when I have to switch between left and right panes?
    [*] Navigating the ship. There is a lack of tangible feedback on hitting objects. Sometimes I hit an obstacle an nothing happens, sometimes I barely brush something and the ship gets damaged
    [*] The fishing / dredging mini-game. Control-wise, there's nothing to complain. But they get repetitive and boring very fast (there's only 4 or 5 different ones) since you have to grind them a lot
[/list]
As stated above the default button-mapping is rather bad, and cannot be changed on the steam-deck at the time of writing this review (as soon as you open the respective menu, the game starts to scroll down and won't stop; haven't seen this behavior on any other game on the steam deck, or my laptop with this game)

[h3] Sound [/h3]
I actually found the changing background tunes very good and fitting to the mood.

[h3] Graphics [/h3]
The simplistic graphics fit to the overall tone and theme, and get the job done. Framerate is decent on the steam deck.

[h3] Progression [/h3]
Another weak spot. Progression comes in the form of grindable unlocks (ship improvements, research) and abilities unlocked through completion of the main story.
The abilities are unremarkable and don't provide much to the gameplay.
The grindable unlocks are - grindy. And poorly balanced. Several of the research unlocks can actually be only used when you have unlocked most of the ship improvements, especially the engines. Others are easily accessible nearly from the start and make the lower-level ones basically useless (trawl-nets, baskets)
Maybe it would feel more natural if the unlocks were gated by the story progression?

[h3] The verdict [/h3]
A weakly told story that could have been much more. A heavily repetitive main gameplay loop and a poorly designed progression system that relies on grinding.
Why did I complete it with all endings? I don't really have an answer for that. Up until mid-game, the weaknesses are not that obvious. The game allows to be played in very short sessions which fits well to my private situation. If it weren't for the button remapping bug, it would be a good fit for commutes with the steam deck. Or if you don't mind the default mapping.

Giving this a thumbs up but for the main game and not the ending. It's great building up your boat's capabilities and the core mood is quite homely and fun on a rainy night in, but the narrative is too short and the game ends abruptly.

I like the game somewhat, but some issues with it prevent me from recommending:

1.  Time changes way too fast.  It's like you just get started and the day is over with already.

2.  The ship takes damage way to easily.  I've done real fishing in 8-15 foot waves - We never got a scratch on the boat.

3.  There should only be one merchant that you can buy or sell everything with.  The separation of those things by fish, shipyard, etc is pointless.

4.  From a story stand point, the characters that you do tasks for are generally unpleasant.  Who would want to go on a fetch quest for someone that acts like an a_hole with a major superiority complex towards them?  In real life, I would have sailed away to somewhere else.

5.  I won't give it away, but there is one part of the game where you have to bait some traps.  There is zero feedback from the game that you did it correctly and I spent a lot of time driving around to the other traps guessing if it was right.  Spoiler alert:  I still don't know.

6.  The horror elements are stupid and take away from the main part of the game.  I would have enjoyed it more if just a straight forward fishing/upgrading/exploring/dredging adventure game in a chill format.  Even with turning off the monsters' ability to attack you, it's just not fun to me.  I would have liked exploring more and maybe solving a pirate mystery or something.

Sorry game makers, but I am deep sixing Dredge to the "Not recommended" rating.

This is the game I wish Sunless Sea would have been when I first played that title several years ago. While I loved that game's story, atmosphere, and lore, it was the gameplay that held back the experience from being truly great. Dredge, however, manages to have all of that on top of actually being enjoyable to play. It features a solid, easy to understand gameplay structure with fun mechanics and a simple, but rewarding progression system that guides the player through uncovering and exploring the game's hidden secrets throughout an ancient archipelago region set during the early 1900's. At first glance, you may think this will be a fun, light-hearted fishing game with a colorful art style and relaxed atmosphere. That's not quite the whole experience on offer here.

The truth is that Dredge is often also a horror game. It is equal parts fishing adventure and cosmic horror story. It's a game that embraces its Lovecraftian roots, utilizing them in a setting that makes you feel isolated, afraid, and alone. You'll explore ancient ruins, lost frozen wastes, and vast expanses of open water, sifting through the sea for forgotten treasures and ancient secrets. Those elements are only heightened more as the Sun begins to set and an oppressive, eerie fog settles in and wraps its sinister grip around your intrepid tugboat.

In exploring Dredge's secret-filled waters, I found myself scared at times, something I didn't expect would happen to the degree that it does. It's surprising how unsettling the game can be during its nighttime moments. As night falls, the feelings of dread and tension intensify, as the game begins to unleash all of its horror-filled surprises on you. These moments require you to make quick decisions on what to do when faced with the sudden terrors of the deep lest your ship and you end up sinking beneath the waves. With each passing hour, you're going to find yourself experiencing a story that while not new, nevertheless feels fresh due to its hands-off approach to player exploration and discovery, two features that are essential to Dredge's gameplay.

Dredge is the kind of experience best played with little to no prior knowledge of it going in. I could honestly say I wish there were more in this game as by it's conclusion I didn't want to stop playing it as I found it so engaging and fun. It's an experience I won't soon forget and hopefully this world will be further explored in the future. The twisted and mysterious world of Dredge is an experience you won't regret having.

TLDR. Not a terrible game, but I don't recommend buying it at full price since it's short already and I found it stopped being fun about halfway through the game. I only got about 5 hours of satisfying playtime out of the game.

I'm a big fan of Sunless Sea. I think that's why I found this game attractive. I was very happy with the game at first while I was learning the various mechanics and meeting the first few characters. Unfortunately when I reached the third zone of the game (about 3-4 hours into it) I realized the game was getting very repetitive. You essentially get to each new zone, look for specific types of fish to complete a quest and then move on to the next zone. The quests remind me of WoW quests to go find 5 vulture livers and 3 boar tusks. The story doesn't seem to offer any meaningful decisions, and I wasn't satisfied with the ending.

I found fishing to be tedious, especially searching for specific types of fish needed for quests. Crabbing was cool though. I have a strange fondness for crabbing in this game :). Repairing nets and pots was annoying, especially since managing inventory is a lot of trouble in this game, and you have to carry all the crab pots back to be repaired.

I wish the game had provided more meaningful choices for the story, roguelike mechanics, combat mechanics, seasons or other reasons to optimize my time each day, etc. The game was so simple that it seemed too much like a cozy game, and I prefer more difficult survival games.

The game starts really strong; if you look any of the screenshots/ gameplay examples & you like what you see, you'll probably really like the game. It's simply a fun game. It has a lot of little systems that intertwine and keep you hooked if you enjoy games with strong inventory management and the different fishing minigames. The art style is definitely the strongest aspect of the game, the story is enough to keep you moving, and the puzzles are fun little challenges that go along with the previously mentioned systems. 

The primary downsides to the game are the pacing and overall duration.
For the pacing, the last 30% of the base game REALLY starts to snowball, in a bad way. The gameplay loop is still fun, but most of the challenge has been negated, and you eventually are just ticking off boxes. Which can be good because, like I said, the game is still fun. But it is a little less riveting compared to the early game because there's not as much suspense, not as much fear, and you've likely seen almost everything the game has to offer by that point.
For the overall duration, I 100%'d the game in under 17 hours, including the Pale Reach DLC. I don't think the game is bad value because I really enjoyed my time (and truly, this game is the epitome of many of my favorite things), but I did expect the base game and the first (real) DLC to be a bit larger. I'll still eagerly buy the 2nd DLC when it arrives, but, it would be nice if it had some new challenges/systems/ideas.
(Oh, and the free updates are fun little additions that I‚Äôm glad they‚Äôve made.)

I was excited for this game because of the ‚Äúoverwhelmingly positive‚Äù reviews. However, I‚Äôm very disappointed.

This game is empty; lacking story and reason. All I keep asking myself is ‚ÄúWhat am I doing and why?‚Äù 

I fish. I dredge. I upgrade my boat, allowing me to fish and dredge more. I fish more. I dredge more. I upgrade my boat more. But why?

What am I doing this for? Maybe I skipped some text too fast and missed the story. But even if that‚Äôs not the case, there are and should be other ways to tell story. 

The gameplay is unique. The game is pretty. But it‚Äôs not enough. 

Sure games can get boring, but you keep playing because you have goals and story to work towards. But when a game like this makes you bored in the real world, to the point where you don‚Äôt even want to play anymore, that‚Äôs a bad sign.

Now, lets go through this with a list of pros and cons and a number rating

Dredge is the story of a fisherman who starts as the new angler of a small village. Soon you find out that something is wrong in the area. The art style looks very nice and the story is mysterious and interesting. The gameplay loop is fun and varied. If you want to support a small developer studio and if you want around 1,5 hour more gameplay time than I would recommend the dlc "the pale reach". The other dlc is just some ingame money to start easier of and two equipment parts. This parts are in the endgame pretty useless so actually you would not really need the "blackstone key" dlc to enjoy the game.  But both dlcs are not necessary because the maingame is good enough. It took me around 20 hours to 100% it and I took my time with it. 

Overall if you are in the mood for something new and different and maybe you see this game in sale I would highly recommend that you give it a try.

I enjoyed DREDGE so much that I played through it twice.  

It's more of a cozy game with spooky elements than a horror game, but the sanity loss effects can be very freaky at night sometimes, especially if your ship doesn't have many upgrades to avoid the most dangerous threats.  

There are a number of different sanity effects, too, which reminds me a bit of an old GameCube game called Eternal Darkness: Sanity's Requiem.  Sometimes you'll have to avoid illusory rocks that pop up in front of you, or a phantom ship that tries to ram into you at high speed.  There are other ones as well, but I don't want to give them all away.  

There are several different biomes that you visit to complete the main quest along with a bunch of smaller islands that can have treasure or side quests to complete, so this game really scratches that itch to explore like The Legend of Zelda: Windwaker did.  However it's a fairly short game unless you're trying to collect all of the fish so I feel like they could have added more areas.  

Collecting all the fish is the meat of this game since you need all kinds of different equipment to do this as well as some spells that you get from completing parts of the main quest to make this easier.  There are also puzzles that give you special equipment if you manage to solve them, which can help a lot if you're trying to get all of the aberrations.  

The artwork for the aberrations is quite well done and I remember saying "eww" every time I hauled one of them onto my boat.  While they are harmless (unless you're dumb enough to eat one) they add to this impending sense of doom that permeates the game's atmosphere.  

I do wish they would add a harder difficulty for this game because by the time I finished the third biome my ship was pretty fast and able to avoid most threats so it was easy to get through the last two areas.  I have the DLC and while I like the new ice biome it didn't take too long to complete.  Hopefully they will make a sequel with more stuff to do since the environment is excellent and the mechanics are addictive.  

Anyway, if you like exploring and collecting stuff you should enjoy this game even if it does feel a bit short.

Very Unique and charming art style and aesthetics. The sound design is also top notch for a eldritch mystery type game. The gameplay is split up between 3 main elements, sailing your boat while avoiding obstacles and enemies, timing button presses when prompted while fishing, and diablo-esque inventory management for your catches. These all do their jobs of keeping the player involved and focused while moving from zone to zone. I was able to 100% the game minus the DLC in under 18 hours, and during this playthrough the only dull moments were fishing for rare/fringe catches that are entirely optional and provide no change to the main story or otherwise. Overall a solid story driven adventure with a touch of Cthulhu to keep you wanting more.

Simply stunning. Incredible depths when it comes to the levels of details for a very immersive gameplay experience. Can't recommend this game enough. Only downside is that the game feels pretty quick to complete - i got a prompt to enter the final stage of the game after 10 hours of gameplay and is now chasing every achievements possible for completionist.

The game is very fun, unique and looks great, but it has an issue with save files disappearing. Based on forums it has been a known-issue for at least six months. I had almost beaten it at about 16 hours and then it just brought me straight to start a new game, no sign of my old save anywhere. I think I got my money's worth but that is a deal-breaker for me.

This game checked all my boxes. Resource management collectathon with a great vibe, compelling setting, just enough story to keep it interesting, and an incredibly addictive "just one more" game-play loop that was impossible to put down. It's a bit short (I ran out of things to do after ~14 hours of casual play with minimal meta gaming), but it's the first game that I've gone for 100% in a very long time, and there's something satisfying about really eking every last drop out of a game before it becomes a slog. This may well be my 2023 game of the year.

I enjoyed this relaxed, atmospheric, slow-paced game!

PROS:

- Really relaxing and not particularly scary, but has a continuous air of mystery to keep you thinking what will happen next.
- A handful of fun puzzles, places to explore, and optional secrets to "dredge" up.
- Very pretty, but simple, graphics. I found it satisfying to pull up new fish, especially... messed up fish. The colorful cast of characters was also wonderful.
- Who doesn't love a little bit of existential horror these days?

CONS:

- The slow pace may not be every player's cup of tea, even with puzzles and story thrown in. There is occasionally some grinding for items and money, but once you start to make bank it gets almost too easy.
- There is no dread for something as dreadful as lovecraftian horror. The ocean having freaky monsters in it is sorta treated like a normal occurrence in the game, removing some of the fear and mystery.
- I found the twist cool and unexpected, but the endings to both be anticlimactic. For example, the game tells you there's no going back and you can't save once you agree to do the ending, but you just move your boat to a point and a cut scene plays, then it ends. Why give a warning in the first place? It isn't like there is any decision making once you start the ending.

Overall, I can see why this is a game a lot of people like, and I had fun! But I could also see why someone might prefer just to watch a lets play of it instead.

This game is something else. I have found myself enthralled with its design, story and game play. To start with its design is so simplistic yet beautiful, I love each characters art design and the overall design of the world. It gives me feelings of utter dread when I see what lurks below. The story is quite linear, but with the choices and outcomes of my actions I truly got attached to my lone angler out on the open sea. Finally, the game play for me is what makes me recommend this game to any casual or hardcore gamers. The quick-time mini games are addicting and have a skill to them. The progression is pretty gradual but the snowball is rewarding as my ship gets faster and easier to go on far out trips on. The sanity and day/night mechanics give you such a sense of fear early on as you dont know what it entails, but as your character grows darker you too feel less and less threatened by those late night casts. Finally and my personal favourite, the movement. I love movement shooters, and any game with solid movement makes me fall in love. The drifting and dodging obstacles feels fair and when I crash(So often) I dont feel cheated. The price on dredge is a little high for a base game I completed in less than 15 hours, but I think if you are playing more casually it is totally worth it, especially on sale. I have heard the DLC are lacking in content, but I have not played. Also My wife divorced me for playing this game instead of watching our infant daughter but babies are vigrin betas and im a dredgepilled giga chad so i dont care.

Not just a fishing simulator.  You're the captain of a tiny fishing vessel in a remote archipelago beset by an unspeakable evil.  Complete quests and recover objects and clues from the depths to solve the mystery.  Catch dozens of fish species, and their foul aberrations!  Upgrade your boat to fish in deeper or more hostile waters!  Avoid ghost sharks, glowing piranha, demonic hermit crabs, and the deadly kraken!  The Pale Reach DLC is a nice addition for those who've mastered the regular game.  Take all the above and throw in icebergs and a hungry narwhal.  Not a happy game by any means, but an engaging experience that never felt grindy.  This game is worth your time.

This game was an odd mix of stressful and relaxing. The ending was pretty predictable, but the fact I saw it coming didn't ruin it. 

The only complaint I have is my complaint with most games like this: I just don't have the time to grind like these games want you to. You kind of suffer if you don't spend a lot of time just out there fishing for random fish to sell for better equipment, and it's irksome when I have an hour to play a game and more than half of that is just skimming around fishing for anything so that I can have enough money to buy the next fishing line I need in order to fish in a new area. That also goes for the missions that are basically 'Go over to this place on the NW corner of the map. Now go to the SE corner. Now back to the NW. Now to the center." Thankfully, this game is pretty light on that stuff, and it's not nearly as annoying as in other games. Being able to put on a podcast or audiobook and just sail around fishing when I need to let my mind wander for 20 minutes can be calming. Having to do it for 30 minutes just to be able to freakin' fish in the Mangrove area is frustrating.

Well, one thing for sure, this is a unique game. I can imagine the developers on a late night meeting, trying to decide what to do with their fishing game, a relaxing cute cartoonish or a tense cosmic horror one. And then, after a few beers, "why not both?"...

It's definetely not a sprawling open-world sandbox, but it works for what it proposes.  Gameplay-wise, it's an easy and user-friendly game. For one side, it makes for a swift and pleasant exploration/progression. For the other, it has little strategy involved, since upgrade trees are very linear and there are few compromises to make. Mostly what fishing gear to load between trips, but swapping them costs nothing and your storage is avaliable everywhere.

Nevertheless, the fishing/selling/improving/exploring loop is so pleasant that halfway through the story I already fully upgraded my ship. After that, all I had to do is to finish the story relatively fast, although still with some interesting stuff to do.

The cosmic horror element is mostly a background. There were few moments were it affected gameplay. The twist of the night being the "scary time" was seldomly relevant in my playthrough, because besides a few quests, there isn't really any reason to risk yourself at night.

So I definetely recommend the game for anyone who likes Lovecraftian vibes and simple but fun minigames, but don't expect a horror game. Also, players on a budget should think twice. since you'll get some 15-hour content from this, and replayability it's close to zero (there are two endings, but you can unlock both from the final save).

A neat little exploration game that doesn't have a lot of content. I found the gameplay loop of explore-fish-dock compelling, although it ran out of surprises quite quickly. 

The game consists of several islands of content, each of which has its own gimmick (think the Outer Wilds). But the map is also quite small, it takes just minutes to completely traverse each island, and while there are secrets to find and obstacles to overcome, it still isn't much. In 11 hours I have completely all but 1 of the islands, and I was taking it very slowly with a lot of time spent just fishing.

On the horror aspects I found Dredge to be disappointing. (just discussing it would qualify as spoiler so the rest will be censored) [spoiler] While the atmosphere is pretty great and for a while I got spooked by just the visuals, from a gameplay perspective really all there is to the horror is "a monster comes and damages your ship then leaves". Once you realize how little threat they really are it stopped being scary at all.

The game also barely delves into the idea of people going crazy from Eldritch knowledge. There is one character which does, but you had like 1 interaction with him prior and 0 interaction after he goes crazy so it barely matters. Your own sanity just means you are more likely to be attacked, which as I mentioned prior is very inconsequential, and you can become sane again by just waiting.

Although while fishing you can sometimes get corrupted fish, which is very intriguing.[/spoiler]

As someone who appreciates the works of HP Lovecraft I'm shocked I let Dredge go as unnoticed as many of the eldritch horrors in the late writer's works. But like any acolyte of the cult of Cthulhu, I'm glad it surfaced.

On the surface, Dredge may seem like a simple fishing game where you... fish for fish... but there's much that lurks beneath the choppy and uninviting waves of the game's surface. For starters, there's a very palpable aura of mystery surrounding almost every element of the game; the characters, setting, and lore all convey a sense of uneasiness with the goings-on of the deep. You play as an unnamed fisherman, recently shipwrecked and given a new vessel with which to continue plundering the depths for fish, treasures, and the like. Your days are spent fishing, selling your catches, repairing and upgrading your boat, uncovering sunken trinkets, and doing it all over again the next day. However, very early on you're given a stern and ominous warning to never venture into the open waters after dusk... lest ye find yerself stuffed into Davy Jones' locker like a sardine packed into a can! This warning is obviously meant to entice you to explore the waters after dark, tempting fate and trying your luck. This is where Dredge truly shines.

Though there are plenty of fish in the sea for you to catch, there are none more horrifying or awe-inspiring (depending on what type of person you are) than the Aberrations. Aberrations are like the twisted hell-spawn versions of the regular fish you catch: an eel with two heads at each end, a three eyed cod, a squid with bulging bulbous masses protruding from its tentacles... the list goes on. The game even plays a discordant little melody whenever you snag one of these monstrosities, and it's enough to send a shiver down your spine. I loved catching these Aberrations, and the game will sometimes mark places in the water where you can find one, but it was always better to fish in an unmarked spot and pull up a deformed crab with a glowing, pulsating shell. But perhaps what's even more surprising is that you can sell these Aberrations to any fishmonger or merchant, and they'll hardly bat an eye. With that, I do wish that the Aberrations played a larger role in the game, instead of being relegated to what is essentially a lottery system that begins to lose its effectiveness with each collected creature.

Another unique element of Dredge is that, like SuperHot, time only moves forward when you do. So if you moor your boat at a dock the sun, too, will moor itself in its current position in the sky. It's an interesting enough element, though it only really applies to the early game when your boat lacks engines powerful enough to carry you long distances in a single day before the sun sets. By the late game when you've upgraded your vessel to be more of a drug-smuggling speedboat than a bulky trawler you can accomplish much more in a single day than you could before. It is true that much of the early-game challenges become trivialized due to your late-game upgrades, but you also can't just not upgrade your vessel. Or maybe you can, idk.

There are four "biomes" in Dredge, each with their own unique flora and fish-a, and without spoiling anything each of these builds on the last (if you discover and explore them in the way the game wants you to) and challenge your fishing and survival prowess. The game's art style and direction also do much to lend to the beauty of each biome, giving them a chance to shine both day and night.

The story in Dredge is not as deep as the fathomless depths you sail across, but it's certainly deeper than a puddle. Much of the story is inferred rather than told, and there are two satisfying endings you can earn when it's all said and done. There are lots of side quests for you to sink your hooks into, but most are admittedly a variation of "catch fish, give fish." Because it is an indie game, I do have to cut their lines some slack, but I truly wish there was just more of this game, its world, its characters, and so on...

Overall, Dredge is one of the better indie games I've played in recent memory. The fishing mechanics are simple, the lore is interesting and inspired, and the gameplay loop is as rewarding as you make it. As sad as I was to drop anchor on this game, I'd be more than happy to hoist the sails and batten down the hatches if more content (besides the existing DLC) were to be released.

Looking forward to more releases from this NZ game studio!

[b]Short version:[/b]
+ Fairly fun gameplay loop
+ Super atmosphere

- May be a bit lacking in challenge
- Not much in it past the main story

[b]Long version:[/b]
First of all it's impossible to look past how spot on the game gets the atmosphere. It's great in every aspect. The character art, overall visual style, the effects. Whoever did the art direction on this deserves a medal. In addition there are little touches here and there that give each area it's own unique look and the way how the lighthouse shines from far away all across the map is brilliant. 
The gameplay is a mix of time management and minigames. There are some enemies, but at least for the main storyline it was super easy to just absolutely avoid them. So the challenge side seemed a bit lacking. Then again if it were harder, it might become annoying. So you go out and usually try to make it back before it gets dark, because then there are more spooky things out on the water. The interesting thing is that as you upgrade your engine, the boat doesn't move that much faster but the clock ticks away slower. So the whole world is shown to be just a representation of the actual world, not 1:1 of what's really there. Which works well with the whole style as well.
While I had a fun time fully upgrading the boat and going through the story, the rest of the gameplay really isn't interesting enough to 100% it, which I usually do. I can see what more there is and it's just fetching collectibles and grinding a few final achievements and the world is not full enough for that. It works perfectly fine as a self contained adventure in terms of the main storyline, but once you've seen that, you've seen most of the game. But don't get me wrong, what's there is pretty great and totally worth checking out.

A very cozy and relaxing game. Don't be afraid of venturing into the night, there are sea creatures but they only give you playful nudges from here and there. And also you'll meet a friendly fisherman! Beep the foghorn and he will come charging right at you, out of excitement of course so no need to panic. Can't really blame the guy when you've been sailing the seas for a long time and probably haven't seen another soul. Oh and if you're the adventurer type like me, who likes to wander off into the edge of the map, if you see this message "Entering uncharted waters, TURN BACK" pfff relax! it's nothi-

I purchased The Dredge a few months ago and never played it, I then picked up a Steam Deck and started playing Dave The Diver on the deck. After beating Dave and playing the free Dredge crossover content i came back to my past un-played purchase. I'll say no regrets, amazing theme, feelings of isolation, good pacing. 

The only negatives I personally see are the somewhat clunky inventory GUI but over all you get used to it.

If you're looking for something with a compelling story to play single player the Dredge is worthy.

It's... alright? This game feels as though it was manufactured, made-to-order. As if someone said, "I would like a Lovecraftian-tinged fishing game with some very mild horror elements" and the developer delivered one. It passes the sniff test, but doesn't really have a lot of pizzazz.

The actual fishing and dredging are fine. Mildly satisfying at best, absolute drudgery at worst. The setting is relatively nondescript and never really stands out. The art style is neat, but pretty tame in its horror elements. The writing is functional, but extremely predictable and it didn't make me emotionally invested in any of the characters. Everything on display is thoroughly [b]alright[/b]. I stopped playing a few hours in before watching most of the rest, which did not seem appreciably different from what I experienced.

As a result, I'm pretty surprised that Dredge is such a smash indie hit. The only reason I'm giving it a negative review is because I feel like I've got better versions of it split across different games.  Sure, Sunless Sea can be even more of a slog, but it's got an extremely unique setting and a real finesse to its writing. And you could play any of the Amnesia games if you really wanted to shit your pants.

I guess true Lovecraftian horror is that I can't fathom why somebody would pick [i]Dredge[/i].

Spoiler warning: Very light spoilers in the form of vague descriptions of a few areas in the game as well as a few game mechanics. I kept spoilers to an absolute minimum. So if you want to go play this game *completely* blind, skip this review.

I have been enjoying the heck out of Dredge. I can't recommend it enough. It is such a wonderful game. I don't know how the devs managed to make this game both relaxing and somewhat unsettling simultaneously, but it's the perfect mix of both.

During the day when you're fishing it feels like real fishing: relaxing and kind of exciting to see what you might get. And you have to learn where the different types of fish hang out and which equipment works best for each scenario. You can catch all kinds of different fish and fill up your little encyclopedia with the information. And each fish has a few aberrations of itself that you can find which is cool. You can also dredge up materials and unique items, as well as things to decorate your boat.

Since there's a lovecraftian aspect to this game, at night it gets a bit spooky. But it also has a passive game mode where it can still get spooky but you won't be in actual danger if you're looking to just experience the story and the game world. There are a few places in the game that I'm absolutely terrified of but I think that's mostly because I am terrified of the idea of being in the middle of a large body of open water. And don't even get me started with basins and blue holes. I am completely and utterly terrified of those. Like there's no way I could *ever* play Subnautica. That's how scared I am of the ocean. Anywho. Needless to say, I had to put the game in passive mode for a little while in two different areas because I am a sea coward. Despite one of the areas being breathtakingly beautiful because everything has bioluminescence, there's an eldritch horror beyond comprehension nearby and I just couldn't handle it. Heh. But even for someone with a touch of thalassophobia, Dredge has a very welcoming environment.

Upgrading your boat is really great as well. It feels rewarding. Everything in the game feels rewarding to do. It's a perfect sit-back-and-relax sort of game. I'm super happy with it. You even get a little camera in the game at one point so that you can take pictures of cool things. Sometimes a whale will leap out of the water or something like that. Or dolphins will hop by. Fun little moments like that. Also, the game is pretty kid-friendly, so if you're looking for a unique game to get your kid for their birthday or something, this is a great choice. Sure, it has spookiness but there's nothing inappropriate in it, and the spookiness is arguably very mild. It's just that kind of that lovecraftian unsettling kinda spooky.

It runs flawlessly on Steam Deck and the PC system requirements are very reasonable, so not only is it a fantastic game, but it's extremely accessible for a lot of people to play. I think it's on Xbox as well. Everything about this game is fantastic. The art style is awesome. I can't find a single thing to complain about. Just praise all around.

100/10 highly recommend this game for anyone.

It's alright, I guess. I completed it in one sitting. However, I think the developers failed to properly implement a few key aspects that would have allowed the game to stand out from the crowd:
* Steady progression. At the moment it awfully slow at the start (first 1-2h), it speeds up a goddamn lot in the mid game (when you upgrade your engines) and there is mostly nothing to do for the last quarter of the game. (aside from trying to catch them all)
* Lovecraftian horror. Ngl it's awesome in the beginning. But once again, by the midgame you've seen most of it aside from a few. I lose that feeling that something is lurking around too quickly and it becomes just a fishing game with "quests". The game doesn't really use the fear of the unknown.
* Exploration. It's good until you reach the second archipelago. Then you realise that the areas differ from each other in fish, maybe zone-specific monster and crustations. They feel the same
* Upgrades. They're alright. But there is too little of them and the part that upsets me the most: devs show you basically the whole progression tree. So the feeling of getting something new and existing doesn't exist. It's more like: hey, i can now catch 1.5 more fish per day, yay?
* Story. Exists and quite predictable

Good, clean game that is tame in both time investment (21 hrs for all achievements personally) and gameplay. Somewhat fits the notion of a chill, lay-back fishing game. Art is very similar to Risk of Rain 2, which I hold personal bias and adore. I did not play with The Blackstone Key DLC and can't speak to it.

I will say though, the amount of content supplied, especially in The Pale Reach DLC, is limited. This is very much a fetch-quest game. Also, difficulty if you can call it that, can be straight-up avoided, however this does fit the laidback vibe the game presents.

Honestly, would really have liked more progression given the amount of supplies that are generally available, especially in the late-game. Also game world is somewhat small, though this may fit the theme and possibly the intent of the devs for this title to be like a "short-story" rather than a large novel.

Story itself has a strong lovecraftian theme, however I feel the ending leaves things unanswered and personally unfulfilling.
However, I speculate that this is an establishing title, laying foundation for future iterations to expand.

Overall, clean title with little-to-no bugs observed, gameplay very chill and themes and art intriguing to just sit back and jam. I recommend getting at a discount. I am also not aware of any mods, etc, that may make this game more enjoyable.
Mods and other 3rd-party content would seem to be great, as the foundation this game has is great.

Average Playthrough of DREDGE

Step 1: Looks like a pretty cozy game, doubt much could go wrong here.

Step 2: ...I don't think that's a fish.

Step 3: That was a weird guy... but hey! Now I can dredge, like the name of the game!

Step 4: Got it! now I can head back to the guy!

Step 5: Made it to Galestone Cliffs, what a pretty spo- what was that roar?

Step 6: AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

Step 7: Cool, now they're happy, I got bombs, and now I got that.

Step 8: Ain't this place pretty... and I instantly spot the kraken, great!

Step 9: Got you some samples, and now I can actually get to the spot above the kraken without dying!

Step 10: HAHA! I CAN FIGHT BACK! ...Once per day, damn it.

Step 11: Now I'm at the swamp... now how do I get in?

A beautiful, innovative and engaging game. Full of truly original ideas, with very fluent gameplay. There are very few bottlenecks in the story, usually you just do what you want and progress -- there were only a few points in the game where I needed outside help, and even then, a bit more exploring would have done the trick. 

I also bought the DLC, it is a very nice addon to the game, with more exciting mechanics and a very satisfying side story.

The cosmic horror elements are also very enjoyable and gripping, it is very distinctivly Lovecraftian without copying anything from existing literature.

Replayability does not seem very hard for me -- the game is very straightforward, once you finished the game, there is very little incentive from doing it again. [spoiler]All endings are accessible from a single playthrough, you can always go back to your last save and keep playing, just as the ending have never happened.[/spolier]

Dredge is delightful. I've spent the last two days glued to this game exploring every last bit of it. All in all it's a perfectly portioned adventure that doesn't overstay its welcome, and I feel like it does all the things it set out to do really well. If anything I left the experience wishing there was more things to do, and I think that's a good feeling to have when putting a game down.

It straddles the line between horror and casual gaming masterfully and I don't think I've played a game before that has had me feeling both tense and relaxed at the same time. The gameplay loop is solid, and the progression system keeps everything feeling fresh up until the end. Exploring the world feels rewarding and there were several times where I just had to pause and take in the sights. The sound design is also in a league of its own and after 20 hours it never got old or felt grating for even a moment. It looks great, feels great, and sounds great. 

The world felt interesting and gave me just enough of a glimpse behind the curtains to leave me both intrigued and horrified at the implications of what's actually going on. And to cap everything off, the game has a great ending that really took me by surprise. It's not a super long game, it doesn't have a lot of replayability, but for what it is it's 100% worth it and I think you should play Dredge if you just like to kick back and invest a weekend into exploring what lies just beyond The Marrows.

It's like a game full of fishing mini games, which is what I was hoping for.
Relaxing, open world, and full of sea monsters.
It looks like the last 1/4th of the achievements are part of the DLC, so I'll probably end up buying that to try for 100% on this.

This is one of the tougher decisions on recommending a game or not, because the bones of this thing are excellent. The problem is that it doesn't have much more than just bones. Bones are it. The whole environment they have created promises depth like the ocean but it's more like a puddle. I know that my playtime shows lots of hours, but I had it on pause for almost an entire day, the actual game was short and annoyingly shallow. There is frustratingly little to see, do, figure out, and achieve. The game feels about 1/6 complete: barely more than a demo. Too polished to be early access, too unfinished to be a complete game.

I'm concerned that these Lovecraft-inspired games are leaning too heavily on style and not enough on content, which is a tremendous pity since Lovecraftian horror should give the best, most unique content around. The imagery for this one is great, the look of the thing is beautiful, the dialogue (what little there is) is extremely well-written, it's just way, way, way not enough. You could argue that the hallmark of a good game is that it leaves you wanting more, but this one leaves you wanting more because it never delivered in the first place.

That said, I think I am going to break a long standing rule that I've had for this game. I've long said that I will not purchase a DLC to fix a broken game. If the creators couldn't release the game in a finished state then I'm not going to pay them extra to do so. I've held to this for a good twenty years, but I might... MIGHT consider downloading the DLCs to expand this world and see what happens. However, if you look at the reviews of the currently released DLCs, it's not promising. I recommend putting this one on your watch list and seeing if they add content. If they do, definitely buy it. If they don't, I think it's a miss.

Dredge is a unique and memorable experience that surprised me with how well its world pulled me in and kept me entertained over the 10 hours it took me to complete its campaign. However, its short playtime and lack of replayability make it worth the money if you pick it up on sale. 

The horror elements of this game are outstanding. I found myself going from being soothed by the many minigame fishing activities to unsettled by a sudden rumbling sound from the deep to screaming as that sound was actually a hellspawn fish chasing me through the ocean. The devs perfectly captured that feeling of being small and vulnerable in an ocean and there were many times I got chills from looking down and seeing something massive underneath me. 

The musical score is never overbearing with much of the game's audio being your boat, fishing, or listening to the oceanic wildlife. But when the music does come in it fits the tone of the situation perfectly.  

Exploration is satisfying and I enjoyed searching all of the nooks and crannies the game offered. Each "biome" has fun fish to find and new fish means weird new monster fish to discover as well.

This is a game filled with minigames to dredge up loot needed for boat upgrades or catch fish to buy said upgrades and equipment. It's surprisingly fun and I was never bored even though I don't care for minigames much. 

I don't really have anything negative to say about this game and I think it's wonderful, but for me, $25 is a touch high for a game I won't play again. For the completionists out there you will get more bang for your buck. Hope this helped!

2) My money eventually becomes worthless. Once you invest in research you get better gear. Better gear leads to making better money. The best gear means you make a LOT of money. Eventually, selling fish for money becomes pointless since you have SO MUCH. Since you have the BEST gear making the MOST money you no longer have anything to really spend all that money on because you have the BEST gear. Doesn't make it a bad game. Just kinda "what do i do with all this money..."

Much like other recent fishing indie darling, Dave The Diver, Dredge is an extremely competent game with very little to say for itself and almost no new ideas whatsoever. It's an excellent few evening's of entertainment if you're the kind of player who likes obsessively upgrading a vessel so that it is more resilient in a very dangerous world. The push-your-luck-and-get-punished-for-your-hubris fishing during the spooky nights mechanic is interesting and a great way of pushing you out of your comfort zone (weirdly, a mechanic the game shares with Dying Light).

The promotional-material teased aberrant fish don't matter in any great way (cool as it is to have a different, more valuable sprite to play inventory Tetris with). A couple of quests require them, but since they're a random drop most of the time, it's probably for the best that they don't do anything. 80% of the time you're finding fish to sell or progress a quest with. It's a fine time.

The elephant in the room is Sunless Sea: which has (bad) combat instead of Dredge's (basic rhythm action) fishing. Sunless has an exquisite novel's worth of branching, bizarre, Lovecraftian tales instead of Dredge's 2000ish words spread across about 10 characters with precisely one choice, right at the end of the game. Sunless has an eldritch reef (Sunless's has an alien intelligence that challenges you to a game of something like chess viewed from a non-euclidean angle, whilst Dredge's has a normal reef with a really, really big octopus), Sunless's ruins poking out of the ocean are cyclopean and terrifying (Kingeater's Castle: go mad, eat your crew), whilst Dredge's has generic Lovecraftian fish cult ruins with a cultist who you help do a thing that doesn't seem to matter much. For the 5 areas in Dredge, Sunless has 3 times as many interesting, more thought-provoking ideas. The music in the sunless games is far more varied and evocative, too.

So, what do you get if you remove the (bad) combat and (good) writing of sunless sea? Fetch-quests with an upgradable ship. What is Dredge? Rythmn-action fishing fetch-quests with an upgradable ship.

I don't hate it. It's a solid game. But where the hell were you all when Sunless Sea/Skies came out?

I started playing DREDGE & DYSMANTLE a couple of weeks ago, and I love DREDGE. (DYSMANTLE not so much).  The fun I am having in DREDGE reminds me of when I was playing Slime Rancher a couple of years ago.  It is a fun game of building up your boat, fishing to earn money, exploring all the islands, and there is a dark mystery underneath the surface. (of both the game & the water).

Now games like this can often be described as grindy. But I don‚Äôt consider it grindy if you are having fun.  And DREDGE, like Slime Rancher before it kept me very entertained, and are both fun to play.  Now, DYSMANTLE, that felt like a grind.

I also enjoyed the graphics in DREDGE.  This can be a problem in some indie games.  DREDGE is in a bundle with a game called Dave the Diver that I had heard a lot of good things about.  However, when I saw the ugly pixel graphics of Dave, I could not imagine looking at those horrible images for hours while playing that game.  C‚Äômon guys, make an effort.  DREDGE has graphics that the Devs clearly spent a lot of time getting just right.

I am twenty hours in now, and I look forward to many more hours playing this fun game.

Fishing is incorporated into so many games across so many genres, the idea of a game that is almost completely fishing might not sound appealing. Dredge is a reminder why fishing is everywhere. There's so much patience, tension, excitement, relief, and discovery wrapped into a relatively small minigame. Dredge makes every fishing opportunity special. Even when you're catching the same fish in the same place as the previous day, there are always fun new wrinkles to unpack, whether its a new type of fish, a new fishing mechanic, or something spookier...

If Dredge was just this stellar fishing game, I would have had a great time. But layered on top of this are so many other aspects, from upgrading your boat to completing quests for different people on different islands to the excellent story. It's shocking how cool and interesting the story is in this game and how well it is conveyed and paced when the main thing you do is catch fish. Fishing is a side activity in most other games, but here it's the main event and enjoyable front to back. This is one of those games I recommend to anyone, no matter what their taste in games is. It just rocks!

A very fun game with engaging fishing mechanics, a deep story and lore, and a satisfying progression system.

The beginning area of the game just oozes with the bleak charm of cold, northern climate with dark undertones and sets the tone amazingly well. That area also has the most going on with charactes, quests, and story lines.

Sadly that can't be said about the following islands. Second area still has a few people to give the place some life, but from the third island to the fifth there's always only one story npc and the themes and biomes feel disconnected from the rest. You go there to find a trinket, you help someone until you get said trinket, then you leave. Those areas feel more like stretch goals from a kickstarter campaign than an integral part to the story. Areas 3 to 5 feel like isolated micro-cosms.

It's still well worth playing, but the beginning of the game shows that it had the potential to be so much more.

This has its charm, particularly early on when the mystery is enticing and you feel the threat of madness from everything around you. I loved the first time I called over a ship only to be attacked by a spirit, or the unavoidable damage from certain projections. But eventually, you realize it‚Äôs all kind of the same, and the loop doesn‚Äôt evolve with enough of a challenge to do anything interesting. It‚Äôs fun, don‚Äôt get me wrong, but I would have loved for the gameplay to get increasingly complex ‚Äî and for the madness mechanic to leave actual impact on my character. By the fourth island I literally stopped sleeping, because through books and boat speed I just wasn‚Äôt going mad anymore‚Ä¶ with no repercussions. Odd. Enjoyed it, but felt it could be better, particularly when it comes to tying together themes with gameplay. More NPCs, more hallucinations, and more horror!

tl;dr -  Love this game so far! A unique adventure RPG with interesting gameplay mechanics and a unique visual style that both set it apart from many of the adventure games I've played! 100% recommend!

I actually wishlisted Dredge BEFORE people started playing it on YouTube because it appeared in my discovery queue and I remember just seeing the screenshots and immediately falling in love with the art style of this game. It's simultaneously beautiful and unsettling in just the right kind of way! This game reminds me a little bit of a cartoon I used to watch back in the 2000's titled The Misadventures of Flapjack art direction wise, although that show was WAY more unsettling, and I gotta admit, I'm oddly into it!

In terms of gameplay and story, I'd pretty much call this an adventure RPG, and I've only scratched the surface! The fishing and dredging minigames are both quite fun and I like them a lot! Overall, this game is already very unique from the other adventure games I've played in terms of how it's structured. I like the way the "inventory" takes the form of your ship and the fishing equipment, lighting, and engines take up space the same way items do, and the way certain items take up more space than others or fill space in awkward shapes creates this sort of limited feeling to the inventory, and this contributes to another thing I really like about this game, there's this constant need to run back to a town not only to unload your inventory but also to avoid getting stranded out at sea in the fog at night, and I know this is only in my mind, but I can't help but compare that to the rush to get back to administration before the generator runs out in Amnesia: The Bunker, it's definitely the same type of tension, anyway, and I gotta admit, I'm really into it! This is also the first game I've ever played where time only passes when you're moving or doing something, which is also quite cool! I'm also getting pretty invested in the story now. The world this game is set in seems a lot more H.P Lovecraft inspired than I was expecting and I find that really cool because most of the time Lovecraft inspired games tend to be horror games and it's refreshing in a way to see a game that isn't a horror game, at least not in the traditional sense, utilize Lovecraftian storytelling and world-building tropes the way this game does. 

Overall, I'm enjoying this game a lot so far, and I can't wait to see what else is in store.

I AM playing this game on a controller, by the way. Steam says that Dredge is "mostly playable" on an X-box controller, but so far the controller support seems fully built in and functional, so if that's worrying you, then fear not!

Having said all that, I recommend the game and consider it a nice little addition to my library.

Dredge (SDOLED, 10.6 Hours)

This was an awesome indie that surprised me. I picked it up after seeing the crossover trailer with Dave the Diver, and then heard good things from around the internet.

You're an angler working to help with an island's fishing needs. You fish, dredge up resources from ship wrecks (both to help residents and to improve your own boat), and help the locals. All seems normal for a little bit...

Resource management is cool, has a tetris kind of overlay to it. There's a day and night cycle, with different things happening at both times, including what's biting. Traversal is limited at first, but opens up in cool and interesting ways as you progress. The encyclopedia of fish is very helpful as you try to fulfill everyone's needs.

Story was simple but good, had a good twist I didn't see coming, which really fleshed out the whole of it. Won't go into spoilers of course.

A satisfying short game, that scratched the itch I wanted it to, and didn't overstay its welcome. I certainly recommend it.

Relaxing but also a bit.... creepy. I mean it's all good and wonderful until you go towards a distant boat and find out that it's actually a GIANT MUTANT FISH LURING YOU IN.

I love it. It's a nice and immersive experience. I have not played this as much as I want to probably because I also grew weary of the sea. Maybe because I ventured too far too fast and it got real scary so fast for me lol. I like how simple the gameplay is, and how much content it has. The ocean at night is scary, but the ocean at night with stormy weather? Horrifying. I loved it. I'm just glad that with the DLC I got a spell that allows me to teleport directly to Blackstone, so whenever I was attacked, I just teleported so everything would be okay. I know it probably is not for everyone, but it is certainly for me. You want to just fish all day? You can. You want to go around and help people, doing some adventures on your ship? You can. You want to just sail around and find some weird people asking for certain fish? You can. You want to go treasure hunting? You can. It's up to you, but be careful with the monster of the depths. It's not just a myth.

I absolutely adored this game. It took me a while to get into it, because I was daunted by the open map at the beginning, luckily the structure of the game is such that you work through it area by area.

I liked the Lovecraftian feel of it all, the story is very compelling (and short) and filling up the fishing journal was a lot of fun.

What I liked:
* The overall vibe is fantastically eerie.
* Some enemies are scary
* The story is good, and the endings are satisfying in a Lovecraftian way.
* Find all the fish, and completing the full boat isn't too much of a chore.

What I didn't like:
* The only thing that makes me rate it lower than a perfect 10 is the fact that this game is the same from the start until the finish. It doesn't change things around drastically which Dave the Diver (this year's fishing competitor) did.

The Pale Reach DLC is simply more of the good stuff. The only unfortunate part is that I had so much fun fishing (at the end of Dredge I was pretty OP due to me speed fishing to get all achievements) that I didn't really pay attention to the story. It's a pity it does add the Lovecraft horror vibe, but it doesn't really tie in to the main story. This should've been a free update in my opinion, but I liked the game so much I didn't mind supporting the team a bit more.

TLDR: A hesitant recommendation, as this game represents the first foray of 3-4 devs in a trechcoat rather than an experienced studio.

I can't say that I didn't enjoy aspects of the game - I did 100% it. I will say that it doesn't feel like it stood up to its peers. The art is truly a highlight, with beautiful immersive visions of the land that blend intractable objects seamlessly into the scene. The game play however? Repeating Quick Time Event button mashes repeatedly or navigating a small boat between obstacles. It doesn't feel like fishing or dredging like a fishing simulator or intergalactic fishing. It doesn't feel like a base builder with satisfying growth like cult of the lamb. It doesn't feed the art style with synergistic game play that makes you feel out the locations through how you play like Dave the Diver. Between the lackluster game play and a very rote story, it can make a $25 ($31 with the sixth area tucked in a DLC) price tag. I'd say buy it on sale for sure.

But why finish it? Why not just write it off as a loss? There's enough heart just below the surface that it makes you dream of what could be around the next corner. It has stylistic flourishes of things that don't usually get attention - like a whale devouring one of the tentacles that attacks your boat. It makes it feel thought out, even if the story and game play don't quite match the melody that the world appears to be setting. It starts strong and then just... fades, with it not having enough power to reach the climax (though the ending scenes are enjoyable and well done). I'd look forward far more to what the studio does next rather than dwell on the missteps here. After all, with a studio of four people, this game being the result of their first product launch is a great story, warts and all.

The only thing I wish was different is the day/night cycle being longer.  It really feels like they pass by WAY too fast, creating this sense of urgency that isn't needed.  If the player goes out at night, they understand the risks.

Recommended if you like a more casual play, some Lovecraftian/Cosmic Horror narratives, good music and some exploration.

I enjoyed Dredge and the Pale Reach.  I bought the Blackstone Key DLC as a donation to the DEVs and their work.  I played through several times.  Of course, playing more than once means the joys of discovery is gone after the first play through.  Still I completed all of the quests and caught all of the fish and aberrations, found all of the "treasures".  It's mostly slow paced and can be repetitive at times but it's not at all like the soul-crushing repetition in some MMO games where you grind experience endlessly to obtain many different levels of skills or equipment. 

Is it terrifying ? No.  It's not Friday's at Freddy's, but your heart can race at times when you stay out too long or damage your engine when trying to escape a danger.  

Tastes differ, but for my tastes it suited me.  Also, for players with slower reaction times or those who don't need constant action, flashing lights and noise this is a game to consider. I'm old, REALLY old (70) , so my reaction times aren't great and my creaky Arthritic fingers don't like too much exercise.  This game is one of the few on Steam that interested me and was within my diminishing abilities.

But as time passes the mood slowly becomes more harrowing till it coalesces into an existential nightmare. The game play is incredibly addicting and satisfying, from exploring the unknown seas to fishing and discovering unknown species of fish/eldritch monstrosities. It is by far one of the more unique games I played in 2023 and earns a 4/5 rating.

Bottom line: I'm glad I got this on sale, and got around the rocky learning curve, because it was worth it.
Long version: I'm a very casual gamer and the first ten minutes threw more at me than I wanted to deal with. 
I felt a bit overwhelmed, but, I'd heard so many positive comments that I forced myself to give it a fair shot. 
And I'm glad I did.
The first hour of the game wasn't great (learning-wise), but once I navigated the learning curve and got a feel for the very atmospheric world, I found myself losing track of the time. A lot of time.
There're few game play elements, but there's a surprising variety within those limited elements that keep them fresh. 
The game world's quite easy on the eyes and ear, making the whole journey all the more enjoyable. 

While I've enjoyed the game quite a bit, I do feel the price tag's just a hair on the upper end of what it should be. That said, I'm admittedly cheap and rarely buy games if they're not on sale. 
Had I 
1: not had a gift card 
AND 
2: not found the game on sale, 
I never would have bought it. 
Even though I technically got it for "free" With the gift card, I still feel the cost was a tad steep. Not that the developers don't deserve to be rewarded for all their time and effort and production of a quality product, but, I've been spoiled with getting much more for an equivalent or even lower price. 
Aside from that, my only other gripe is that the menu navigation with a controller is far clunkier than it has any need to be. It seemed bizarre to me that certain norms (like cycling your cursor back to the TOP of the menu if you push down at the BOTTOM of a menu) are non-existent here. And there're a few similar norms that simply aren't present, which is mildly annoying in an otherwise great new gaming experience.

I wasn't sure if I was going to like this or not despite it being very much a game I should like and I dragged my feet on buying it until the winter sale but honestly this is one of my favourite games I've played all year. The tactile feel of the UI and the fishing games and the creepy little world it creates come together to make a really nice little experience. Upgrading your boat becomes really addictive and rewarding. Great game!

A caveat: I don't care for fishing mini games. I don't find them particularly interesting and I don't think every game needs one. Since this is a fishing game, I'll give it a pass. The fishing mini game in this one is fine. I appreciate that I don't lose my catch if I mess up. It's basically the same throughout the game, just with different visuals. Dredging is more interesting, though I'm pretty bad at it, which is fine because you can still pass even if you mess up a lot.

I find this game mind-numbingly tedious. It's a fetch quest game in a vehicle that's kind of a pain to navigate in where the points of contact aren't that close to each other. My real gripe is with the day-night cycle, which is awfully short given that travelling and fishing both take up time. You have to sleep every day or face the consequences of insanity, which takes the form of hostile monsters and birds that steal your fish aka possibly resetting your progress on a fishing fetch quest. I find that I usually can only get one thing done in a day, since I have to travel to the spot where whatever I'm fetching is at, get whatever I need to fetch, then return to one of the sparse ports so I can sleep for a few hours, then leave again.

To make matters worse, the quest screen has frustratingly little detail: you'll be asked to bring back several fish, but my memory is a bit shit and you're supposed to know the fish by the silhouette. The quest menu just says "get the right fish" but doesn't list them. If you want a reminder, you have to go all the way back to the person who gave you the quest, which would be bad enough without the inconvenience of the travel mechanics. I find that I have to keep a guide open while I'm playing, which for something as simple as remembering what's in the quest seems like an oversight.

I love Lovecraftian horror, so I do like the atmosphere and the spooky moments. My favorite thing is fishing for aberrations, which are interesting and fun to look at. Unfortunately, looking at them is the only thing you can do with them, other then sell them for more money than regular fish. 

I'm going to finish the game to see it through, but honestly I'm not too enthusiastic about it. if you're really into fishing mini games or Lovecraftian horror I say go ahead and play it, but it's nothing to write home about.

If this is on sale must have, you won't regret picking this up. There is not much for me to say that hasn't been said or echoed by many other. The DLC's aren't required or cut content, the base game is a story bundled up nice and tight with a bow on top. Also since others don't seem to talk about it much, if you are more of a casual gamer this game feature a passive mode under settings. Hostile creatures and other bad events won't occur, this does remove from the experience but if you're here for story and fishing/dredging then you will appreciate not having to deal with hostile creatures and events.

A nice and sweet fishing game for the whole lovecraftian family. I enjoyed the simplicity of it (and the idea behind it), though I do wish it was longer (took less than 15 hours to 100% complete the game). This game is worth about $15 (given my $1-1 hour of enjoyment ratio). The art style and horror aspect were definitely the highlights of this game (and there is a lot more potential to be explored in a sequel). The fishing aspect of this game was relatively simple (and I do wish there was more challenge and variation). The level design was aesthetically pleasing but relatively simple. The overall difficulty of this game is definitely more casual (which isn't a bad thing), but this game is relatively polished for what it is. In conclusion, this is a great shorter-length game for a discounted price, and I recommend it for any casual players with an interest in horror.

A lone fisherman answers a call for an angler on an island archipelago called the Marrows. Before arriving, you crash your ship just below the lighthouse. Now, you must start anew with a dinky local boat in unfamiliar waters, with no idea what lies below the surface. This game is about fishing, almost exclusively. That concept initially wasn't enough for me, as I am not a huge fan of fishing in games or reality, and the survival-adjacent elements of building up your boat did not sound interesting. I have now 100% completed Dredge in the same weekend I began playing it, and I can truly say it is one of the best games to come out this year.

As mentioned, you start from basically nothing. A painfully slow moving boat takes you just outside the starting village to catch a variety of small, worthless fish. Catching fish requires completing a little timing-based minigame, which change depending on the type of fish and where they are located, which never got old throughout my playtime. Slowly, you'll gain enough money to afford an engine, more fishing rods, and gear to get you away from the first area and then the game opens up significantly. Essentially, Dredge is an open zone fishing simulator, where you fill out your encyclopedia of fish as you try to find bigger and scarier creatures. Developer Black Salt Games is not subtle with its Lovecraftian horror elements. Most types of fish have an "aberration" form, a genetically twisted or strange mutation that is a rare catch for each species. The smallest and the biggest fish have these alternate catches, and one of the joys of the games is just collecting them all and seeing what they have come up with.

The strongest pull of Dredge is in its core loop, which despite its slow start, the game wastes no time getting you invested in. At dawn, you set out to go find pools of fish. You have a limited amount of space in your cargo hold, so you must choose wisely and organize neatly to be able to bring in a sizable profit. Determining which fish to go for and what to let go is a careful balance, and the game does a great job of making every decision and upgrade count, from just a small increase in speed to a little more light at night. Speaking of night, you are able to fish under the moon (there are even species that only come out then), but this is at the cost of your sanity. Stuck in the darkness, you can experience hallucinations, sanity breaks, and even terrifying monsters that will not relent. The panic when night sets in before you've been able to stop at a dock is excellent, and the constant need to find a safe space shows a true understanding of horror game design. There are consequences; anything that attacks your ship can make parts malfunction or some of your catches can fall overboard. I had many instances where my engines failed, so I had to slowly crawl back to a shipyard. Some of these things may get annoying to some players, but it reinforces the harsh environment and even at your most powerful, you are never truly safe. I do wish there was an easier way to fix your boat away from the docks though.

The tone of Dredge is generally morose and oppressive. Whether you are traversing the volcanic shores of Devil's Spine or the narrow ridges of Gale Cliffs, the environment design and the supporting audiovisual elements sustain a feeling of dread and grim stagnation. Talking to people reveals side quests, which mainly request of strange characters asking you to fulfill a lifelong wish or a broken survivor trying to put their lives back together. All of the quests (obviously) require fishing, but I do wish there was some variety in quest objectives. Some form of racing with the boat, or other non-fishing minigame or objective would have gone a long way to make the game feel more dense. As is, the open sea feels like five distinct zones with nothing but ocean in the middle. Those gaps don't really feel shorter even at your max speed either, so I wish there were more fast-travel or in-universe options to hasten the pace towards the endgame.

A Collector approaches you to collect a cursed relic from each of the regions of the sea, guarded by an ancient threat. You can choose to seek them out, but who knows what fate lies on the other side if you do. I was compelled to see this story through, and was pleasantly surprised by the minimal, but interesting narrative elements. Enhanced by the pleasant soundtrack and excellent quality of life features, Dredge quickly throws you into the loop and sets you on an adventure in its dark oceans. It's a perfect length, and finding fish has never felt more fun. I can't wait to see if the devs return to this world on a second dive.
