i think dredge is pretty good, but definitely loses the ability to scare or even surprise you way too quickly. i saw another review talking about this, but once you leave the starting town, you're not really scared anymore. i personally was expecting way more like huge sea creatures and lovecraftian things, but none of that really exists outside of the big sea serpent at the edge of the map and the bad ending. at the start i was going in blind and was excited to see what huge monsters the game had, but again, it doesn't really have any. it just turns into a normal fishing game with a slight threat at night. i wish it was more tense and nerve-racking, and i wish the world felt more connected rather than just a loose collection of islands. don't get me wrong, i still enjoyed the game; i 100% completed it and bought the dlc (which itself was also lacking and underwhelming), but i wish it capitalized on it's potential more. i do like a lot of things about this game, but those are my critiques.

I leave reviews for games SOLELY on accessibility for the Deaf and hard of hearing. Dredge itself is an accessible game, and has setting tweaks to make them more accessible based on what you need. I actually enjoyed how you could miss cues if you were too focused on your fishing or navigating. It was immersive without being frustrating. I'd absolutely recommend this to my fellow D/HOH gamers.

Dredge is a charming horror game. It blends picturesque imagery of a quaint maritime setting during daytime with a disturbing dark sea inhabited with living nightmares during nighttime. The world design makes this game addictive yet relaxing with a gameplay you can either hurry through or take your time and sleep the night away in safe havens. The visuals are amazing in their cartoony simplicity and you're always wondering what new abberations you are gonna pull up from the deep. The music is great and is at times calm and serene and other times distressing and eerie. Overall an amazing game that is just the perfect lenght and while the story is not groundbreaking the gameplay and exploration through fishing really makes this game unique and worth your time.

I'm not a fan of "grind to win" games, even casual ones like Stardew Valley or Graveyard Keeper, where the entire point of the game is to do the same thing over and over and over...

Dredge is the exception! This game makes it fun, and I've been playing it for three days straight, doing nothing but fishing, crabbing, selling, and fishing some more. I got all achievements because I love this game so much, without once going on Passive Mode or feeling even a sliver of boredom from repetitiveness.

I don't know what is it about Dredge that makes it so fun while being so simple, but it warranted giving my first ever review on Steam, and I recommend this game to everyone who likes casual games with a fun twist that keeps you on edge even in later parts of the game.

(TL:DR below) On a serious note, this game was so much fun. Gave me heavy Gravity Falls and LoZ: Phantom Hourglass vibes. Art style is very unique and pleasant (or not so much (in a good way)) to look at. Lots of unique mini-games for different types of resource gathering that consistently kept me 'hooked', as well as an engaging inventory/upgrade management system. Atmosphere is quite eerie and I would have liked a lot more of it. Characters are diverse and interesting. There were some great story beats that gave me goosebumps.

Gameplay-wise, you reach a certain point where some core mechanics no longer apply to you and as a result, you lose that sense of horror that you start the game with. Fortunately the game is long enough where this does not become a major issue. More quests that explored the lore of the world would have been nice. Random events/encounters would have done wonders to the overall experience. There are a handful at the start, but it significantly diminishes after.

Narrative-wise, I wish they went more into the lore and dived into why things are the way they are. Some events happened near the start of the game that was not touched upon later at all? Feels like they wanted to do something but dropped it, which is a major shame because it intrigued me immediately.
The ending was also a little bit lackluster and very sudden. No big finale mission, just a "Go do this real quick and here's your ending."

TL:DR it's a visually pretty and fun game to play with some classic Lovecraftian horror sprinkled in, but not too much is explored beyond that.

This is a good adventure game that offers a lot of exploration, items to find and fun quests that all revolve in boating around to various places. The scenery is 

The biggest complaint I have is around its inventory management. You are forced to return to shore extremely frequently since the inventory fills up so quick, even after size upgrades. If you wait too long the fish will spoil, so you can't stay out very long anyway. In addition, you're forced to play inventory tetris all the time to try to maximize the small amount of cargo space you have, which gets old very quickly. I'd suggest a) make the inventory size upgrades more accessible and b) offer an upgrade that manages the item placement in the inventory automatically.

I thoroughly enjoyed this wee cutesy/Lovecraftian Horror fishing/Tetris, exploration and time management game. Others would say, "it takes a lil' bit of everything from everything and throws a story on the docks" on it - but if it works; it works. I easily obsessed for days, restarting 4 times - then buying the DLC (Review separate).
All in all, what I can say about the game is it had me somewhat scared to dredge at night in the beginning. The music and ambience and strangely the cartoon realism sucked me right in. Then the weird stuff began happening and I noped out of there.

This is truly an amazing game - but don't expect a AAA production that keeps you busy for 300+ hours.
However, if you like to freely explore uniquely designed open worlds, to collect, to upgrade and to get immersed in a wonderfully dark, eerie, but still cozy word - this is the game for you.

It really is a unique experience, part dark gothic adventure, part grinding fishing game (but the fun kind of grinding), part survival / horror game, part exploration game. Dredge is very relaxing, yet deep enough to keep you playing and it also has its suspenseful moments.

To me, this is the perfect quick casual game for everyone who likes games like Subnautica, The Forest, etc. and longs for a less time-consuming and casual, yet engaging experience in a uniquely designed world with amazing game play.

Highly recommended, I absolutely enjoyed this!

Great game in general, lately seeing a lot of criticism of the Pale Reach DLC which I disagree with.

I feel the base game is fairly priced and delivers a good amount of content, especially if you're hunting all the "collectables" (which I recommend). 

The DLC is obviously shorter and does have less content than 1/4 of the base game as the price tag might imply. Sure that may mean it is a slightly lower value for money proposition than the base game, but if you enjoyed it as much as I did I would still recommend picking up the DLC. It delivers exactly what I would hope for from an small expansion - some more of the same excellent game, with familiar yet unique systems to keep things interesting. I finished the DLC (100% completion) in a bit under 3 hours. The core story part in a bit over 2 hours, if that's all you're interested in. For $10 NZD I'm pretty happy with that (beats movie tickets!)

DREDGE is a "fishing" "simulator". You control a boat in an eldritch location where a mysterious fog descends on the seas every night and brings with it the bizarre and the horrific. So yes, very obvious Lovecraft influences. Nevertheless, the game can usually be pretty relaxing, helped by the fact that time only passes when you are moving or fishing/dredging.

Unfortunately, that rule does [b]not[/b] apply to the various abominations that want to attack your boat, which is the main source of frustration in the game. In fact, the second area you will likely visit (if you follow the storyline, which you are free not to) consists of extremely narrow passages between sheer cliffs, barely wide enough for your boat, even brushing against which takes away one of your initially just three hull points (and also potentially disables some of your equipment or tosses some of your catch away), there are falling rocks, sudden water tornadoes... and there's a monster that lives in these narrow passages which WILL try to attack you, be it day or night, forcing you to try to quickly navigate these very dangerous waters.

The actual fishing and dredging is very simple: they're just tiny minigames where you either have to press a single button whenever time comes, or, in the case of dredging, you have to jump your cursor between two lanes to avoid obstacles for some time.

After you fish something out, however, you have to store it on your tiny boat, which also has to house your fishing equipment, your engines, your light sources, and whatever else you have already fished/dredged out, all of which have their own shapes and sizes, so it becomes sort of an inventory management puzzle in a very much non-rectangular inventory.

Other than just fishing and selling your fish, or doing the main quest, you can also explore (though the map is really not as large as it initially appears to be) and find some side-quests to do.

Mechanical progression is a matter of collecting enough materials and money to upgrade your boat and its equipment, while progressing through the main story requires you visiting several different locations, each with its own gimmick, and doing something there.

While it's not really required for anything, the biggest problem with the game is trying to get a specific rare fish, or, worse yet, a specific aberration of a specific rare fish (to 100% the encyclopedia, for example). The fishing spots are hard to, well, spot even with the spyglass (because you have to be pointing precisely at it while it's somewhere in the distance hidden behind the waves, oh, and also you are being rocked by the waves), they aren't infinite (for a lot of fish you'll be lucky if you find a spot that allows you to fish more than one), and the rules on when they "respawn" aren't entirely clear. That's not even getting into net-only or crabpot-only catches, which are entirely random. And getting an aberration is purely chance-based as well (though you can increase your chances somewhat, it's never a guarantee).

Oh, and you can also make the abyssal-horror-lure-phantom-copies-of-your-boat echo back your foghorn precisely, which means you can make them echo back a simple one-note melody, such as "a shave and a haircut", which was my favorite useless feature of the game.

I can't help but feel a little betrayed by DREDGE. It promises a delicious and intriguing adventure, proves to you that it indeed can fulfill this promise - and then it just kinds of... trails off into mediocrity.

Okay, mediocrity is a bit of a strong word. The game still manages to be very engaging, and the way it channels the spirit of Lovecraft's... uh... craft - a nice surprise, considering how often "Lovecraftian" is just a shorthand for tentacled cosmic horrors. But that only strengthens the burning question I'm left with after beating it: [i]what if?[/i]

[h1]Sunrise over [strike]Innsmouth[/strike] the Marrows[/h1]
See, DREDGE has a very strong start. Something's not right. You [i]know[/i] something is going to happen. Fishing? Sure, let's fish, sell the fish, get better gear. Don't pay attention to the black ooze coming from the package you're asked to deliver. And make sure to come back before sundown.

Point is: the mood is there. On top of it, you're given a nice gameplay loop with an extensive upgrade tree. Oh yeah. This is going to be a great ride. Eventually, you begin the main quest in the earnest, and things really get moving.

[h1]A leak in the hull[/h1]
But then you slowly start noticing the flaws. The pacing is not quite right, for example. When upgrading my boat, I often felt constrained in this... artificial way. Almost like I'm just [i]supposed[/i] to do things in a specific way. This one's a bit hard to explain, and maybe it's a me problem; who knows. 

Another artificial feeling comes when you realise how the game world is structured. It feels less like a living, breathing world, and more like, well, a set of video game levels. Everything is too deliberate; too functional. You might say that it's a good thing, keeps things lean. I say it's a tradeoff - one I personally didn't like too much.

[h1]Light up the night[/h1]
And the final complaint is that once you begin the main quest, the dread just stops. Yes, there is the general feeling of 'what the hell am I even working towards' which keeps going until the very end, but that's about it. The areas start feeling sterile. The threats - all manageable with ease. Even the night stops being an issue after a while.

Also, the general design of the areas other than the central one is just... not very eldritch, if that makes any sense? There's nothing ominous about them. Yes, there are major, location-specific threats, but they're rather obvious and have some pretty fool-proof ways of neutralising. Maybe it's my fault for comparing this game in my mind to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/304650/SUNLESS_SEA/?curator_clanid=42922988]Sunless Sea[/url] (can you blame me?), where literally every place filled you with a dread of different flavour (even if the gameplay itself was nowhere near as fun as here).

[h1]Rise from the depths[/h1]
Yeah, the game is fun, in spite of all these flaws. Fishing might be a collection of minigames, but they're varied and short. The inventory management is a pleasure throughout the entire game. And even though I said that the threats are all trivial to manage, it still remains a thrill to do so - mainly because your boat is very susceptible to damage, and every hit can ruin your haul.

And the main mystery, hoo boy. You're being fed pieces of the truth as you go, and let me tell you: I've seen [i]a lot[/i] of mysteries. I hate the extent of my plot prediction abilities. And here? I managed to piece one thing together, but the final twist caught me off guard like a champ. And it's [i]excellently[/i] foreshadowed. 

[h1]Throw me back[/h1]
I guess I just wanted... more. More mystery. More exploring. More upgrades. It's a great game, all things considered; and the combination of fishing and Lovecraft seems like such a natural concept. And yes, in spite of everything I wrote, I recommend this game wholeheartedly - even if, or perhaps especially if you're not very good with horror.

And for those who don't generally play indie titles - thanks for reading. DREDGE is a good game, but trust me, if you decide to, uh, dredge the depths of the Ocean of Steam, there are so many amazing experiences out there to find. For sure, play this one; just perhaps consider throwing your fishing line into the unknown sometime. You'll be very surprised by what you'll find.

Fun little adventure game that involves fishing. What's not to like?

Game is pretty short, with a lot of filler quests that don't really add to the experience. Some are worth doing and get you upgrades to your ship, but even then its mostly flavor. Like, you can get faster at fishing but you don't really need the money after a certain point, and the main narrative is pretty easy to do without fully upgrading.

The game is dripping atmosphere though; very engrossing story hooks (heh) and a modicum of tactical inventory management help to buffer the monotony of playing the same fishing mini-games (I think there're like 5 or 6 max) over and over. Ultimately I think the game would be better served by being more challenging, either more weather effects to fight against or a trickier mini-game here and there would have made upgrading feel more worthwhile.

The fish designs are fucking cool though, and definitely will unnerve you at times you least expect. The flavor is undoubtedly chomped from H.P. Lovecraft. A more fraught and hackneyed inspiration there has never been, but the Devs here really make it something special  by focusing on the fishing angle. 

I recommend this game to those that like Eldritch Horror, Fishing Games, Story Driven Experiences, and Inventory Management.

If you like fishing mini games and Lovecraftian horror, this game is for you.

There is a story, and its okay, but I found the game play to be the most enjoyable part. There's many different fish varieties that you can catch. The fishing mini game vary slightly depending on the area or the type of fish that you are catching. You also have to manage storing the fish you catch on your boat until you reach a port where you can sell them (it's quite similar to resident evil's storage system). It's fun having to figure out the best way to place your different sized fish to fit in as many as possible.

It's a relatively short game; the different endings can be achieved in less than 10 hours, even if you're real casual about it. If you're a hardcore horror fan, this game might not be scary enough for you. I haven't played many horror games, so the horror level was perfect for me. 

Overall, I'd recommend this game!

DREDGE is an amazing, atmospheric good time.

Atmospheric Horror is one of my favorite genres, and this game knocks it out of the park. 

The fishing game mechanics at the core of the game are good, but where this game really succeeds is at creating atmosphere. Each sub-area has its own unique feeling and challenges, the art style is visually distinct and adds to the setting and mood, the music and audio cues let you immerse yourself and add to the discomfort that the eldritch aspects of the game aim to inspire. 

Heavy recommend to anyone who loves eldritch horror and creepy things while also looking for a good, casual game that will give a strange sense of comfort amidst the lovecraftian things that Should Not Exist.

Presentation: 2/2
Graphics are simple and effective. Water effects are beautiful and the caracters' artwork is top notch. Reminded a little bit of Disco Elysium. Sound is superb and the music is atmospheric and tense. This would be a very different review if the sound wasn't as good as it is here.

Length: 1/2
It took me 12 hours to do both endings and to do all side quests. I could play it for longer, do more upgrades, chase after rare fish or treasue. The gameplay loop is that addicting.

Gameplay: 1/2
It takes some time to get used to the boat controls, but you can really feel a sense of progression as your boat gets progressively more equipped. The inventory mangement aspect is done in a very simple and engaging way. Never have I felt frustration while engaging with this system. The fishing / dredging minigames are simple and are a nice distraction. Also they do not overstay their welcome, so things remain fresh.
The save system is amazing. I wish more games like this would adapt to this old-school-esque saving system.
I'm taking one point off due to some early game frustration where something will hit your boat and randomly your only engine will stop and now you're playing sea slug simulator. We could also use more incentive on catching all the fish or pursue rarer loot or legendary fish.

Story: 2/2
I'm impressed. While Dredge's story (probably) won't be worth an HBO series, I was very surprised with the content here. The world is moody and mysterious. Characters are well presented and are fascinating to talk to. I was always excited to see what piece of lore would be dropped next. The game has two endings and it allows you to enjoy both in the same playthrough, which is a welcome quality of life that I wish was more common in today's games.
All in all, it's a nice mystery to be a part of and both the conclusions are satisfying in their own way.

Lasting Impression: 2/2
I'll be recommending Dredge to everyone. At the moment of this writing I beat dredge 1 hour ago, and it's probably one of my all-time favorite games. Let's see how this statement holds itself in the future.

Uniqueness: 1/2
I'm so glad they did not went the roguelike route with this game. It's a boat RPG where crafting is actually meaningful and fun. It's relaxing at times and dreadful at others. It's a game of extremes and they knew fully well how to craft an experience that would take full advantage of this.

Total Score: 9/10
Most fun I've had with a game in a long time!

A short and sweet experience I wish was longer, and that I was a bit smarter to begin to put the pieces together before the ending. Looking back, a few of my issues with the game was that it just felt too vague at times. Now I know there was a story reason for it, but man am I slow. My favorite parts were in the beginning, where I tricked myself into thinking I was playing a normal fishing game, until I fished up an abomination and was rudely reminded. When it settled in though, I really loved searching for aberrations, especially for deep sea fish, to see just how messed up they got.

Dredge taught me to throw that shit back.

As others have said, it's an interesting mix of "relaxing fishing game" and "Lovecraftian eldritch horror". It's an odd mix, but it works. You run around fishing, making money, upgrading your boat, doing fetch errands and solving a big mystery. It's not a long game (I think it took me about 18 hours to finish it). The game does have a definite ending, but it's a confusing ending. I didn't understand it and if the necessary material to understand it is IN the game, I must have missed some critical pieces. I had to do a Google search to figure out what the ending was about. Anyway, it was a fun little game and worth the money. I give it a 7 out of 10.

This game is somewhat difficult to recommend simply because I'm not sure what it offers. At it's core it's got a nice idea, playing as a fisherman in a lovecraft story. However the characters are very thin and the story is somewhat minimal, so you aren't going to get any deep conversations or meaningful themes.
Perhaps gameplay? It's a good game to play in the background, but for a creeping dread horror game that's not a strong endorsement. I thought it was going to be scary in a "Is that just a trick of the light, or did that shadow just move?" kind of way. As your paranoia meter goes up, more spooky things start happening to you, but this already shows a fundamental misunderstanding, Now there's a clear line between I am in danger and I am not in danger. Spoiler: [spoiler]If your paranoia meter isn't flashing red, you're not in danger. Any potential danger outside of this is very easy to spot.[/spoiler]

"But it's an adventure game" There's 5 locations in the base game each with a minor gimmick and a few fetch quests.
I don't understand why this game is overwhelmingly positive. It's alright, it's not a bad game. On a sale I'd even recommend it, but as it stands the game is just kind of mediocre. The game has a lot of potential but squanders it with a lack of character, intellectual meat, or quest variety.

Additional Note for the Devs: [spoiler]If you're going to add an enemy that resembles another boat, have there be other ships that we can mistake it for. As it stands, I can see it from distance and cleanly avoid it.[/spoiler]

I wish there were a "aight" review option because this game does atmosphere really well, but I feel like it doesn't do characters or events much justice. Level design was mostly innocent, but also felt goofy at times just from the nature of the way I explore games.

I'd say, if you want to play a fishing game with great lovecraft atmosphere, then this would be a huge recommend, but I was here for some lovecraftian horror and storytelling that I feel fell short.

I would have really liked some characters to have more dialogue after their pursuits/quests are complete. It really feels like someone asks something of you, you do it and then nothing happens. I don't think this is excused by the whole "Horrors beyond comprehension" trope either as EARLY QUEST SPOILERS: [spoiler] literally nothing happens when the fish market is given an aberration to eat. He just closes for a couple days and then pretends it didn't happen. Similar with the dock worker. Dude apparently just placed an order for a horror beyond his reading level and then stands there for the rest of the game as a pale zombie. [/spoiler]

Maybe the game just isn't exactly for me as I believe the appeal of being a fisherman is meant to be as present a selling point as the eldritch horror. It would hurt the fishing catalogers to suddenly and without waning have important NPCs lose their minds from staring at a rock too long,  but I still feel that a lot of the horror could be expanded on conceptually and fleshed out like the end of the main story pursuit is which was really cool!

The ice DLC is good except for the weird entrance to the iceberg. which felt... idk too artificial?
The key DLC is garbage though. I don't have a problem with supporting devs for making a sick game, but the workshop that the key unlocks is visible for 98% of the game and nothing tells the player that they need a DLC they don't have in order to open it. I don't think I should have the option to inspect the workshop if I don't own the DLC personally.

Well, Dredge is almost a masterpiece, but that's a big compliment.
This is finally a proper fishing game that captures the world, cool mysterious stories, setting out to sail, managing your ship and upgrades, finding secrets and loot. All the while being surrounded with an authentic seafaring atmosphere, music, and beautiful art. Really great stuff and absolutely recommended.

It could have been a masterpiece if there was a bit more substance to it. I liked the fishing mechanics in the beginning despite them being simple. If only they went with more complexity I think it would have kept it interesting - especially for the rare fish.
There should have been something to balance time, as it stands you can just wait for no penalty, then why risk anything - just sleep away or wait till dawn.
And of course, the game doesn't overstay its welcome but also the pattern emerges quickly and it can really only sustain its current length - it needed to be changed up a bit and extended.
I think there's so much potential here for a sequel and hope they go deeper with mechanics, secrets, and upgrades.

Dredge is a great chill game.  It's actually pretty story driven.  The loop is familiar and satisfying, it's more of a treasure hunt game than a fishing game and the mechanics of how you fish and treasure hunt are solid.  It's a comfort food game, it's not hard, it's not especially unpredictable, it's just good clean fun.  The production value and style is great.  The pacing is good, you could bang the game out quite quickly, but getting all the stuff isn't overly exhausting either.  I think i was very close to 100% at a 14 hour play through.

It was disappointing that the initial town did not get expanded on much, I was hoping they would have stayed as recurring characters since i thought they did well with the creepy aspect on that starting region, but no, you treat every region as pretty much its own place and ignore the previous region you were in. The hungry hungry hippo cultists that eat fish felt like the only thing tying regions together since they were all freaking gourmands that wanted some deluxe fish delivery service. 
The DLC is an afterthought, I steamrolled it in maybe 30-45 minutes? It felt really disjointed with the rest of the islands for me since I went there after I beat the game with endgame setup. Probably need to go there when you are in between gale cliffs and stellar basin in terms of progression, but I didn't see anything hinting at that in game. 
Buy it on sale, i wouldn't get it for $25

I am a simple creature. I like collecting things, I like puttering around and exploring, I like fishing games and minigames, and I also really like eldritch horrors beyond mortal comprehension. And Dredge hits all of those buttons for me!

First and foremost: the lack of time-gating. While of course a major aspect of the game is avoiding going out at night, or at least managing your time out there very carefully, I have never felt pressure or stress; this is a big failure of many farm sims and cozy games for me, because I inevitably get stressed out trying to do everything that needs doing before the day needs to roll over. The closest Dredge has to time management is making sure you get your catch back to port before the fish all rot into nothing, and that can take a day or two of ingame time; plenty of time to get to the fishmonger and even if the catch isn't fresh, you still get some coin for your troubles.

(My understanding is at one point a set of sidequests DID have a timegate element, but that has been patched out. To which I say, thank you, Black Salt!)

The mechanics of the game are very easy to pick up, too. I like crunchy mechanics, but I also like simplicity, and balancing cargo space and engines and rods gave me the opportunity to fiddle with fishing strategies without being overwhelming or frustrating. Features like the spyglass to help scout out pools of fish are incredibly helpful, too, and get a ton of use.

Also, this game is beautiful. I enjoy the oppressive atmosphere of the fog, the creeping awareness of the dangers unique to each region of the game, and the unsettling designs of the aberration fish--these are all stunningly well done. But the locations, the ocean itself? Incredible. I am from Lovecraft Country AKA New England and watching my little fishing dinghy rise and fall on the swells and catching sight of a loggerhead turtle in the water or humpback breaching the surface just makes something in me content and happy. There's a lot of love and care put into the visuals and it's very easy to immerse myself.

Also there was this one time in Devil's Spine that I woke up some sort of giant tentacle that was I frantically running away from and then a sperm whale showed up to make that tentacle lunch. That was pretty bitching.

So yeah, do you like fishing? Do you like gorgeous games? Do you like the growing dread of knowing something's in the water and it's not going to let you leave? Play Dredge!

incredibly fun game, fishing mechanics vary and the inventory management appeals greatly to me. Upgrading your ship and being able to physically *feel* the progress you make as the seas you once were afraid of are now your playground is great.
In general it just feels good to play this game. Lots to explore and find.

The quests in the game are however, fetch quests. The entire main story is kind of a mcguffin hunt where each mcguffin can be acquired by finishing up a fetch quest. Not very interesting in the grand scheme of things.

The story itself is serviceable but feels disappointingly short. Right when you get to an interesting twist, some sort of answers, the game is basically done. The ending of the story feels like it just kind of ends too soon, too quick. There is no post-game, you get booted back to just before you trigger the ending when you go back to your save file.

The bones of a story are there and there is things to unravel through the notes you find, but I was hoping for something more- especially between the characters and the player once you learn of certain plot-relevant information.

Very nice game. Very simple but addictive game play  and the story hooks you with the eerie mystery. The Lore was very interesting to experience and it all comes full circle by the ending of the story - I personally prefer the "bad ending" as it was more grand and shocking.

In terms of achievement hunting I highly recommend - the game took me less than 20 hours and the achievements were not frustrating or too easy. Also, the achievement icons are very aesthetically pleasing - I love how they are colour coded and designed. The DLC was OK, I think it could've done with more content and lore personally for the price you pay.

Overall a unique and enjoyable game - I'd give it a 8.5/10.

I don't have a whole lot of free time to put towards games nowadays, so I appreciate shorter games where I can sink a couple hours now and then. The mechanics are simple and engaging. The story is enjoyable with some interesting twists and some  additional lore tucked away to reward exploration. Great atmosphere and soundtrack and it doesn't overstay its welcome. The developers had a clear vision for it and seemed to have pulled it off. Worth picking up, especially on sale.
Excellent game, great balance of relaxation and suspense. This is a no-brainer, get it. Get it now!

I can see why it's good. I didn't return this because I think it's bad, but rather because I have problems with motion sickness in games and this one made me feel a bit ill. The game itself seems good :)

So, all in all, dredge is a great game. It's an extremely fun time for nearly anyone. I highly recommend it.

However, I do think there are some areas where the game could be improved to just get it from a tier to s tier, such as:

- Amping up the horror, i felt once you got used to certain hazards the effect wore off quickly, some more horror just in regular gameplay, variety and consideration into how the horror affects people would be great. The effects of having high panic were also very minimal, with pretty easy to avoid enemies as well as them not spawning half the time so your screen goes red and then pretty much nothing else happening.

- I feel like the story segments were just a little bland, they were pretty short and extremely easy to do, and i think the game should try to be more difficult in general. Adding more length and detail to the story I think would help it feel more like a plot than a series of loosely connected events. (not to mention making lore more easily accessible and digestible)

- Story Spoilers: [spoiler] I don't know, I felt like both endings weren't super great. I'm a bit tired of the trope where someone tries to revive a loved one and ends up ending the world, and the mc dying randomly in the other ending was just strange. I think a better route could be taken than cthulu being like an ultimate big bad, for example giving some nuance to the deep magic and maybe not painting it as totally evil all the time as well as making the deep not a kingdom ruled by cthulu but more just a collection of monsters and various magics that the player could harness either for personal gain or to help people. [/spoiler] 

-[spoiler] I somewhat enjoyed the dlc, but i feel that it was just a little poorly thought out. the story was incredibly short, the area felt just kind of bleak and not interesting, the monster wasn't scary, and through extremely easy means you can get both an item that renders the manifest ability pointless as well as an item that renders the previous best net in the game pointless. [/spoiler]

This game captures everything it sets out to. Ever since I picked it up, I've been in love. Every update and DLC since, I head back out there and do everything new as soon as I can. The only thing I can ever ask for is I wish there could be even more. Dredge is, by far, my favorite game of 2023, and I cant wait for it to get better and better with the continuing support of Black Salt Games.

One of my favorite games of all time. Has a better story than most other games. Has a fun and simple gameplay loop that helps with the horror. Gives off the fear of being unable to do anything else but just survive which lovecraft is known for. Progression system is very rewarding and leaves you wanting to get the next upgrade. The game is simply just one of the best at everything it try's to do. Story, horror, fishing, exploration, lovecraft, everything. There's no better evidence than this game single handedly bringing lovecraftian horror back into the limelight if even just for a month or two.
Pretty fun.

Dredge is the representation of love poured into a game.
All the attention to the most minute details, the gameplay loop, the progression system and the hidden mysteries of the story make this the most fun game of 2023 and Black Salt Games deserve the highest praise for releasing a game with such high quality and their constant interaction with the lovely Dredge community.

It is a neat small game and I would definitely recommend it, but it is not without flaws of course. I felt the pacing was very weird, the game very quickly becomes easy and there are very few side quests that are not just "get me this fish", and those that are there are done quickly. The world felt very small and arbitrary, and there is very little to do. 

All of this said however, I would still recommend it as a short game (much shorter than I expected), because it has great atmosphere and despite simplistic textures, they manage to convey the feel of Lovecraftian horror well, and though it quickly became pointless, the fishing was quite fun and there were varied methods of catching, so it didn't become monotonous. 

I know people don't like grinding, but I feel Dredge could have benefited from some higher hurdles to progress to extend the time spent in each area. I wanted to be in the areas longer and soak in the atmosphere but there was quickly nothing left to do so I just had to move on. 
While there is certainly merit to letting the players find things out on their own, I still feel you give them tools to do so, especially when you don't really have to revisit places. (I have too many points so I'll stop here)

Overall Dredge felt like a great game that didn't have the time/funds to become fully fleshed out and refined, but it was a fun Lovecraftian experience while it lasted.

This was a fun can easy going game full of fun Lovecraftian monsters and surprises.  It was a lot of fun unraveling mysteries or just fishing for new species.  The art is well done and the music track is great. I enjoyed this game more than most I've played recently.

Eh. The game isn't bad, but it also just feels like lots of grind for nothing. Every time I upgraded the hull of the ship, I expected a better layout, but instead it always got worse. I also expected the story to be more interesting, but it was fairly simple. The fishing minigames were interesting until they were repeated heavily across the different fish. If every fish had it's own minigame, it would have been far more interesting and added another reason to try and find all the different fish. It was easier to just upgrade my ship and research the higher tier parts than it was to buy the lower tier parts before getting the next tier and having to replace it. Essentially, the parts would get replaced so quickly, it wasn't worth buying the lower tier parts. The "economy" of upgrades was not quite right.

Art and music was good.

This game brings me simple joy in the way few other games have done.
The kind of joy I first felt when I got into flash video-games as a silly, young child. 
The kind of joy where you don't bother with mechanics or stress over anything, you just play something and the game fits like a glove, comfy and fun.

-The art is cute.

-The atmosphere is on-point.

-The scary is... scary.

-If you screw up it's not too punishing, you will at most lose a replaceable item or two overboard, it's the perfect amount of ''i don't wanna bash my boat against that rock, but if i do i won't feel frustrated''

-The game saves every time you rest the night at a dock which is very often (I think? i got to day 60~ and died only once)

-The mini-games are enjoyable, varied, responsive, etc.

-The different stuff you can catch is actually somewhat interesting, and it's quite nice to be invested into finding specific fish to better tetris your cargo hold.

-The fish that are horrors-beyond-imagination mutations are interesting to look at and read the descriptions.

-The game-play loop is satisfying, 

-The game doesn't hold your hand per se. you can always go off fishing and upgrading your boat and pursue the main missions later (which is what i did because i just enjoyed the fishing) but you always have them there, to pursue at your leisure.

-I just really enjoy playing tetris with fish, apparently.

-When you use the fog-horn into the night, the horrors beyond my imagination respond with the same sound pattern, which is way funnier than it should be.

The gameplay loop is very enjoyable. It's a fairly short game, about 25 hours, maybe up to 30/35 for completion. The gameplay in general is well polished and feels good to play, but there are some glaring and head-scratching issues when it comes to many of the upgrades in the game: there's often no reason to use some of the "best" upgrades because there's limited space to implement them, and multiple lower tier upgrades can do it all, and better. Also, both of the endings are completely unsatisfying. But if you can get past both of those issues, then the game is pretty fantastic. Recommended in spite of those two issues.

I loved every aspect of this game, at first I wasn't sure what to think of it.
But as the story unfolded I was invested right away.

A unique, good game. I don't think it deserves overwhelming praises, but it simply is a good game, not without flaws.

The only, but very major complaint I have: It is so short! Yes, you can keep grinding all the fishes you desire, but that really wasn't the point of the game for me - the simple minigames become pointless at certain point and I am no slave to achievements, just for the sake of completing a checklist. And I also have to say that after initial first few hours, the game loses the main charm. It's still a good game, but first few hours were the peak.

I was expecting more narrative based gameplay, but that gradually goes away, as you keep going further - don't expect Sunless Sea. The storytelling is decent, but it holds up only for the first half of the game, then it's more about just going by the checklists and exploring rather mechanically the remaining places.

I would love to see this concept, but further expanded, with even more in-depth gameplay, rather than few repeated minigames, which are fine, but get inevitably boring, and mostly, with much more narrative focused sandbox gameplay. However, I am still quite satisfied with what I've played - not a game of the year, but a good product. By the way, how perfect is that? I've finished the game on day 100.
Truth be told, I played this more for the fish than for Lovecraft, and had a consistently delightful time.

First spotted it on a wishlist of someone else, and got it for myself not even 2 days later.

Pro: 
> Atmosphere and storytelling. This is not a jumpscare-feast, focussing more on creating an unsettling environment in which one is so, so relieved to spot another person. Main and Side quests lead one to explore the map, and forcing to navigate through the darkness and/or new challenges imposed by the different areas. The game knows how to inflict thalassophobia.
> Artstyle. It just looks amazing and rough, with the simplicity of the character designs emitting exactly what their dialogue and task would make one assume they'd look like. 
> Exploration. The areas and their respective fish just make sense, and one has to carefully consider what type of gear to take on bord as space is limited. I spend quite the time just driving around gawking at islands being a little sad I could not hop off the boat, and even more time chasing sunrises and sunsets on open sea.
> Immersion. I forgot everything around myself for a while, finding out the story's startoff and working on the first improvements to the boat. Time passing as one fishes keeps one on edge, seeing how there is more than just us on the seas - and they know where we are.
> The main story ending. After getting used to the horror a little not spooked by all anymore, the ending sequence was ... intense, to say the least. 
> Feeding doggo, petting doggo.

Cons:  
> Achievement hunting. One needs the DLCs to go for perfection, and chasing all fishies after finishing the main story is a little drag. 
> Money and Endgame. Even before finishing the story, at some point the passive income by nets and such, and just emptying one's cargo in between aberration hunting, leads to 20k+ of money one never needs anymore after finishing all additions to the boat and buying all gear. That may be something someone not actively achievement-hunting may not be affected by because the main storyline itself and the possible upgrades match quite well.
> Duration. The game was too short for how amazingly good it is. I was so happy about the Pale Reach DLC because it meant I could go explore and hunt again, after the story had been over. 

Altogether, all the things that I put as a con are self-inflicted and my fault alone. Dredge is a quiet masterpiece, pensive and haunting, and I still am sad I played through it already. 
9/10 - would erase my memories just to play it again for the first time and discovering all its mindfucks and monsters once more.

Lightning in a bottle.
A lot of indie developers these days get lightning and then fail to capture it.
Sure, this game isn't especially large or long, but the fact that the developers kept some realistic bounds to the game really allowed them to put the detail and shine into everything that needed it. Better to start strong and small and win than try something too big and fail.

When I picked the game up I didn't really look into it, I just saw some clips and thought "cool, fishing game" and bought it. Imagine my surprise when I fished up the All Seeing Cod.
Even though it puts a spin on the fishing game genre with horror, it hits both notes high. It's a very relaxing fishing game sometimes, and then a tense horror game a few minutes later. This game knows what it wants to be and then does it.
I hope the team keeps doing more with this. Not getting a bigger sequel would be an awful reality to have to face

I cannot recommend this game enough. 

The best description I can give is that it gives an intense feeling of nostalgia of the singleplayer gaming experience from growing up gaming. Truly entertaining story, and I found myself not skipping through dialogue and really immersing myself into it. It wasn't overwritten and it didn't feel like it was padding for time, as a lot of singleplayer games feel to me nowadays.

Also, I'm not really into horror or mystery type games, but this game does a really good job with the horror and mystery. It's not resident evil with 2 jumpscares a minute, and it's mysterious enough where you have to really evaluate the environment and figure it out for yourself. 

If you're planning on going into it, please go in cold. Don't watch videos or tutorials or anything. It's an awesome experience if you immerse yourself.

The game is good, but lower your expectations. A lot. It is not nearly good enough to deserve the 98% Overwhelmingly positive rating it has. It is a decent 7/10 game, it has pretty graphics, nice music, great art style. But it lacks a solid gameplay core. 

[h2] FISHING [/h2]
Yeah, there is fishing in it, as advertised, but it is very [spoiler] pun ahead [/spoiler] depthless. Sure, you can catch fish. Sure, there are a lot of different kinds of fish, all of them have different [spoiler] corrupted [/spoiler] versions that are VERY well made, interesting and diverse. But... A good fishing game is ought to have something more than fancy looking fish, don't you all think? So, when it comes to actual fishing GAMEPLAY, this game really shows it's flaws. All this game can offer in terms of fishing mechanics is some simple reaction minigame that changes very slightly with different types of fish. There are no baits or different fishing techniques (e.g spin fishing, casting, etc.), so you do the same thing over and over, no matter what kind of fish you are trying to catch (There are crab traps, but I don't think they are worth mentioning). You basically treat all fish spots like you would treat ore deposits in some MMORPG game. You just see one, come to it, gather it and pass on. I wish there was more things about fishing in this game, like fish reacting to different weather or time of day, but unfortunately, in this state the game is not that good when it comes to actual fishing. 

[h2] ENEMIES AND HAZARDS [/h2] 
I wish I could say that this game is better at being a horror game than it is at fishing, but sadly it is not. Nothing really stops you from going out to catch some fish even in the middle of the night, because all threats in this game are easily manageable, avoidable and hardly scary. Imagine a lone, puny fishing boat, traversing an endless sea of fog, its dim lantern casting feeble light, barely sufficient to see anything at all, while an eldritch horror lurks just beneath... Now forget it, because you will not feel any "dread" or thalassophobia, there are only 3 types of hazards in this game that you will constantly encounter, and none of them are even remotely scary. And to make things even worse, somewhere closer to the 40% of the game your ship will turn into a Formula 1 racing motorboat that is capable of moving at a stable speed of 150 KM/H (or 80 knots, if you are a maritime transport nerd), so even if you somehow find yourself surrounded by hazards and monsters, you can just easily run away. 

[h2] LORE AND CHARACTERS [/h2] 
Slight spoilers ahead.
The game welcomes you by a nice small questline that really hooks you and creates an amazing feeling of suspense, but like all other things in this game, it quickly loses it's charm, and after a few hours in game you realize that you barely get any new lore, and instead of a lovecraftian horror adventure you are doing simple chores given by random people. There is only 1 main questline, with a choice at the very end of the game that changes the ending. Most of the characters in the game have some dialogues available from the start of the game, but once you've read them all you can basically forget about those characters, they will not get any new dialogue options based on your progress in the game or the quests you've completed, For example, let's look at the mayor. At first he looks like a stereotypical fat greedy mayor, he gives you some basic instructions, and then gives you a *suspicious* box to deliver. For the first 30 minutes of the game he feels alive, he feels like a character that reacts to your actions and the world itself, but once you've completed the tutorial questline, he just becomes a cardboard cutout man that just stands there and does NOTHING. Even when you've almost completed the game and completed around 10 different sidequests, he will have the same dialogue options he had when you just finished his beginning quests. And it's the same with EVERY SINGLE character in this game except 2 characters that are basically main quest characters. And even those 2 don't have enough lore dialogues for my liking. My other complaint about this game's worldbuilding is that it does not react to your actions. Why do we need 200 different types of corrupted fish when traders don't even react to that? There is only 1 quest at the beginning of the game where you have to bring some corrupted fish to the trader at the home city, but after it, corrupted fish and regular fish become basically the same. Imagine how fantastically cool it could be if the city and NPCs actually changed if you sell too much corrupted fish to them? Like mayor becoming more and more suspicious and fish-like, city houses becoming visually more neglected and desolate, etc. Also, there are some creepy hooded creatures scattered across the map who demand you to sacrifice different fish to them, and as a reward you get.... Skill books that improve your stats by a few percents. Great.

[h2] CONCLUSION [/h2] 
In conclusion we have a game that is not a great fishing simulator, and also not a great lovecraftian adventure game. It lies somewhere in between, so neither of those two aspects of the game is good enough to outweight the flaws of the other. It is a nice game to get on a 50% discount, but as I said at the very beginning - lower your expectations.
UPD: At least this game is not purchasable in russia, big thanks to the developers and publishers. Russia should be isolated and deserted, just like a savage caveman country it is.
Fishing is fun, but trying to piece together the aspects of the Lovecraftian horror is even better.

throw it back
no but this is such an amazing game (the 300h is not playtime i left my computer open with the game playing for AWHILE) i'm on my 4th(?) play through trying to find the last ending, its a bit expensive but id say its worth it. Terror begins to stop after the 1st and second play through, you can get through the game in under 4-5h with getting lost and confused constantly ( i skipped too much dialog)  after that playthroughs are rather quick. 
recommend the game if you like being chased around by fucking horrifying birds that STOLE ALL MY EELS GIVE THOSE BACK THAT WAS SO MUCH MONEY. i recommend trying to find all the books they help get the momentum you need early game

This is a cool game. It ramps up kind of quick with the upgrades. I like the open ocean and the undulating waves, the panic meter and the Lovecraftian nightmares that await me! Hint: if one wants money to purchase upgrades/fishing rods/nets etc... quickly, use crab pots. These will be the money maker!!!

Dredge is a good example of how a short game can still be a good experience. The atmosphere of the game is superb with its Eldritch horrors lurking below the surface. Combined with a sleepy-town artstyle and horrific aberrant fish monstrosities you find along your chill fishing adventure. I just loved each one of those creepy buggers that I had to find them all. All this while following the story of a lone fisherman that is haunted by his past. 

The game isn't complex and nor does it go into pretentious overthinking of its themes. It is what it is, a little loveletter to classic Lovecraft and his sleepy hamlets coated in nightmare fuel. This game is also a great grab if you like to get comfy with your Steam Deck and enjoy a bit of horror while snuggled up in bed. This came in so handy with me being sick for like ever it seems. 

Sometimes its nice to appreciate and enjoy the simpler side of indie games. Could it be more in depth with systems? Survival mechanics? A bit more balance to economy? Sure... but does it really need it to still be what it is? No. We have so many games that go overboard with those kinds of systems that having something like this is a treat.
Fishing is fun you should try it out :)
beautiful and very enjoyable, ended up wanting a bigger map

I recommend this game, its fun, its cool, very atmospheric, however, it sorely leaves me lacking. It has great ideas and it just doesnt do enough with them. Go further, make the game harder, do something with said great ideas!
The game is full of cool mechanics and other things that dont go anywhere.
[u]This game is essentially euro truck simulator at sea.[/u]
I wouldnt mind the 9 hour length if it offered more, but for 25‚Ç¨, or 18‚Ç¨ in my case, its just not enough. Im not asking for more content, im asking for the content that's already there to have a gradient, a curve to it, im asking for things to escalate as the game goes on. 
It bums me because it could have been so much more! Its set up to be what it isnt! This is like grinding in an MMO, just with great atmosphere.
[u]This is essentially a game jam prototype polished to appear as a full game.
Take this as a hesitant recommendation, reasons why below[/u]

The mechanics work well together and they are fun, but they dont change over the course of the game. The fishing minigame for example never gets harder. Reeling in a shark, or a mutant shark even, is just as hard as reeling in an ordinary small fry.
Picking up a piece of wood from the surface is just as easy as dragging jewelry from a sunken wreck from way deep.
There are mimic crabs that disguise themselves as sunken boats and whatnot, but they dont move, they dont entice you to get closer, they just sit there, and when you come close they try to strike and you have a lot of time to just get away. Thats it. A great idea, that doesnt actually do anything. 


The scary monsters and other things are really easy to avoid and pose no threat. You cant maintain the great vibes if you dont back them up. For me to fear the dark, there actually has to be something to fear in it. The game has a very strong and foreboding atmosphere and when you try your luck, you arent put into a dangerous spot. Sure there are hostile creatures but just like the mimic crab they are not dangerous. At all. Its hard to take the excellent vibes seriously when there's nothing backing them up.

Same goes for the story.
There's a dockworker who receives a [spoiler]mysterious dripping package[/spoiler], you give it to them, and then [spoiler]they turn into a fishy zombie[/spoiler]. They dont talk, no other NPC mentions it ever, and since they werent an NPC with a purpose like a shopkeeper or something, they just sit there for the rest of the game, with no follow-up to an interesting plot setup. It ends abruptly. 

When the fishmonger asks for a mutant fish, [spoiler]to see what would happen if someone ate it, he closes up shop, disappears for two days so no shop, then comes back, looks the same, mutters something about you not being there yesterday (because he didnt open the shop)[/spoiler], and then everything goes back to normal. No consequence actually happens after this, no follow-up, nothing.

Very early on its emphasized that installing things on your boat takes time and you should schedule it properly, but why? There is absolutely no urgency in this game and when i dock the boat i can wait for days at my will. Why should i care that installing my new fishing rod is going to take 6 hours? I have all the time in the world. This is what i mean with this game. It has excellent ideas that it doesnt follow-up on!

The NPC's also talk about how the mayor of the other island went insane, and disappeared, [spoiler]and you can later find him, and he babbles about things, and then he disappears[/spoiler]. You cant talk to the other NPC's about this, you cant tell the other mayor that this mayor what happened, nothing. 

On one of the island clusters, there's a cultist, [spoiler]who literally burns himself alive[/spoiler], and nothing happens. He had the item with him you needed, you got it now, cool, thats it. No follow-up. No consequence, no lasting effect.

The NPC's also mention the photographer a bunch, and how she disappeared, and she might be in danger, and i should look for her, and when i find her, she's just there. Not scared, not in danger, just taking pictures of things, tells me to get a thing for her, i give it to her, get a reward, and the entire ""chain"" ends there. I cant report back to the townsfolk that she's alright, she's not in danger, nothing actually happens in this game. 'Please get a thing for me. Oh, you got the thing? Cool, here's some reward, now go away.'

There is an island cluster with [spoiler]a giant kraken in its middle. [/spoiler]The entire story goes as follows:
You show up, [spoiler]the giant nightmare kraken is there already and destroyed the research lab[/spoiler], scientist lady tells you to get a thing, she gives you a gadget that [spoiler]temporarily scares away the kraken[/spoiler], you get the relic you came here for, you leave. [spoiler]The kraken is still there, its still a massive danger to everything[/spoiler], and apparently thats fine and we are not going to do anything about it, since we got what we came for.

The ending is doing the same mistake aswell. When you get the fifth relic, you get to make the only decision in this game, which is choose the ending. In the bad ending, [spoiler]you perform literal necromancy, AND raise an elder GOD, and aside from showing the main city of the game as a burning ruin[/spoiler], nothing actually happens, roll credits. [spoiler]The revived person has no dialogue with you[/spoiler], the entire cutscene is only like 15 seconds long, and its a great setup for things and it just doesnt go anywhere. Again, a great idea, they didnt do anything with. Really? [spoiler]You resurrect her and she doesnt say anything, be a mutant, get mad at you or anything. [/spoiler]Hell, the entire ending is: 'NPC tells you to go to a place, you go to a place, 15 second cutscene plays, roll credits, you're back to main menu, and loading the save puts you before you started the ending'. This applies to both good and bad endings. This is exactly how both cutscenes work. You go to the same place, same cutscene length, same letdown. 


I guess i just feel bummed because this feels like i was lied to. And because i overpaid. This is a 10‚Ç¨ game where you grind for 9 hours while listening to youtube. Thats the entire game. Its not really a game, more like a pretty and very atmospheric chain of grinding. I feel like i wasted my money with this game. I could have bought other games from this and would have gotten an actual game from it.

Obviously waited until the word was out on this one. Had never heard of it until What Culture Gaming started talking about it. So I picked it up on sale and not upset with my decision at all. Would have paid full price for it. Super simple, yet addictive gameplay, with an intriguing and dark story. Fishing was fun, my toddler loved watching and clicking with me. I will say some of the puzzles were a little out there, but great overall. Would have liked to see more out of the pale reach DLC, 5 or 6$ for another hour or so of game is....acceptable I suppose, I can't complain. I didn't get it, but the blackstone key dlc upsets me for some reason.... 3$ for a couple pieces of equipment... I was trying to figure out how to get into that damn workshop... and to find out its behind a paywall really irked me. However overall, loved the game 2 thumbs up!

There's no getting around the game being short, but it is a very well crafted package that has a satisfying gameplay loop and an interesting world to explore with plenty of mysteries to uncover.  The game never gets super hard, almost making this feel like a cozy casual c'thulu fishing simulator.  That's not a bad thing.

I'm giving it a thumbs up because I enjoyed the game enough to see it all the way through.  Still, I don't really see myself coming back to this one now that I'm done.  And that's okay -- not every game has to be some endless content driven experience.

This game is the ultimate chill vibe. The soundtrack is one of the best and most beautiful I have ever heard, I hooked up my PC to my home stereo to feel the experience. Gameplay is great, story is interesting, and I personally like the ability to switch between normal and passive game modes at will. Sometimes you like a challange, but sometimes I just want to play... and Dredge ticks all the boxes.
this was great

Its got a simple but fun game play loop but it does border on tedium at times, especially when you're going for 100%.

Adored the Lovecraftian element and were genuine moments of terror when i was relatively new to the game and wasn't aware of the random events that occur during night time.

Art style was charming and the soundtrack was very soothing and fit right in with the immersion of the game.

My only issues were Inventory space and the progress to getting the better gear felt a bit sluggish. I completed the game with half of the equipment still locked and the ending felt a little bit anti-climactic but is totally understandable from a lovecraftian angle. 

also i wasn't big fan of the little fish at Devil's spine, they weren't scary or much of a threat as much as they were just super annoying. I know you can get rid of them by burning them with the hot water from the underwater volcano thingy's but they'd just make a b-line for wherever there spawn point was which was often where i needed to go. They were also really badly placed, it felt like no matter what direction you took you were going to encounter them at the same time trying narrowly avoid walls and the mother was just a really unpleasant experience.

Easily fixed by removing some of the more clustered spawn points and perhaps setting a cooldown for when the little piranha things appear back at their spawn.

I feel what could have made this game a lot better is having a sort of corruption system. For instance one of the early sidequests is the fish merchant you sell fish to asking you to get a corrupted fish and when you get him the fish he shuts himself away for a day, comes back and groans about a headache and its NEVER touched upon again. I feel like it was a missed opportunity to keep bringing him more screwed up fish and watch him get more and more horribly disfigured due to him consuming all the fish, just didn't seem to go anywhere which is a little disappointing.

Overall though, still very much enjoyed the game and definitely getting the DLC solid 8/10

Yes. But...

The game plays well, I encountered no bugs, soundtrack is nice, its really aesthetically appealing and has a little interesting story. So... whats the catch?

Dredge is short (between 12 and 15 hours short), its easy and doesnt provide much of a challenge, most of the "upgrades" arent really needed or get any use and has no replayability value. But, again, a longer game might have felt repetitive whilst the relaxed gameplay doesnt really need a complex upgrade system. 

The game is just short enough to keep you busy and entertained until the end is nigh so, I dont know if any change in this balance would have payed up.

Come for the dread Lovecraftian/Cthulhu Mythos vibes, hang out for the boating-exploring-fishing-selling-upgrading loop. Exit with existential angst that the story is short.

I think I'll check out The Lighthouse movie with Willem Defoe and Rob Pattinson and replay Sunless Sea.

Dredge is a very good game, I have always been a fan of eldritch nonsense, and this game does it so well. It's a nice slow burn of "huh, that's not right" folding over itself time and time again. But unfortunately it doesn't really go anywhere with that story-wise, it's just kind of a funky fish collecting game. But I still highly recommend it, as it is fun from start to finish.

Fun game, but not worth the price relative to what others cost. 

The main story can be completed in a single weekend sitting (8-10 hours). The concept, art, and gameplay are fun, but there is little real depth to the grinding.

I picked this up because they did a collaboration with Dave the Diver. If you want a game that is fairly fun to grind and has a cute story, that is more your style. I really wish the collaboration went both ways, so that we could open a temporary restaurant in this game. Would've added a bit more to do.
fun fish bad monster

I may not be the biggest fan of the game from a few angles, but it's interesting and fresh enough to give it a thumbs up. I was able to do everything I cared about in 10 hours, which seems fine for the quality of the product. It has a fantastic art style, great sounds of the sea and OST, has interesting approaches to gameplay, upgrading is fun and doesn't overstay its welcome, and it's rather generous when it comes to some elements like getting abberant species of fish.

On the other hand: it's not the smoothest to play, sometimes being hit once is way too unforgiving, and you can't expect me to remember what the shadows of 9 fish look like without opening up a guide. I don't know if its in the code or if I'm just incredibly unlucky, but 90% of all first damages received were always assigned to my main engine... disabling it. Losing nearly all of your speed really does make you want to step away from the title.

It's a great little indie title. Pick it up if you want a unique experience of operating a little boat on the eldritch horror seas.

This is such a satisfying little gem. It's nothing groundbreaking, but the fundamentals here are very solid. Fish, get money to buy better gear for better fish. That's good plain fun. But then you add eldritch horror to the mix, vibing fully with the unknown depths, and you get a delicious whole.

Great game.

Dredge is a game that wants to use all of the imagery and ideas of a lovecraft setting without committing to the themes of a lovecraft setting. The mutant fish caused by the ancient evil of the land are just a price modifier, the magic spells that man wasn't meant to know just quick travel and other speed up functions and the monsters borne out of your fears and insanity have all of the impact of a asshole on the freeway cutting you off in traffic. Even the stereotypical lovecraft characters you meet of a scientist or castaway are just there, no interesting descent into madness or fear at finding out the truth of the world.

This games premise is excellent, the fishing is good enough for what it is, but if you wanted a lovecraft horror story like I did you will not find it

Purchased on December 7th. Finished on December 11th. 5 out of 5. This game caught me completely off guard. Great story, open world, beautiful graphics, unique game mechanics, multiple side quests, dark humor, replayability and dual endings. H.P. Lovecraft, eat your heart out. Worth every penny for base game and dlc. Black Salt games and Team 17 created a masterpiece. I look forward to more games like this in the future.

It's not the longest game, yet so many things about it just feel right. The good thing is, this is a game where I think you'd quickly be able to tell if it is for you. Core gameplay:
- Revolves around 5 major island environments
- Find/catch fish to make money to upgrade ship+buy stuff to catch better/more fish
- Side quests
- Dredge up scavenge to upgrade ship
- Manage sanity in spooky atmosphere
- Solve puzzles revolving around fish you find
- Chase after macguffin in each of the major areas
- Fin

+/- 9 hours to beat
Absolutely delightful. Totally engrossing atmosphere in the style of thatgamecompany.
One of my favorite games. An absolute must play

Dredge is one of my favorite games ever. Not only is it easy to just get lost in the amazing fishing and dredging of the game, then upgrading and doing it again. On top of the fishing, the storage brings extreme pleasure to my internal Tetris player. The story is creative and although it is a bit small right now, there are plenty of other quests to keep you busy while the game is expanded. All of these factors add up to a game that, for me, doesn't have a single obnoxious or boring feature. I'd recommend this to anyone who is interested in lovecraftian horror stories of any kind, and who wants a creative adventure. However, it isn't nearly as scary as the average horror game, so don't buy it if you only want horror.
This game was amazing it had great twists and was a blast to play.
fish

Absolutely phenomenal game. The gameplay is a mix of relaxing fishing game and "HOLY SHIT HOLY FUCK HOLY SHIT WHAT IS THAT I'M GONNA DIE". The two portions of the game blend seamlessly together, and discovering the different locales and characters was a blast. Seeing events that correspond to the day and night cycle, and differeent side quests that, to me at least, never seemed too repetitive. One complaint I have is that some fish are INCREDIBLY difficult to find. I've got 16 hours on this game, finished it, and have collected every abberant fish there is, but I cannot for the life of me find the moonfish variants. But even with that, I find the gameplay fun and interesting, the atmosphere amazing (especially if you like H. P. Lovecraft's works), and the story immersive. Highly recommend.
Amazing game, graphics and story, would absolutely buy again

What a great game this could have been... It starts very promising and along with the overwhelmingly positive reviews you expect a really good experience. And then comes the gradual fall. 
There's a main npc that has his objective whom you help. The why is only revealed at the last minute of the game at the end. While the ending idea is good, it is done so boringly and in an underwhelming way that it completely fails to deliver. The rest of npcs give you some simple fetch quests which are almost unrelated to main story. You find the same boring npc merchant in every single island who -what a surprise- has also one fetch quest for you.
The only appealing thing a few hours in the game remain the night horrors which are not really horrors if you have unlocked 1-2 abilities early on. So you can just be out all night without a single fear. Another appealing aspect can be the collection of all fish to fill the stickerbook.
Buy only in very heavy discount for the early gameplay, otherwise avoid. If you enjoy fishing and good storytelling go play "Spiritfarer".

I am very happy I picked this up.  Dredge is an atmospheric and beautifully done game with a simple concept well executed.

You go fishing and upgrade your ship while encountering various eldritch horrors, especially if you get greedy and take risks.

This allows the player to sort of scale the difficulty to their preference in addition to the settings themselves.  I took a lot of risks, and still found it pretty easy.

I wouldn't describe it as especially scary, though it does have moments, particularly if something catches you by surprise.  The one time I remember dying, it was because I was being greedy and overconfident early on and crashed into a rock while being chased.

Once you start stacking on the upgrades though, most threats become an inconvenience.  All in all, it does add up to a bit of a mismatch of themes.  The player feels powerful, the NPCs are mostly friendly and helpful, and the horror element feels a little blunted rather than something overwhelming waiting for you to make a little mistake or just be unlucky, as would perhaps fit better with a game in this genre.   Despite the theme, in many ways it is closer to Stardew Valley than it is to Darkest Dungeon.

That aside though, it is an addictive, fun game which is absolutely worth the asking price.  I started a second run right after finishing my first just to re-experience the early game after I knew what I was doing.

What they really need is another expansion to add some more threatening monsters to the game.

Pretty great game to get on sale. It has charm and is aesthetically pleasing. Your little boat bobbing in the water as you sail across the map is extremely relaxing and peaceful... during the day. 

Gameplay mechanics are extremely simplistic. The story is interesting and pushes you to find out more.

Overall 7.5/10

I don't think I spent more than an hour away from the game, so almost all 15 hours I've played, were spent in the game. I did not sleep between starting and finishing the game. This was the most memorable 15 hours I've had in quite some time, and from such a small game. Well worth the price. Lovely art, adorable voice blips, and so much fishing.

---{ 9 / 10 }---

Final Notes: 
Obviously Lovecraftian at heart, but it has more to offer than just being a love letter to the Cthulhu mythos. Charmingly simple, intriguingly mysterious atmosphere, and just a downright fresh experience. It's one of those rare games that made me feel like I'm finding video games again for the first time, and not just playing "the newest installment of the same game I played the last however many years but slightly worse" that so many franchises and genres suffer from these days. Which I haven't experienced since playing Inscryption some time back (review to come soon). I loved every moment of Dredge, and I can't wait to see if we one day get a Dredge 2 to expand on the game-play and world offered in the first installment.

Review based on game-play prior to update 3.0, and The Pale Reach, and subject to change when re-visited.

If you enjoy Lovecraftian fiction or eldritch horror then you'll probably love this game. 

If not then this is simply a treasure hunt with occasional mutant fish, giant sea monsters, and a thin story draped over the top.

The "game"parts are all very well executed with good guidance, pacing, and progression but I spent the whole game waiting for the story to get exciting. It started off intriguing only to steadily disappoint me until the ending that was a complete anticlimax as I realised that was it.

It's ironic that a game about dredging up mysteries from the deep has such a shallow plot.

I enjoyed my play-through, but it is easy to skate by and miss a good chunk of content if you don't take risks at night like I did. The only negative thing about the game is how short the main storyline is, though it maintained my enjoyment to a point where I might get the DLC storyline and max out my boat :D.

Dredge is easily one of my favorite games of the year, and there have been a lot of good ones. I love the tone, mood, and eerie mysterious feeling. My favorite part is cruising around the beautiful environments engrossed in their ambiance. I love when there is weather and storms and wish they would add even more of these environmental aspects, the thunder sounds wonderful.; maybe weather could even impose danger and hazards to you. I know this is a brand new game but I'd be so excited for a sequel.
This game redefines the fishing-horror genre.

I had no idea what to expect, but this game is really cool!
You are a fisherman hired by a somewhat rundown town, but not limited to that specific place - you can travel to a variety of small towns and islands and meet many characters who'll give you quests along the way. Catch fish and sell it to earn money, seek treasure and upgrade your boat - but return to your safe haven before night falls. Because once the fog sets in, dangers lurk behind every corner. 

Something about this game makes it really hard to stop playing. You'll want to keep making progress and uncover all the mysteries that are being thrown at you. I did wish for an option to change the day length a bit, because it was quite tough in the beginning (with a not-yet-upgraded boat), but after a while I figured a better timing out.

Me and my husband both play this game on our own pc every night after work and I love how we both explored the world of Dredge together. And funny how we both do it in a different way, he's the just-do-it kinda guy, not afraid to explore at night and keep getting his ship wrecked, me on the other hand the overly cautious one, only travel during the day and avoid high panic meter and getting red eyed. After a while I'm not scared anymore, so for those thinking of buying this game but afraid it will be scary, it's not, atleast it's only in the beginning. So, don't miss out, buy this game!
