the most mid game to ever receive an overwhelmingly positive review

Bought it for the overwhelmingly postivie reviews, and I really don't see it. Every area is barebones, generally with a single NPC to talk to (not including the same shopkeeper in every area), who needs a specific fish for some reason and then you get a small powerup like fast travel or fishing really fast for a bit. 

They should remove the lovecraftian tag because there's pretty much no horror in the game at all. The scariest thing that can happen is a large snake thing chasing you. None of the NPCs seem to care, and the spooky lovecrafting powers are just  random game tools like fast travel or a speed boost. It's very hard for anyone to take it as a mysterious otherworldly power when it's just the equivalent of stepping on the accelerator.

Most NPCs have no interaction after the first time you talk to them. There's a point in the game where you have to help an NPC called The builder make a house and then take them there. At which point you never say anything new. Most NPCs are in the first 2 areas after which you'll won't even find more than 1 per zone.

Every quest is a fetch quest and all of them are convuluted reasons for which someone wants a particular fish. 
Even then, it can be nonsensical. There's a quest to give a certain fish to a robed cult members and the reward is a boost to your engine. 

This feels more like a mobile game that people can play on the side while doing something else.

I won't lie- I had my doubts about this game, given that fishing games (and fishing minigames), in my experience, tend to be grindy past the point of being enjoyable. Not DREDGE, however- the only time I felt like I was actually "grinding" was at the very end, for the last 10 aberrations. With the proper equipment, aberrations (special fish variants) became common enough (without actually being 'common,' per se) that it wasn't an interminable grind to complete the encyclopedia, and the sidequests added further intrigue while providing well-worthwhile rewards. 
The hazards in each area felt unique, and provided some genuine tension as I proceeded through the quests. I did a genuine double-take the first time I encountered [spoiler]the anglerfish[/spoiler], in particular- well done, you bastards. 
Honestly, the only reason I'd hesitate to give this game a 10/10 is because the outer areas of the circular region (i.e., the west and east ends) seem pretty empty, but I'm going to go out on a limb and assume that it's going to include content in a future DLC. Other than that, the game did what it intended to do, and that's a job well done. I was able to get the platinum in about 12 hours (not including 5 hours of idly enjoying the ambience), too.

This game was a surprising treat. A friend of mine recommended it as a 'fishing game meets creeping dread' and he was absolutely right. Overall: 9.5 of 10 - I loved every minute of it.

The Good
- The art style was unique and very suitable for the tone of the game
- It promoted a sense of calm that evolved into an entirely different experience over time
- The pacing in the game is a work of art. It's rare to see pacing so well done.
- I loved the creativity in the various species of fish, the way the plot unfolds, etc
- You could pause the game at any time, so it plays well as a casual game
- I particularly enjoyed most of the fishing mini-games, they were cathartic in a way that I imagine mimics real fishing
- I liked that the mechanics were generally simple and learned by experimentation. 
- I liked the use of audio and visual effects on the whole

The Neutral
- The organisation of the various 'hubs' was a bit weird and trite, but you tended to know where you needed to go next
- Players who don't enjoy horror might not enjoy this one
- Jury's out on whether the subject of fishing makes for an interesting plot
- The tone of the game is calm to mysterious to intriguing to anxiety ridden. 
- The game had a discernible story that required the player to read between the lines. If you like indirect messages and figuring things out yourself, you will probably like this game. If you prefer someone to just come out and say what they mean, the story may frustrate. All in all, your mileage may vary on this one.

The Bad
- It was sometimes hard to find things you were looking for, so I had to resort to Google to find spawns
- At some point, you run out of things to buy and the game feels a bit 'over' just slightly before I actually finished it
- The writing was okay enough to get the job done. There were some great points of mysterious atmosphere, but the plot really didn't come across as particularly deep. Occasionally there'd be a great story setup then the follow-through was disappointing or non-existent. The devs leaned more for atmosphere than satisfying story fruition. 
- The ending could have been more involved and impactful.
water is  scary

Great game, lots of fish, lots of rare fish, lots of fishing rods, lots of different mini-games, lots of different monsters. I played the beta version a while back and loved it, happy to see all the improvements!

I am a bit surprised at some of the abilities though since they seem a bit overpowered. The banish ability that can be immediately refreshed by sleeping, the bait that can be easily received to farm rare fish. The teleportation anchor seemed a bit unsatisfying, personally it would be better to be able to choose the second location instead of it being at Blackstone again, would certainly save a lot of time venturing from one end of the world to the other. The various DLCs also seemed a bit... out of place, it probably would have made more sense for The Pale Reach to come with the original game. And the Key DLC was completely unnecessary and just seemed like a cash grab instead of a "support the developers" title.

But then again, I've had a fantastic time overall. Looking forward to your next (hopefully also fishing related) projects!

Just finished getting all the achievements (Pale Reach included), and I can safely say Dredge was one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had in my life.  It's an absolutely perfect adaptation of a fishing boat simulator in a Lovecraftian world, and both facets are masterfully executed (along with art and music). One of my favorite aspects was how the difficulty is completely and seamlessly managed by how much (or how little) sleep you get.  I have absolutely zero complaints, other than I wish there was more already! Will definitely buy anything by Black Salt without so much as a trailer in the future.

When I sat down to play DREDGE, I was expecting a lax, calming game about sailing the seas and harvesting some fish. Sure, the "Lovecraftian" tag tipped me off a little, but I was sure that my innate fear of the ocean would keep me plenty entertained.

What I was NOT expecting was to walk away with DREDGE as one of my favourite games of the year in a year that has been jam-packed with amazing releases.

Seriously, this game does everything you'd want a game of this genre to do. It delivers on the fishing, it delivers on the world, the characters, the immersion and... well, that tag isn't there for no reason. In fact, it was so good that I was immediately compelled to go for 100% right after seeing the credits.

As for gameplay, it goes for a bizarre blend of a fishing minigame that you might find in a game like Stardew Valley or Animal Crossing, but it manages to sprinkle in one of the most ingenious elements from a game like Don't Starve: the Sanity (panic) meter. Trust me, you'll get used to frantically glaring at the surface of the water while that chromatic aberration kicks in.

The upgrade system helps you feel like you're truly progressing, and something that I cannot commend the game enough for is the freedom of choice. Do you want to brave the waters on the first night, slowly dredging while something larger-than-life waits beneath? Go ahead. Want to take your time, upgrading your ship as much as you can before entering a single major area? You can do that, too.

I CANNOT recommend this game enough if you're into this sort of "subtle horror" experience. If you're like me and are helplessly scared of any body of water that's more than two-feet deep, then all the better.

Definitely one of the standouts of the year, and one that I'll look back on fondly.

The game is about boating and fishing but with the heavy undertones of a Lovecraftian horror story. It's easily both a chill and chilling game, but if you're into all that creepy nonsense like I am then you may even find it therapeutic. One of the simplest joys I have is boating round during thunderstorms.

The story is beautiful. Special mention to the art department and that soundtrack.
The ending is fantastic

There's something special about the art style of this game that makes it a very peaceful experience, even when it's trying to be the opposite. The game not being very scary was okay with me. I wanted an experience that would take me away from the stress of work and life - that's exactly what I found here. The score and art style are uniquely soothing to experience. The game is rather simple but if you have minor ocd like me you'll find joy in it's clever use of organizational skills. The fishing is perhaps the easiest part of the game, which you might not suspect from a game that seems to be about fishing. Though it really isn't. It's a game about dredging - obviously. Dredging up a strange Lovecraft story-line that lays itself over the game's experience rather nicely.

The ocean at night is a terrifying place. Dark and vast, deep and unexplored. It's full of nightmares, don't fall overboard. You will drown or starve, be eaten or maimed. Fear the ocean, it can't be tamed.

Anyway check out this cute relaxing fishing game.

Additionally, some quests are not worth it. I'm not hunting fish for cosmetics and I'm not getting some weirdo specific fish. I feel like some of the upgrades even could be more purposeful or tied in with the story. Most of the time I just got fish to upgrade my boat and then when that's done, everything else seems a bit less thrilling. 

So like many games, I feel like you get overpowered and then detached from the game, but overall I'd recommend.

One is I wished the animated scenes, selling animations etc seen in the trailers were actually in the game, but they are not and they looked very cool. 
Secondly, I finished the game without "unlocking" any "black stone formation", they require high panic for them to work. I rarely had high panic because I was playing cautiously, so they are easy to miss and for me it's a shame that I missed all of their messages/phrases, I suggest a rework.

Incredibly misleading gameplay. This feels more like an inventory management simulator with some fishing elements. The game mechanics get stale really quickly as there really isn't any challenge to them. The eerie atmosphere loses its scare factor after an hour. Exploring the world felt like a chore as there isn't any fast-travel besides to the centre of the world.

The plot is non-existent and it felt like the game reached its conclusion really abruptly. Every character that I encountered felt incredibly shallow. The lovecraftian elements were highly exaggerated and it feels like an afterthought.

The only upsides are that the game looks pretty clean and the music is great. But other than that, I'm struggling to understand why is it rated so high.

Honestly, as someone who [i]hates[/i] fishing minigames and goes rabid for tetris-like inventory management, I loved this game. It looks great, it controls well, the insanity events are clearly telegraphed so you know they're not real (but they ARE dangerous), the story is both tantalizingly out-of-reach and easy to find bit of if you explore a bit, and it's tolerably frustrating (again, as someone who really does not enjoy fishing minigames).

My biggest complaint is that the inventory slots for the boat items (lights, motors, rods, etc) are off-center and the most efficient equipment leaves gaps, but that's purely a cosmetic thing that bothers me. No, wait, also heck the big eel. I hate him. Die in a fire, sir.

EDIT: I forgot!!! Thank you for having accessibility mechanics!!! Especially ones that don't lock you out of gameplay and achievements!!! The fishing-easier and the no-chromatic-aberration saved my bacon in terms of both frustration and also not getting migraines.

So I've done a couple of playthroughs of this game on the Switch before picking it up here on Steam so I can try to get all the achievements. So needless to say I can't recommend this game enough. The core gameplay loop is simple and fun. You go out and explore the various regions, fishing and dredging as you go. But lest you think this is a chill little fishing sim, let me tell you, things get spooky if you don't make it back to port before nightfall. The game doesn't explicitly forbid you from going into the fog at night, but let's just say there's a deterrent in each major area that will have you thinking twice about lollygagging.

The gameplay is a chore, there's no two ways about it. Fishing is made tedious and boring with a mini game that never manages to pose a challenge unless you are paraplegic or 5. Had it been 5 hours long it would've been a much better game, but it obviously would've spawned backlash due to the price. All in all, this game plays all too much like a mobile game - full of filler with very little meat. 

Overall a creative take, but a regretfully disappointing one.

In the first few hours, the game is really good, eerie, dark, curious. Sadly as soon as you unlock high speed you feel invincible. Sure, entering an area for the first time will have you on the edge, mainly from the game's atmosphere, but I just wish it had bigger threats and kept up the creepy vibes a bit longer.

The fishing grind is fun, the story is interesting enough to keep you going, the endings are not that great, but if a game makes hours go by fast, even if only for a few sessions before it ends, it's still a win in my book.

Dredge is a quite comfy yet Lovecraftian fishing simulator. I can say I thoroughly enjoyed my 30 hours with the game.
Should be played together with Subnautica for maximum maritime terror.

Although there are a few of minor things I could nitpick:
- Money, material and upgrade items become obsolete before halfpoint of the game. By the end of the Pale DLC I was sitting on 60k+ of useless cash.

- Nearly all of hostile sea monsters are more of a nuisance that a proper eldritch horror. The only exceptions being the Leviathan which you only see glipse of on an open sea and the slumbering god in one of the endings.

- The "good and "bad" endings are switched in my opinion.

- The ESG score must be high with these devs. The backwater archipelago set in 1930(?) is full of overly diverse, ugly women working traditionally men jobs that constantly send you on errands and to top it off the smartass lighthouse lady that sets you on the "good" path.

- Placing of the "panic mists" and whirlpools in the DLC is infuriating.

I'll preface this with this: It's not for everyone. For me, I just really vibe with the aesthetic.

Gameplay, while consisting of puttering around in a boat doing QTEs, is stimulating enough to stop at least me from getting bored, For me, the meat of the game was the aesthetic.
Solid soundtrack, absolutely enthralling sound design, and a solid feeling of the freedom of piloting a seafaring vessel. Feel is where this game shines. The control of the ship has weight without being slippery, and any sluggishness I would consider appropriate to the genre or method of transport.
The story as well is quite interesting; nothing groundbreaking, but the general consistency was good. The story feels local, lacking much in the way of breathtaking highs or depressing lows, aside from the ending itself. Cozy, ironically given the subject matter, is the term I would use.

Again, not for everyone, but I liked it.

Normally I wouldn't say a fishing minigame, inventory management "minigame" and just cruising around with a boat would be a fun game to play. Yet here we are... 

A well polished indie with some quite welcomed Lovecraftian theme.

Part cozy fishing sim, part eldritch horror: Dredge is my pick for game of the year! Its atmospheric and stylish visuals and soundscape evoke both the natural beauty of the open sea by day, and the jittering panic of facing horrors beyond human comprehension by night.
If you're a bit chicken (like me) you can control the amount you interact with the terrors by doing most of your adventuring in the daylight and spending the nights safe in port, but you can also choose to court danger and live on the edge! Of course, a certain amount of risk taking is necessary and encouraged to get the full experience, especially if you are going for 100% completion. And not all monsters are strictly nocturnal. (If you just want to tool around and explore and catch weird fish, the game also offers a pacifist mode where the terrors of the deep won't attack you, but I never found I needed it.)
The main storyline can probably be completed in a few hours if you focus only on that quest, but the game encourages exploration. I took the time to 100% the achievements in the base game, and later came back and enjoyed a second play-through with the additional DLC. (The Blackstone Key DLC offers a slight boost in the early game, but I mostly saw it as a way to tip the creators. The Pale Reach is an entire new map section and side quest that unlocks some useful abilities, and is thoroughly enjoyable if you want more Dredge.)
In short, Dredge manages to be by turns relaxing and bone-chilling, and always entertaining!
It's a short but very fun and atmospheric game. Definitely worth getting.

If you happen to be a fan of games like Sunless Sea and Sunless Skies, then this game is sort of a lighter version of those two. Without the need for having to ration supplies for an entire crew, fuel for your ship, or concern yourself [i]too[/i] much with needing to ferry goods back and forth for coin, this game is a milder take on Lovecraftian horror.

The beginning of the game certainly gives you the sort of under your skin type of anxiety that someone is lurking right around the corner or dwelling in the deep, but as you progress and upgrade to better equipment, it becomes less of a threat, and simply another obstacle in the way that you can either steer around or avoid entirely. 

I enjoyed this game for what it was worth, and have a good near 10 hours of searching for goodies and loose ends, but there are some aspects of this game that don't lend themselves well to the slow pacing/free lance mood you find yourself in.

All in all, I recommend this if you're looking for a slower paced game with hints of eldritch intrigue here and there, a lovely soundtrack that accents points in the story without being overbearing, and several open ended narratives that leave much to the imagination.

Answering the call for a Fisherman for Hire, you travel all the way out to the Marrows where you're expected to go out and harvest fish day and night and make end's meet. But within your first few days, you soon find that things are not what they seem in this vast ocean...

There are many people to meet, many biomes to explore, many fish to catch, and many ways to do all of it. I was drawn to this piece by its fishing theme, and I got what I was looking for and more. This game's art style and music are both worthy of praise as well - they do a great job of selling the gloomy atmosphere of living in a quaint fishing settlement like the ones we see in DREDGE.

For me there are no real flaws that stuck out in my playthrough. This game is well polished and I cannot get enough of it. I hope to get my hands on the DLC soon so that I can prolong my experience with DREDGE.

The game released very polished and the devs made a great decision that since they had to delay a DLC they chose to replace it with another that was meant to come later. So instead of just making the community wait for the delayed DLC we still got content.

I didn't think I'd like Dredge as much as I do, but it turned out to be a combination of essentially everything I like in a game. The satisfying boat upgrades, sleek inventory organization and management, captivating mystery filled story, and of course, THE FISHING, make Dredge a brilliant game which feels like it was made just for me. Oh, and did I mention the game is really pretty, too?

In summary, Dredge is a 10/10 for me and I highly recommend it. I think almost anyone can find something they enjoy about Dredge.

The game takes inspiration mostly from HP Lovecraft for its weird ocean fear vibes, but simultaneously grounds the aspect of it being a video game in tight mechanics that push a risk and reward system that really plays into the aspect of your initial confusion of not being familiar with the game. The mask of a fishing game that is always there with the trickling reminder that things are not right always being somehow present. Haven't played the ice zone yet but I expect hidden horror along the way.

Dredge is a short but rewarding immersive and unnerving foray into the horrors of the deep. The game features a gorgeously grim art style which ties the constant looming dread afforded by the music and storytelling, tying it all together beautifully. Each game mechanic (puzzles, upgrades, inventory management) enhances and paces the story well. Dredge is worth a purchase and a play - even when not on sale. The standard price is more than generous for the labour of love it is.

My only gripe with this game is minor, and the introduction of further content in DLC kind of abates it. The game unfortunately while being a fantastic experience loses out on it's replayability, that being said if you are a completionist and after achievements you can stretch the base game content to ~15 hours.

Overwhelmingly Positive.......I read the reviews. The occasional negative was that the first few hours were awesome but then after that it became too boring. I bought it on sale so no regrets, but I must agree with the minority of reviewers on this one. First few hours I loved it. But soon after it got boring. Mostly due to the fact that you cannot leave the dock for more than 3 or 4 minutes in real time then you have to return to the dock to rest because the time literally zooms by, or if you bump a rock you lose an engine so you need repairs, or the giant fish attack your boat making you take damage or lose what little bit of loot you scrounged up, or your cargo hold which is too small in the beginning stages cannot hold more than a handful of fish and it takes too much time out of the fun things the game has to offer like exploring and adventuring  when you are spending more time at the dock than you are out in the water. Seems to be a good amount of content and I did not encounter any bugs but I just cant do the back and forth over and over again for hours  for minimum game progression.

Surprisingly fun, light survival/exploration game. As I say in other reviews, I really don't like survival/craft games, but this one, as well as a few other choices hit that right balance of of it that when combined with the other elements of the game make it feel less a hassle and more fun which is what I want.

Add in the deep spooky story elements, the actually frighting night time exploration, giant evil fishing chasing you out of nowhere and you have a very fun and unique experience. Like no joke, I came into the game thinking the whole lovecraftian angle was sort of in-joke, next time I know a giant sea serpent has taken a bite out of the back of my boat and I let out an IRL scream of terror as I'm running for my life, lol.

Got my wife back. Nothing bad happened. Nope. Not a thing.

Man, what a gem of a game. I loved and enjoyed every second of it. The relaxing fishing portions are cool and fun, but the story, atmosphere, themes and music really reel you in. The gameplay is tight and fun, the graphics are beautiful and the music is great. The eldritch horror portions of the game was also very enjoyable. I guess my only negative with the game is not knowing which missions are timed and also how you receive less research parts in missions than what is needed to complete the research portion of the upgrades.

Other than that, I had a blast. I wouldn't call the game short, you just have to decide your own level of involvement. Do you just want a quick story with some gameplay?  It might run you for about 6 hours. Do you want to go through the whole thing?  Complete every mission, see every fish, explore all locations and riddles? Might take you anywhere around 10 to 20. Either way, it's worth it.

When I completed the game, all I could think of was that I wanted more. More abilities, more fish, more locations, more everything. I wanted more not because the game was lacking, but because I didn't want it to end. If the devs made a sequel (or DLC) and it was the same graphics, same music but adding more of everything, I would probably pre-order it. I hope they make more of these and just play around the endings. There's always more sea to explore.

Update:

Just finished the DLC and it was just more of what I wanted. I still would have liked more story, side missions and fish, however I am very happy with what we got. I hope there are more DLC's to come! A sequel would be great too.

What a great journey. As a Lovecraftian mythos fan I got to say I loved the various story element adaptation and the shape of this universe. Great atmosphere and story. There were quite a few subtle Lovecraftian twists I really appreciated.
Gameplay is essentially fetching stuff, but all game mechanics and progression put into perspective - it got never dull or boring. You are never made to grind, but sometimes you got to try harder and overcome RNG. Journey was never tedious or feeling like wasting my time. Everything is placed with intent, if you are curious and explore a bit, you will find everything and you will experience everything the game has to offer without any help of guides. There is no unnecessary backtracking, multilayering zone locking behind progression or other 'smart' ways to recycle same content.
I loved how game progress, how your character and vessel progress - things become kind of harder, but the upgrades you pick up makes you less careful and more in control of various high-risk situations.
As I finished it 100% plus the DLC, my only complaint is that it could have had few more main pursuits and few more zones. Style is gorgeous, kudos to the people who worked on the art.

All in all, if you love Lovecraft mythos, this one is a no brander, creators definitely did not do dirty on this one.

Underrated game, it's so good. I kept finding myself wanting to go out of my way to grind the different fish types and completing all side quests, useless ones too. Peaceful fishing game with a heaping side of Lovecraft horror, Dredge does a great job combining peaceful and stressful elements into a single game without losing one or the other.

The game itself isn't particularly long but feels fine for the amount of time you put into it. The fishing mechanic is simple so you won't be struggling to catch anything too badly, it also changes slightly depending on what fish you are going after for a bit of variety. The upgrading system is smooth and upgrading your ships hull changes the appearance of the ship which I really like and makes the upgrade system feel more impactful.

The 3D environment looks great, combined with the day night cycle does so much for the games atmosphere, the ocean is a whole different place at night. The characters and fish on the other hand are instead stylized 2D sprites that look even better, the fish in particular each have a rarer corrupted "aberration" form each with a unique sprite. Each of the zones in the game have a unique look, mechanics, and story to them, Stellar Basin in particular is amazing.

Overall Dredge is a great game with a great story and a fair price with an ambiance and atmosphere second to none. Don't forget just because you don't see anything on the open ocean doesn't mean something doesn't see you, try going out of bounds.

honestly this game is something else. i love the seemingly cutsie fishing in a small ocean town mixed with the eldritch horror of whats beyond the bay, its so captivating with its mystery of whats on that island or whats beneath the waves. We need more games like it and im stoked to see what else these devs come up with in future DLCs or even games

This is one of the greatest games I've ever played. Massively recommend to anyone who loves horror or fishing simulators. There's more depth to this game then you would expect, especially now with the Pale Reach DLC.

I feel there are two ways to approach Dredge, you can either take the slow and careful approach and actually prepare for each new challenge or you can just say "screw it" and charge around getting stuff done and dying frequently. Fortunately, the game autosaves and you respawn without losing too much. Great game. Would definitely recommend.

I really enjoyed it. It was a nice breath of fresh air to try my hand at a horror game, and this one was interesting and rewarded you a lot for exploration and engaging with the story and remembering different tid bits.

The biggest downside is that there's not much content. I've played through the game twice and the DLC once and it took me 35 hours to do a full completionist run. It's not a difficult game when you learn the rules. Those lovely hours before you know the rules and where the angler's dens are are terrifying in my eyes.

But it's such a short game. Great to replay and enjoy the vibe every once in a while, but if you like to skirt the edge of danger instead of running head first into it to see what happens, you might enjoy this game a bit more.
So far, my only complaint is that there isn't enough of it. It is a delightful game, and I hope they will make more expansions.

I've played a metric butt-load of games. If you like slow creeping horror... Unique indie art... A small, but full experience... Easy recommendation. Buy it full price, buy it on sale... It doesn't matter as long as you own this game.

---

A Lovecraft-themed fishing simulator where you play tetris with your catch, upgrade your ship, gain skills, and slowly uncover the truth of the sea you sail in. This game puts you in a world filled with a beautiful art style, solid sound design, and a generally upsetting atmosphere. It's somehow very cozy, and then quite spooky at the same time. It's that creeping dread of the world being not -quite- right.

I really enjoyed the lighthouse you can see from nearly everywhere on the map which is a lovely detail in the dead of night, when everything else is covered by near impenetrable fog. The fact that each cluster of islands has a very distinct theme and flavor in the art and sound is really enjoyable.

The Pale Reach adds a very fun area to the south of the map as well. The fear of what the ice may hide is oh so fun.

There is also a peaceful, anti-spooky mode if all you want is a fishing sim. Lots of cool fish.
Absolutely adore this game. Lovecraftian fishing? How could not like it. Just buy it.

How can I describe the feeling that the first playthrough of this game made me feel ?
The feeling of hapiness to discover something mysterious but the dread to find out what horror lies beneath the surface.

Great art, good music, gameplay strangely addictive even if it's just a minigame of fishing.

I'll draw in it again when the next DLC will pop out, for sure.
Very Relaxing Game and innovative Gameplay Idea.

Dredge's greatest strength is that it's very relaxing and incredibly tense as a game, seamlessly able to swap between the two moods at a moments notice. Most games aren't able to pull off such a balancing act, at least not in an organic manner, but Black Salt Games nailed it with Dredge.

Mechanically, the ship movement and abilities feel good, both of which can be altered by upgrades, and the core game play loop is solid and enjoyable. Fish and dredge for useful materials, sell your catch and any found treasures, upgrade and expand your boat, repeat. It's a good positive feed back loop reinforced by regular discovery and simple fishing and dredge mechanics that are varied and quick to learn. Day and night cycle and stress regularly interrupts the process preventing the whole loop from becoming tedious. Eventually you'll have to risk more and more to get greater rewards, and make more progress in the story and world, which is what allows the aforementioned balancing act between peaceful and stressful to exist int the first place. Night is dangerous, and threats real or imagined will follow you into the day if you stubbornly refuse to rest at a dock to prevent insanity and paranoia from setting in.

Thematically, the game is perfect. You feel like you're really captaining your fishing vessel and will manage your time and resources intuitively. The ocean and the archipelago feels alive with ambient wildlife (both mundane and not), yet vast and lonely at the same time. Plenty of elements of mystery and horror work their way into the story and just exploring the world, with classic ghost story at sea tropes, a bit of sci-fi here and there, constant Lovecraftian undertones and threats that become more prominent as the story progresses, and even something of biblical origins and proportions if you're 'lucky' enough to witness it. All of this is tied together by the beautiful music, both those tracks dedicated to specific locations or events in the game, but also the ambient pieces that add so much to the exploration and sailing at sea.

Dredge is a wonderful, phenomenal game. I encourage everyone to check it out.

"Dredge" is a small and simple game that combines various elements to create an immersive experience centered around the uncertainty and fear of the ocean. the exploration channels Outer Wilds vibes, where there is little direction and the limited but detailed world allows you to put the story together yourself as you play. With 30% exploration, 30% fishing mini-games, 30% inventory management, and 10% concerns about the dark, the game offers a unique twist on a casual looking collection game. The art is beautifully done, and the music and sound design enhance the atmospheric ambiance. While not particularly long or challenging, it's enjoyable to play and relax while catching fish. The game's cosmic horror theme, although not especially terrifying, still leaves you with unanswered questions and intriguing mysteries about the world. It effectively presents cosmic entities indirectly through mutated fish, distant shapes, and fragments from an ancient civilization. [spoiler] The twist before the conclusion is well executed and cot overly signposted. [/spoiler] If you enjoy chill games and cosmic horror, "Dredge" is recommended. It's also worth 100%, as it showcases everything it has to offer without being overly difficult, and you can obtain both endings and all achievements in a single playthrough.

So glad also to see some  new add on content with the ice breaker and cold climate.  This game is definitely replayable, even when you finish.  For young or old.  Absolutely a must buy for anyone's collection!

Dredge has a lot of very good ideas and features, but it really gets dragged down by how linear and predictable the game gets. The first 2 hours of this game is fine, but later it feels like a chore. Traversing the ocean and spending one full-ass in-game day moving two tiddlywinks of water, only to go to a dock to skip the night because the night will make you insane, is not fun. It doesn't make much sense that most of the actual horror of this game comes from the Panic feature (which you get mostly from night time), and then give incentive to the player to not play the game during the night. This means that most of the horror parts barely feel present, or are not present at all.

Islands feel empty and boring. The open waters are boring. The whole story is the most generic "Go to this place and get an item" quest. Even when there is some attempt to make quests interesting (Airman traps, Researcher generator, those flame things), they end up being the exact same "Catch 2-3 Fish" and "Go here and get this". When you've finished the first few quests, you've done all of them. It really does feel like they built the starter area (The Marrows) and then shoehorned a bunch of other areas on top of it, instead of making it one cohesive world. Half way through the game it didn't even feel like I was playing a fishing game at all, simply a fetch quest simulator with fish as the item. 

This game would've worked much better if it was more free roam, less linear, had more purpose to empty islands, and leaned a bit more into the fishing/seafaring aspects of the game.

I've been a longtime Lovecraft enjoyer, so I was looking forward to playing Dredge.

In terms of graphics, it's colorful, stylish and it runs well on a simple computer. It's very relaxing to wander about and take in everything at your own pace. The story is very simple, but it works. It cuts to the chase and the quests are straightforward. In the end, it's a gentle introduction to Lovecraft and you'll enjoy completing the quests that you're given.

However, the game's pacing has real issues. The first area that you're recommended to explore is the most difficult. After that, it's pretty much downhill. You can upgrade your ship and build it into a fortress, but there really isn't any point in doing so since there aren't any serious threats. 

Honestly, I enjoyed the game and I think anyone can too. It's great for relaxing after work. If you were looking for Lovecraftian horror, I'd rather go for something Nobody lives under the lighthouse.

This is a wonderful fishing adventure game that combines mini game aspects (fishing), with puzzle solving, and horror/suspense. You "level up" your boat by upgrading it as you find and sell your catch while investigating the mystery around the towns. The story is not overly dramatic nor overly simple. It quickly pulls you in. This is my indie game of the year, and easily a top 10 game of the year, in a packed year of games.

Phenomenal game, You can really tell that the devs actually care about the game.        The artstyle is cosy. creepy, and beautiful all whilst also being very minimalist.    It features an amazing Soundtrack,   and can really just let you sink into the game and play for hours without realising it.          The story is quite fun to figure out, although some of it requires you to sort of figure it out for yourself.          There are tons of small side content to do, and lots of places to explore, it also has a really enjoyable gameplay loop,          

My only qualm is with how good the game is, I wish there was more new content!      But the devs are releasing DLC for it!


I hope they add a bit more customisation to your boat though. especially in the layout/inventory section of it.



I would fully recommend picking this game up even at full price, it supports the devs and rewards them for a job well done.

Dredge is a tour de force in the gaming industry, a mesmerizing journey that transcends conventional boundaries and elevates the player experience to unprecedented heights. From the moment you delve into its intricately crafted world, it's evident that Dredge is more than just a game; it's a work of art.

The narrative brilliance of Dredge is its beating heart, weaving a tapestry of emotions and engaging plotlines that captivate players from the opening scene to the final credits. The character development is nothing short of extraordinary, as each persona is imbued with depth, nuance, and a sense of authenticity that forges a profound connection between the player and the virtual realm.

Visually, Dredge is a feast for the senses. The attention to detail in the environmental design is breathtaking, with every pixel meticulously placed to create a stunning, cohesive world that feels both fantastical and tangible. The game's graphics are not just a backdrop; they're a dynamic force that enhances the overall storytelling, immersing players in a visually stunning universe.

Gameplay in Dredge is a symphony of innovation and entertainment. The mechanics are finely tuned, offering a balance between challenge and accessibility. Whether navigating intricate puzzles, engaging in heart-pounding combat, or embarking on epic quests, the gameplay seamlessly integrates with the narrative, enhancing the overall immersive experience.

Moreover, the musical score of Dredge is nothing short of a masterpiece. Each note, each melody, is carefully composed to evoke emotions that complement the unfolding story. The soundtrack is not merely background noise; it's an integral part of the game that enhances the emotional impact, making every moment memorable.

Dredge is a testament to the dedication and passion of its development team. It's evident that every element, from the storyline to the visuals, was crafted with meticulous care. The result is a gaming experience that transcends the ordinary, leaving an indelible mark on players who embark on this extraordinary journey.

In conclusion, Dredge is not just a game; it's a magnum opus that sets a new standard for excellence in the gaming industry. It's an immersive, emotional rollercoaster that pushes the boundaries of what games can achieve. Dredge is, without a doubt, a must-play for anyone seeking a transformative gaming experience.

Something that would have helped me from the start: The game saves at each dock, so if your ship is destroyed, the only consequence is to load the game at the most recent dock.

The game is easy to get into in the beginning, but around the 3 hour mark I started to wonder how this game has such an Overwhelmingly Positive response.  At that point in the game, by the time you got your boat to somewhere you needed to go, it was time to turn around because you didn't want to get caught in the night fog eyeballs.  It was a constant back/forth of slowly collecting fish and dredging resources with a one-button timing mini-game (but never more than one outing/day). Around the 6 hour mark, this turned around; not because of the better boat upgrades, faster speed, etc., but because I'd found all of the places to dock so that I wouldn't have to turn around so much.  Maybe it's my own fault for not looking at guides.

It's a well made game with interesting (albeit shallow) characters, but thinking back to the actual gameplay, there's very little strategy, the one-button minigames are meh, and navigating your boat are all very low-stimulation activities. That said, it's a great game for the Deck with its big UI, and add to that time in the game stops moving when your boat stops, it makes it easier to occasionally participate in conversations while playing...

[h1] A Great Game That Falls Short [/h1]

[u][b]What does that mean?[/b][/u]

It's a fantastic game. An intriguing lovecraftian story, a fitting yet unique art style, simple yet fun gameplay loop, and of course plenty of fÃ∏ÕÜÃùiÃ∂ÃíÃÆsÃµÃîÃ¶hÃ∂ÕåÃ∫ to catch. The gameplay is like the open ocean aspect of Wind Waker but refined and expanded upon, which is no small compliment. The soundtrack is also pretty dang good, so I'd recommend grabbing that as well if you're into OSTs. 

[i]However[/i], the game does feel lacking in a few areas, and I say that because of the potential it has due to the polish of what it gets right. The writing in the beginning is fantastic, the intrigue of what's going on and the allure that a good lovecraftian story can have is really strong. It gets it so right in the beginning of the game, but that's where it peaks. At least it did for me, that is. After maybe an hour in, you can figure out pretty much what's going on, which isn't bad if it was just in terms of the story, but it isn't. You've experienced most of the gameplay, too. 

There are some really cool elements added for each area you go to to progress that shakes things up, and they get that so right. But once you're through in that area, it doesn't stick around. It's a one and done gimmick to that area instead of something that adds to the gameplay after you get what you need, which is a real shame because it could add a bit more difficulty to an already easy game, especially after a few upgrades. It doesn't stay.

Speaking of upgrades, they're good. They add more to what you can catch/do and increases what you can carry, adding more gameplay and incentive to seek out materials, keeping interest. What you do to acquire what you need for upgrades is really fun, and ultimately they get it right. But the one thing you might not realize you get when upgrading your ship is wasted, being hull integrity. You can take more crashes/hits before you sink, which is good if you're a bit clumsy or have trouble with what lÃ¥ÃäÃßiÃµÕ†Ã•eÃ∏ÃáÃ®sÃ∏ÃéÕî Ã∂ÃèÕñbÃ∏ÕíÃ≠eÃ∑ÕåÃÆnÃµÕÄÕÖeÃ∑ÕòÃ§aÃ∏ÃÇÃ´tÃµÕòÃûh... But those dangers don't really increase, just shift a bit. [spoiler](Looking at you, Devil's Spine.)[/spoiler] To go back to my previous point, it feels like the stakes aren't raised after getting what you need. And once you've upgraded your ship to max, a substantial and fun mechanic becomes practically useless. 

Lastly I want to touch on the story, or the writing specifically. Like I said before, during the beginning of the game the writing is great. But maybe halfway through it becomes a bit watered down, (no pun intended). Perhaps a bit less descriptive, or maybe just not as alluring, I'm not sure. What I am sure of is that it feels like the curiosity that [b]hooked[/b] me at the start of the game stopped [b]reeling me in[/b], (pun intended), and became a little generic. Not bad, but not as good. I will say that there was something that caught me off guard, and that was a great feeling. But then it became generic again almost right after. Again, not bad, it just left me a little underwhelmed.

With all the crap I just gave it, I need to emphasize; [b][u]I loved every minute of the game[/u][/b]. All of what I said was out of the love I felt for playing this. I want to convey these criticisms so that the next game, or even the possible DLC (hopefully) that these devs will make will be what I know it can be, [b]fantastic[/b]. They have talent, and it shows with this game here. I want to see the full extent of what they can do realized. [i]And I'll be there when it is.[/i] 


TLDR:
It's got plenty of potential for more, although it's great as it is and you should absolutely play it.

Update:
I will be trying the DLC out and will (hopefully) come back to edit/add my thoughts.

Summary:
The game is good, but rather unremarkable in every aspect other than its visuals.

Some details:
-The artstyle is really gorgeous, and might be the only thing that keeps the game from being a waste of time for most people.
-The gameplay loop got old a bit too fast for me, and the gameplay doesn‚Äôt evolve much past ‚Äúget to new area->do some chore for a local npc->get key item ->unlock slighly useful traversal skill->repeat‚Äù.
-Also, given the game‚Äôs setting and influence from lovecraft‚Äôs texts, it‚Äôs a surprise that the game is not scary at all, on very rare occasions it does make you feel slightly uneasy, but they are way too few and far in between as to contribute to the general feel of the game. 
-The nighttime is just a mild inconvenience rather than a creepy stage, which also lacks any tangible reward for braving it, so you‚Äôll probably skip most of the nights if you have to go from one map zone to another.
-The narrative is good, a bit boring and too straightforward, but it‚Äôs enough to motivate you to at least keep playing till the end

Black Salt Games really set a high bar, can't complain at all! Very persuasive and captivating take of a single player adventure where the protagonist, you "The Angler" have decided to take on the mission of holding your own out at sea, settling in the town of Greater Marrow. You must fend for yourself by scavenging what you can out of the fear inducing open waters, and face multiple challenges, learn the cursed secrets of the islands, complete with interesting character development, satisfying side quests, beautiful exploration, and unique abilities taken to a level not seen in other titles in this genre. 

Not to mention - solid mechanics of movement, when for example, being met with the panic induced terrors and hazards in the night, the monsters chasing your vessel - its an engaging and fluid experience. While the story itself may be a quick one, the multiple ending dynamic of this story was short but sweet. Huge replay value as well, you can create many strategies of beating the game in different methods. No spoilers here, don't worry.

The Blackstone Key DLC is totally not PTW... or necessary to enjoy the game, although the Devs really deserve the tip, as the game is fairly priced. I found it useful for the endgame, to catch all the aberrations, simply for the achievement.

I am also happy to see that the Devs really listen to the community, and conduct updates and reported bug fixes surprisingly efficiently and swiftly. The new update is a great addition of content to the game and there is a steady roadmap for 2023 regarding its future development.

Worth the try if you have never played this kind of game before, honestly it reeled me in quick, check it out!

Update - The Pale Reach DLC is awesome. Good on Black Salt games for not giving in to public pressure and ironing out all the kinks before releasing it to the public, gotta respect devs for that in today's greedy world. It is fun and very innovative. The feature that surprised me the most and made me think, wow I never knew I needed that until I saw it, was to be able to freeze your prized catches to last longer outside the water.

Dredge is great.
It works both as a casual fishing game, and as a low-key eldritch horror game. Many games take the look of eldritch horror, and many look great, but few accomplish any of the actual.. yknow.. horror. Dredge gets it. 

There is an oppressive weight through the game that pushes you into the escapism of the fishing, and this feeling of trying to ignore the horrors creeping in is exactly what this genre is about!

Had a very nice time with it, and will definitely be keeping an eye on its future.

Dredge is a wonderful experience, with a great soundtrack and amazing art style. The Lovecraftian elements are well-executed, and the management sim and fishing minigames are entertaining for the duration of the game. The only part of the game I would say is a little lackluster is the narrative, which is left intentionally vague. I would have loved to have more lore and deeper world building, but for the sake of being a fun and casual game with emphasis on ambiance, Dredge hits the nail on the head. I definitely recommend Dredge and its DLC if on sale, as the length of the game is rather short, but everything that is included is masterfully done.

A cute little Lovecraft inspired fishing game. Explore archipelagos, fish, sell your catch, upgrade your boat, travel that bit further out, encounter dark eldritch horrors, go insane, get eaten.

At first, the insanity meter, hallucinations and monsters make night a spooky affair but eventually you realise you can easily survive the entire night. The Lovecraft stuff just ends up being largely window dressing. 

Despite the elder-god stuff being weak, the fishing loop is a lot of fun. Each fish-catching and fish type have their own quick little mini game, and there's something very satisfying about tetris-ing your boat inventory to fit one more fish. Fish, upgrade your boat, travel further, see spooky stuff in new locals. 

I should mention, this is not a rogue-like. There's a clear through line main quest that carries you from biome to biome, and each archipelago has its own major and minor quests associated with them. 

Its honestly a pretty chill fishing game, with a neat painted aesthetic and aquatic-lovecraft trimmings.

One of the best games that I have ever played. Period. Sound is beautiful, story is phenomenal, and the game play managed to be both relaxing and nerve-wracking. I truly hope this gains more traction.

Had high hopes coming into this one as a fan of Lovecraft and was left completely satisfied. Although short, this game is the perfect example of something being 'greater than the sum of its parts', with each of its individual components coming together to create a cohesive and polished experience that never gets boring. It feels like a nice balance between the classic Simulation style of games like Stardew Valley and Spiritfarer, and 'walking-sim' adventure games like Little Nightmares and A Short Hike that rely heavily on their distinct artstyle and aesthetic. The core gameplay loop of catching fish to upgrade your boat and fill out your collection is simple but addictive, but the main selling point is in the exploration. The game is deeply immersive, looking and sounding equal parts beautiful and eerie, and it's a ton of fun sailing through its open-world to find all the dramatic and terrifying points of interest, and to put together all the pieces of how this world came to be. Overall, a brilliantly engaging experience, and worth checking out for fans of simulation or exploration-driven adventure games, or for those who just like cosmic horror in any form.

DLC: The Pale Reach DLC was also brilliant, albeit slightly anticlimactic, but considering the overall quality and how seamlessly it fits into the base game, it's absolutely worth picking up if you want more.

Played for almost 8 hours, I think I was around 3/4 of the game.
My main issue of the game is the speed of time. You want to be most active during the day, where there are no lovecraftian horrors awaiting for you. But it goes so fast, that you entire day might be just fishing in two places and then run home. Even if you only want to explore, you almost intermediately have to go back.
Of course, this all sounds just like regular survival game stuff, and it is. But it feels too constricting.
The other mayor thing that annoyed me was the lack of cruise control. It's a boat, let me set the speed and let go of the keyboard.
One more thing about the lovecraft theme, it feels a bit pasted on. While there is spooky stuff that you can interact with, the main stuff seems to be happening to the npc's, not you. For you it's just hazards, different fishes, and puzzles to solve.

This game has insane amounts of style, the music and atmosphere are excellent, and the overall vibe is undeniably Lovecraft. All together, wonderful little game, but I would wait for a sale.

A tidy little fishing game with a small eldritch twist.
Fishing/Ship progression is pretty nicely tied to story progression.
I did find that for achievement completion there were some things that were a bit harder to find than others mostly due to it being a percent based chance of 'rolling' a specific rare fish.
Don't expect anything incredibly challenging when it comes to this, the game is definitely something easy to consume in small chunks.

I usually don't write reviews, but this game is too good not to, especially with the release of the Cold Reach DLC and the planned release of another DLC next year which looks to be just as good if not better. 

First of all, the sound design of this game is truly amazing, and it's one of the few OSTs I actually listen to when not playing the game. Most of it is very relaxing, but in certain areas the soundtrack definitely amplifies the fear of the unknown and the lovecraftian vibes.

Although the gameplay loop is somewhat simple: catch fish and dredge for parts to bring both back and earn money to upgrade your ship and get better equipment, it's also so much more than that. Each NPC you meet along the way has a unique voice and narrative (except for maybe the "figure(s) in [colour]") that make them stand out and make the world feel genuine.  The quests you get can be a challenge to complete, but they also are rewarding, either giving you something to progress the story or just to make your life easier (ie books, upgrade parts). 

Speaking of which, the story. The story, although seemingly simple, is one of the best stories that I have seen in a video game. Without spoiling anything, I would say that although the story's straightforward, you can pick up both background information and clues to the ending(s) throughout your playthrough which help you to understand the ending(s). 

If you're concerned about the replayablity of the game, I will say that it is still just as fun a second or third time around, especially if you're trying to get either fish or notes or books that you missed. It doesn't have the same impact as the first time when you're wondering what the story is, but it is still very fun. This isn't even mentioning the "Cold Reach" DLC, which adds another layer of worldbuilding and the fact that another DLC is supposed to come out next year. 

I definitely think the game is worth the $25 price tag, but if you're concerned about that then you can always wait for a sale, especially if you're planning on getting DLC(s) with it.

Dredge is a lovecraftian fishing game! The premise seems weird but I actually enjoyed it a lot. The atmosphere is really well crafted and the game will appeal to collector types as you have to find all kinds of normal and aberrant fish while trying to solve the game's main storyline mystery. You also work a lot to improving your boat (engines for speed, cargo hold for space, stronger lights for protection at night and so on). I finished this game at about 10 hours gameplay, but did a chunk of it offline on the steam Deck while I was on holidays. Steam glitches out and didn't recognise the hours from offline mode. 

Dredge is one of the best indie games I've played in a good while. I played the demo back in the last Steam Next Fest and knew I wanted it straight away, so I stopped playing the demo almost immediately to get the most out of the full game. The art style is great, the gameplay loop is satisfying and the story progression hooked me in as quickly as I was hooking poor twisted bass up out of the waters of little marrow. 

I didn't know it had a darker, lovecraftian side until after I'd played the demo, which suited me down to the ground. 

This also has a big emphasis on inventory management, which I love. It's almost puzzle like. You have to do a bit of tetrising to make sure you're getting your cargo stored correctly, especially in the early game if you want to make money quick. 

The only improvements I could suggest for this game are very minor. I wish the boat's engine was a bit more audible. Not hearing the engine makes you feel like you're gliding around a bit too much. Plus it would open the door for your upgrades feeling better when you hear the unique sound of your high end engine instead of the rattle of your old one. 

Some of the UI interactions feel a little bit clunky on controller. Transferring things to and from menus can be a bit of a pain sometimes. 

Otherwise, this is a top tier game for me. It runs perfectly on the steam deck too. Smooth 60fps at all times. Same story for my ageing 1070 GPU. 4k60fps at all times. 

Great game, extremely well designed and optimised.

Edited 4 months later: I've played this game on and off for the last few months, and have come to absolutely love it. 12 hours of play since I reviewed it and it's whole atmosphere kept me coming back over and over. just 100%'d it today and I'm actually sad that I'm fully finished it. Really hope there's a plan for some good DLC or a sequel. Great game. Easily my Indie GOTY and up there as one of my favourite light horror, atmospheric and Lovecraftian games ever.

Dredge is an Adventure/Exploration game focused on fishing, with a sprinkle of lovecraftian horror elements. The consistent, yet nonrestrictive game play loop and the creative world/art keep you engaged throughout it's ~15-20 hour runtime. While the world gives you enough information to be intrigued, the plot and stories that are told through the game are not as prevalent. 

Dredge contains a solid game play loop of fishing for money and using the money for upgrades. Ship upgrades allow for more hull space, faster travel, and new categories of fish to capture. Developing strategies around upgrade paths was truly the hook of the game. Every upgrade feels immediately rewarding. The freedom in the upgrading and management of the game is also reflected in the world. While the game does provide you with set objectives, you are free to explore the world at your will. I had a lot of fun exploring "late game" areas early, and then returning later on, better equipped to manage it's unique challenges. 

Adopting horror elements into a fishing game seems out of place, but Dredge manages to pull it off. It invokes the fear of the unknown multiple times throughout the adventure, whether through it's mechanics or it's world. The art, in particular the creative design around the aberration fish designs was truly a treat. I find myself wanting to catch every species just to see the creative ideas the art team came up with. 

Dredge implements a day system where time passes as you are moving. Unfortunately, the mechanic of passing days did not come into play besides a day/night cycle and a few side-quests. I would have loved to see more quests and objectives utilize the day system in such a way that it forces you to make temporal decisions.

This is a fantastic little romp into the world of Eldritch Horror lite and a beautifully relaxing one at that, if you can believe it. I mean, really, it's a fishing game at heart with a smattering of mystery surrounding both your origins and what's going on in the world around you. As you complete pursuits, fish up oddities in the sea, and meet some rather colorful and... well oddball characters along the way, shining a light in all the dark places, you start to understand that nothing is ever as it seems and maybe the root cause is closer to home than you think. 

It's not an incredibly long adventure but it never once over stays its welcome; even the repetitive bits (there's a lot of fishing, ok? A LOT.) are actually quite enjoyable. The music filters in alongside the ambient noises, the waves crashing against you hull and the rocks around the various sites on the map, even the unsettling echos from the fog and unseen entities floating through the ocean are just fantastic. 

I highly recommend this game to anyone that's looking for something to scratch both a fishing itch and to immerse yourself in a bite sized horror atmosphere. 

I had a blast and hope others do too.

EDIT: Nov. 22, 2023

The Pale Reach dlc is a fantastic continuation of the story bringing in new fish, new encounters, new npcs, and just simply more of the game that I love and cherish. If you haven't tried Dredge now is the best time to take the plunge!

After 13.5 hours, I finished my first playthough. If you are a person that loves either 1. diving into lore and reading data entries about the world, or 2. love to collect curios and complete lists, this game is PERFECT for you. BUT I would also recommend this game to anyone who doesn't play that way, its entirely possible to experience the incredible story without getting caught in the weeds reading all the text. I found that, despite all the reading, I never experienced fatigue or wanting to skip over anything. Others have finished the game in less time than I did.

Honestly, I'd pay full price for this game. And I might even pick up the DLC to tip the devs. This is the kind of new, fresh game that the industry needs. Not a reboot, or a sequel. Not a game as a service, or a big blockbuster hit. Just good stories, fun mechanics, and tight streamlined controls. 10/10 will play again.

Update: The DLC Pale Reach does NOT disappoint! I can't wait for the next one. I bought the Blackstone Isle Key DLC and don't regret it either. The devs have so much love for this game. They hangout in the official discord and chat with players all the time.

DREDGE is great, but it's a wee shame that it's so short. I've 100% it within 24 hours, but I had finished most content within the first 15. The gameplay is very simple, but engaging. Between navigation, fishing and inventory management, it's a robust game that rewards your progress. When you visit a new region, your ship becomes beefier and your tools become more versatile. While the endgame might be very easy if you play it very safe, your panic meter will give you a run for your money if you stay out in the dark too long, with paranormal threats bombarding you if you aren't careful.

DREDGE also manages to have incredible atmosphere. From the music ambiance to the creeping echoes for when you visit the hooded figures around the archipelago, the sound design is incredible. 
The visual design is great as well, with beautifully illustrated characters and fish, as well as charming flat-coloured 3D graphics. The game is visually intuitive with QOL features like map markers having recently been added. 
The game definitely leaves you wanting for more but it's such a good game you should try it out anyway. The Pale Reach DLC adds a wee something, and Black Isle are still developing more DLC and updates, so there definitely will be more.

Also, try and avoid spoilers. It's a pretty good story when you start reading between the lines of the things you see and find.

The game isn't that good at explaining a few things, and you can permanently miss things without knowing.   I was on the fence of recommending, but that last part tipped the scale.   There is NO reason to have quests that are not only timed, but doesn't tell you they are timed either literally or storywise.  You can easily do some world building and explain urgency for a quest, but nope you come back and it is gone.  Losing permanent upgrades because I started a quest too early is a terrible design choice.

Edit:  They removed the timed quests so I'm giving this a recommend.  The game is still a bit shallow, but enjoyable all the same.  It is still a fun game, but still also shallow.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Dredge is a game best described as "just enough." 
Just enough story, just enough fishing, just enough variety.
Just enough pelagic nightmares and horrors of the deep.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
[h3]Updated for the First DLC Release!![/h3]

Dredge is a unique and well-put-together game about fishing, with some horror elements thrown into the mix. The story serves it's purpose as a driving factor, both for the plot and your curiosity. When the story falls short, the atmosphere and artstyle pick up the slack. There's enough variety in the different mechanics of the game that they don't get tedious. To some people, the game might be a little short for the price tag but I think it was "just enough" to hook my interest and reel me in.

Playtime: 28.8 hours for two full 100% playthroughs.
Update 1.1-1.3 Playtime: 2.0 additional hours for 100%.
Pale Reach Playtime: 2.0 additional hours for 100% (with endgame ship and equipment).

[hr][/hr]

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[b]World[/b] - While the story might be pretty simple, I really enjoyed the worldbuilding itself. It has great atmosphere, both during the day and the night, has charismatic characters, and encourages you to be curious about things.

[b]Fishing[/b] - One of the better minigames that I've seen. There's a few different styles and sizes that help to break up doing the same thing repeatedly. It's quick to pick up, and not too difficult, but rewards being good at it. I didn't get tired of it at all during my playthrough. Satisfyingly simple.

[b]Variety[/b] - There's [strike]128[/strike] (now 151, or 174 with Pale Reach) different fish in the game including aberrant variants. They're spread fairly even across the different zones. [i]The following was fixed in [u]Update 1.1[/u]! They doubled the abberation chance for trawl-only species.[/i] [strike]Only two of these fish are annoying to track down, since they're trawling-net-only aberrants which essentially leaves them up to random chance.[/strike]

[b]Horror[/b] - The game is a fishing game first, and horror game second. A few parallels I could draw are Sunless Sea, Subnautica, and Darkest Dungeon. It's the type of horror that's a result of worldbuilding and suspense than anything else, and I love that.

[b]Accessibility[/b] - [u]Update 1.2[/u] added Passive Mode, for any faint-hearted players out there. It also added the ability to turn off the effects while using [spoiler]Haste[/spoiler] which was much appreciated.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[b]Story[/b] - It's pretty bare-bones and straightforward. I did enjoy [spoiler]the twist towards the end of the game[/spoiler] and I think they did a very good job leading up to it. However, I still think it does a good enough job getting you interested and wanting to learn more.

[b]Playtime[/b] - It took me 15 hours to 100% achievement the game. This might be too short for some people. For me it's "just enough" as I said before. I ended up playing through it again with all the tips and tricks I picked up the first time around. Total playtime for two 100% playthroughs was 28.8 hours. Second time wasn't much faster, but I completed the four (previously) missable quests without failing some of them the second time around.

[b]Upgrades[/b] - The way you upgrade your boat is pretty linear. I don't mind that so much, but I wish it was a little more customizable once you got an upgrade. I know the boat is set up the way it is so the TETRIS-style inventory isn't too easy, but it would be nice to have a little more choice over where things go.

[b]Achievements[/b] - Game doesn't require multiple playthroughs to get all achievements, even though [spoiler]there are two different possible endings. The game warns you that from a certain point your progress isn't saved, so you can go back and do the other one.[/spoiler]

[b]Camera Mode[/b] - [u]Update 1.2[/u] added the Photographer with a small quest to unlock photo mode. Personally not for me, but I know that a lot of other people would probably appreciate the feature. Likely best used with the Passive Mode previously mentioned.

[b]Cosmetics[/b] - [u]Update 1.3[/u] added the Painter with boat customization! There's now the option to change the color of your roof and your hull independently of each other, as well as add a flag or bunting. There's 8 possible paint colors, and 8 flags (including no flag).

[hr][/hr]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
[b]Map Markers[/b] - They added map markers in [u]Update 1.1[/u]. They're okay, and nice in a pinch, but they lack customization. Can't name them, so you still need to remember what they were for. Best used for a few things, instead of charting the whole map. In my opinion the icon on the map for them is also too huge to be usable. They're like, 10x the size of the crab pot marker. Bonus QoL is that you can see them using the telescope, I guess.

[b]Quests[/b] - [i]This was fixed in [u]Update 1.1[/u]! Timers for these quests were removed.[/i] [strike]There's four missable quests. Even though the rewards for them are minimal, it surprised me because of how well done the other quests and rewards were. They encouraged exploration, and didn't have time constraints.[/strike]

[b]Research Parts[/b] - [i]This was fixed in [u]Update 1.1[/u]! Merchant now always stocks one research part every day, with a 50% chance to stock two.[/i] [strike]By the time I reached endgame I was a little research-part starved (about 10-12 short). I know I said you can get all achievements easily on one save file, but the ones for completing each upgrade tree might be better split across multiple playthroughs. Even now that I've beaten the game, I don't really understand what prompts the wandering trader to restock the ones she sells.[/strike]

At it's core, Dredge is a fishing simulator: you go out on the ocean, sail up on a school of fish and start fishing. Different fish have different QTE minigames to speed up catching a fish. This is important because the Dredge is also a horror game. Not super scary or anything, just a lightly dreary atmosphere with the occasional monster showing up when you get too panicked (this usually only happens at night). The closest thing to a jumpscare is not paying attention at night and suddenly something is on top of you. There is some variations to this formula, but they all follow some pattern. Learn the pattern to avoid issue. Rest up at a dock (any dock, monsters are all playing a game of tag and every dock is base, apparently) and the panic goes away.

Different locales require different rods and nets, but offer different fish as well. Don't sleep on crab pots like I did, they're passive money and the painter takes rare crabs and makes new paint for customizing the boat.

There are a few secret spots in the game with varying sidequests. Nothing too hidden, but not in plain sight either. The rewards vary from good to... kind of okay? I mean every reward has an upside that makes the sidequest worth doing, but some rewards feel outclassed if you don't find them right away.

Overall, it's a pleasant experience for a horror game. If you ever wanted a fishing game with some Lovecraftian horror mixed in, then Dredge is a perfect fit for you.

A fantastic and relaxing indie game focused on fishing, and sprinkled with Lovecraft elements.

You ever just felt entirely alone? Have you ever been alone at sea? What about alone at sea and anything can get you from the depths and the darkness of the night? Is the fish really worth it at that point?

This game is phenomenal in its style and simplicity of its game play. The various character you interact with and the rich story will keep you wanting more and to continue to risk your life for just one more fish. One more fish. One more... Aberration. Don't want to stay out for too long though as you are risking something happening to you that you'll lose your cargo, let alone usable space. Every little bit of your ship needs to be carefully organized and managed as you don't have infinite storage. However each part of your ship can be upgraded to better suit your needs. Need more space? Get rid of your lights. Not going for a certain fish too? Get rid of your extra rods. Just make sure you keep some sort of engine.

For a horror game, this is incredibly relaxing and will have you coming for more and more. Sure its story is not 40 hours long, but the game play loop is very satisfying. I couldn't recommend this game enough. If you were on the fence of about buying this game, you won't regret it if you do.

This is one of the few games I 100% completed and wished I had more to do. The gameplay is addicting, the style is wonderful, and the story line has a wonderful twist that kept me engaged the whole time. The opening hours are nerve-wracking, as you explore the dangers of the unknown and grapple with the eldritch horrors waiting for you in the deep. This opening section of the game is one of my gaming highlights for 2023, but even after the danger fades away, the gameplay remains richly rewarding, morphing into a relaxing fishing game with occasional scares. I cannot recommend this enough, especially if you own a Steam Deck.

I will say as you learn more about the mechanics of the enemies the intrigue is lost a bit, a big fish is less scary when you know exactly how it works. I'd say moving forward keep a level of random to it.

DREDGE is a really good game, especially for fans of Lovecraft. When I bought it, I knew it contained references. But the game even exceeded my expectations. Combining fishing and Lovecraft is a very cool idea üé£

It has fairly simple gameplay with main and side quests and a plot twist at the end. Besides that, it's also a relaxing game: you can just chill out on the waves and fish while exploring the ocean. However, you will be safe almost nowhere in the game world: the ocean is limitless and very beautiful, but dangerous. Nightmares and whispers of the abyss that drive the fisherman crazy, frighten and fascinate. But at dawn there is always wonderful calm music. My favorite place is Star Bay: mysterious light, bright jellyfish, coral atolls and a not-mad scientist in the middle of it ü™º

Cons: 

1. After 10-15 hours of gameplay, fishing gets boring. When you've completely upgraded your boat, fishing stops making sense at all. Only those who want to get all the achievements (like me, haha) need to continue this.

2. No chapters. The game has two endings. To get both, you need to make a save, otherwise you will have to start over. I forgot about it and will start from scratch üòû

DREDGE is worthy 9/10. I'm surprised how much the developers packed into such a small game.
I save this game for when I travel, and it plays great on Steam Deck.

A genuine hit that had me hooked (pun intended) from start to finish. A combination of cool mini-games, tense moments, and a story constantly leaving you with more questions than answers. With my fear of the ocean I was truly losing my sanity, but also having the time of my life maintaining my ship, selling my cargo, and completing quests.
Nice and chill fishing game, although I do wish there was more eldritch happenings.
Both relaxing and terrifying. Great on Steam Deck

Dredge made me feel immersed in a game for the first time in Years. The atmosphere, music and unique graphic style is amazing and complement each other very well. The lovecraftian theme combined with my fear of open water makes into a sometimes nauseating experience.

The devs have really put a lot of work into both the game and the community, and they've done a great job so far.

A lovely little casual fishing sim with a dollop of Lovecraftian horror on top. The game loop is satisfying and the story and puzzles are doled out quickly enough to keep things fresh through the finale. The grind is pleasantly mild such that the game doesn't feel like a chore, and the scares are just spooky enough to be fun. Atmosphere is top notch and I loved every minute of it.

Dredge is a really fantastic game. It's kind of short in that I was able to 100% the game in 21 hours, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. Every moment of the game was enjoyable and even at full price I would buy this game again. I've bought it for friends. Its a really beautiful game that manages to nail the vibes it's aiming at. 

The fishing mechanic is unique from other fishing mechanics I'm familiar with, but really easy to grasp. The real joy though comes from the world and story
A stylish fishing mystery game with bits of exploration and ship customization to enjoy. Inventory management can be a bit of a pain, but upgrades help. Highly recommend.

This game is captivating and eerily beautiful. The story is rich and rewarding, feeding into the game play loop. With a game that includes somewhat optional collection, it never feels tiresome or mundane to keep fishing until you catch what you're looking for... or until what you're looking for catches you. A seamless transition between a POV of a local fisherman selling fish to his mysterious community to a cosmic horror. Give the game a try for an artistic Lovecraftian experience.
