A simple fishing trip really. After a few beers you lose track of time and find yourself out way past what you planned, and the sun is going to set before you make it back to port.

Not to worry, you know the waters around the island like the back of your hand. It's right around this corner....oh. Guess not. Oh well, must be close now.

It's been hours. These shores don't even look familiar anymore. The fish are following the boat now, have been for hours. I can see their blank eyes staring at me. Why are there so many? Aren't they afraid of the motor?

The sun should've come up by now. I don't understand. But I saw a boat's lamp around the next outcrop, They'll point me in the right direction.

Dredge is one of those games that you don't want to end, i know i didn't, having 100% the game i can say with confidence dredge is worth your time and money, while it is admittedly short (around 12 hrs to complete the story on average, 6-8 hours if speeding through) the gameplay backs it up 100% as i often found myself just fishing random fish attempting to fill up my journal with new species or sailing around searching for islands with secret wrecks or hidden messages i was always having a good time. The story may be short but it is extremely high quality being captivating and intriguing as you discover the mysteries behind the eldritch creatures inhabiting the deep of this archipelago. If you are considering picking up dredge i wholeheartedly encourage you to give the game a go, who knows you might just fall in love as i did

I was very excited to jump into this and reacquire my 100% achievement status (and complete my encyclopedia again just for fun)! I had been counting down the days to the release of this game ever since I played the demo here back in November 2022. After pre-purchasing the deluxe edition on every console I have (digital on pc and switch, and physical for xbox) as soon as it was available, and doing everything I possibly could in the switch demo‚ÄîI am SO excited to finally have my hands on this game and play the full release!!

To say it has lived up to my excitement would be an understatement. In the same year that a new Legend of Zelda game releases, DREDGE was one of my most anticipated games right along side it. The atmosphere, gameplay, sound design‚Äîevery single aspect of this game has been crafted with care and passion and it is so fun to partake in! The game is just what it says on the packet- a fishing simulator with some inventory management, and an eldritch horror vibe overall. Unsettling, but not enough to be off-putting. So far the DLC has been good and non-invasive, with a little bit of something for all kinds of players, It scratches an itch if you're into this sort of game.

To be honest, I am quite impressed. I was not expecting to have this much fun with this game! Dredge has a lot of things that more devs should be doing like granting access and the possibility to upgrade everything that you have BEFORE you finish the game. Not like certain games where you get the final gear after you beat it.
Also, with the new update you can activate passive mode so you simply can enjoy just fishing!
There are a few things that could be better like more fishing spots out in  the ocean, so it doens't look that dead, but in the end, the game is just incredible! 9 fish out of 10.

Edit: The Pale Reach is pretty nice!

[h2] 100% recommend this game! [/h2]
I am a big fan of cosmic horror but find that a lot of games, who try to incorporate it, do it very poorly.
Dredge however does an amazing job with it. The story is so good and the pacing is not too slow nor too fast, perfect balance in my opinion.
It really makes you question whether [i] you really heard that noise or if this detail has always been there, was that shadow just a glitch or actually something else? [/i]

Everything in this game seems to be connected and has meaning - if that is your taste, then make yourself some tea, dim the lights and enjoy your fishing adventure in Dredge.

Team 17 really put in the work and lots of love alongside of it. [b] I am absolutely in love with this game! [/b]

Great short indie game, great mechanics and great story telling and immersive effects, the story itself was short, but not short where you were longing for more. The horror type atmosphere developed with the game gave a great and unique aspect to the story telling. If you are looking for a short play, feel free to try it out yourself (Mid ending though, could have shown a bit more, but that's just a personal opinion). Also Plus lovely addition of a new DLC.

[h1]Dredge is something different.[/h1]

[i]Take your boat.
Explore the world.
Fish in a relaxed way.
Follow the story.[/i]

The game covers many aspects for relaxed gameplay. It contains a pleasant little story, many puzzles and short challenges. Achievement-grinders will also get their money's worth.

I definitely had a nice time with the game.
Thanks to the developers.

This game is very addictive and laced with incredibly creepy vibes. Especially after long hours out on the open seas, the ships that may NOT be ships, that deep roaring deep in the depths and that interesting island...the one that always seems to get farther away, then vanish entirely. 

If you're looking for a case of sea madness, pick this game up. That Overwhelming Positive rating is one that has been well and honestly earned by this game.

Fun and simple game. It takes a little to get used to the gameplay loop(storing fish and performing upgrades), but it's enjoyable until the end - never wearing out its welcome. There is a good amount of fish variety in each region, and none are particularly difficult to catch or find. The narrative is pretty light and ends abruptly, things were just beginning to get interesting. The engine upgrades feel great, but it's pretty difficult to see the effects of the fishing speed upgrades, they all seems to go the same pace. 

At the end of the game, in the fourth region, they ask you to navigate tight spaces, and with the higher speed engines this becomes unwieldy and a bit annoying. 

Overall, the game is a nice relaxing time. It's never that scary, but the foggy nights and creatures create a nice horror atmosphere. I wish they created an end game. :)

GOTY 2023, impressed with how it never felt like a grind even though it's pretty much just fishing fetch quests. Amazingly strong gameplay loop, only complaint is the lack of warning on the time constraint of the hooded figure quests, would've appreciated a heads up. Took 12.5 hours to 100% easily worth the money, very few games have been as enjoyable as this one. Replayability is possibly there, as some equipment items I found toward the end (shrines) could've been attained earlier and possibly used for some kind of speed running. I hope eventually they release some kind of expansion i'd gladly pay $20-$30 for another map with its own fish and quests (although not sure how it would fit into the story). If modding support is added I could easily play this game for 100s of hours.

EDIT: End of the year and I still agree, nothing has come out that has felt quite like this game, I love it entirely. The devs are great and keep releasing content (that I end up completing hours after release but oh well) and that bodes well for this games future. I can't wait to see more!

A fairly unique take on a fishing game, though I'd describe it more as a time/resource/threat management game based around about 3-4 fishing mini-games that are more or less skill checks/QTEs. A lot of it is managing your inventory while under the threat of various monsters, as well as time management so you can avoid being out in the night where most things that want to drag you down to the depths will be. Of course there are various fish that can only be caught in the night, so at some point you will have to take that plunge. And naturally there are still threats present even during the day in most major areas which is part of the threat management; "do I have time to fish/dredge here before the big monster comes to take a bite?" and "I gotta sort this shit quick or the big monster is definitely gonna take a bite out of me."

A major part of the game is the atmosphere. If you aren't the type to be immersed and focus solely on the gameplay Dredge ironically might not be deep enough for you. Boiling it down to its base a lot of the game just ends up being fetch quests to improve your boat and fishing equipment to become better at fetch quests. While it is by no means a walking simulator, there are clear threats and failure states, most of the game is "go to place to get something and bring it somewhere else." You are at best able to temporarily drive away the monsters, you won't be defeating anything. So actually getting invested in the world, talking to and learning about its characters, reading descriptions of the grotesque mutations taking place, finding bottles and monoliths to find out what is happening and may potentially happen in the future, is fairly important to your enjoyment. If you engage with the setting you'll find it drags you in really well with its various little touches.

Dredge is a quick (20hrs~) but rich experience.

The atmosphere is unique, the feeling of loneliness in the open sea is extremely original, the soundtrack is well-thought and is the kind of soundtrack that will give you that feeling of warmth when you're facing an atmosphere that truly needs a bit of it.

The scenario is not the most original you'll discover in your life, but it's still good enough with some tiny twists that deserve to be discovered. The few characters you'll meet in your adventure all have just enough charisma for you to remember them. Not much, but that's not what we ask of the game in the first place. Like in any good Lovecraftian story, the environment is as important as those who live in it.

The real essence of the game truly is its gameplay. You're playing a lovecraftian fishing game and you're enjoying it because it's, to me, exactly what you would love around a real fishing experience. This atmosphere, the discovery, the calmness, the thrill. Plus, you can drift with the boat.

One of my favorite indie titles.  Beautiful combination of Lovecraftian horror elements and a cozy fishing sim.  The story is great and the background lore is always very interesting to read.  Out of any game to capture the psychological dread and cosmic horror of Lovecraft's works, this fishing game somehow does it the best.  And the game itself doesn't draw out any of the mechanics to the point of being boring or frustrating.  They take the "moving a boat around and fishing" aspect to every level it needs to go, and never too far beyond what it should be.

The Blackstone Key DLC is unnecessary and is mostly just a way to give the studio some extra cash.

Pale Reach is a little disappointing with the amount of content it adds, and I feel the story of it is a little lackluster compared to the main game.

I have never liked fishing in games or real life for that matter. Luckily DREDGE, a game about fishing, has very little to do with actual fishing funnily enough. DREDGE plays more like an ocean adventure game with survival horror elements. You traverse an open sea in hunt of rare fish and other goods, but are very vulnerable to the many horrors that lie below the sea. The game is casual and easy to get into, yet oddly still frighteningly oppressive in tone.

You can reduce the danger a bit as the game always gives you goals and upgrades to work towards, but you're never truly safe. DREDGE really likes to mess with temptation. There's always an incentive to push yourself harder or play riskier, but the game's atmosphere and your vulnerabilities always remind you of how bad things can wind up. Add in some light Lovecraftian story telling and DREDGE's horror and wonders are simple, but very effectively done.

This game deserves all the praise. It has stunning visuals paired with fantastic audio design. The story is so well put together and told through the environment and characters where you can discover it at your own pace

Dredge is an interesting twist on the Lovecraftian theme in that you're the one who has to go out to sea and actually encounter the eldritch abominations in their territory. Facing off against, or more realistically hiding from, the horrors of the depths can get quite tense, as you need to pay close attention to your fishing and dredging while hoping you don't draw the ire of the various monsters of the sea.

Or you could turn off the monsters in the settings and play a pretty chill and fun fishing game. Your choice.

I love fishing in video games. When a game has a fishing mini-game I am all about it! This game is great as it has multiple fishing mechanics and a decent story. Upgrades to your boat feel impactful, and the boat controls very well while still definitely controlling like a boat. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
-Multiple fishing minigames based on types of fish.
-Multiple passive incomes by using crab buckets or trawling
-Good size map to explore with fun and often useful discoveries
-Upgrades to the ship make a huge difference to where I was excited to get them
-Player upgrades unlocked through story
-Music is atmospheric
-NPCs have a good feel with a variety of knowledge of the unknown
-Fishing

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
-It is a bit short
-I would have liked more upgrades, but really I wanted more game.
-Most achievments are hidden, and I had to look them up as I would not have gotten some of them organically

[h1]DLC Pros:[/h1]
The Blackstone Key 
-provides 2 early game boat pieces to make your start faster
The Pale Reach 
-Provides a whole new area to explore, basically a 6th level for the mid game
-Provides more fish
-Provides another mystery
-It has an excellent Item that will provide convenience all the way to late game
-Really enjoyed this story

[h1]DLC Cons:[/h1]
The Blackstone Key
-I bought this after completing the main game. It provided almost no utility. 
-People defend this DLC as providing a tip to the devs, While the devs deserve more money for this excellent game, this still feels like it is barely an update, and that defense is very indicative of its value.
The Pale Reach
-No complaints


[h1]My Level of Experience with the game[/h1]
I took about 15 hours to beat the main game and then another 2 hours to fill out my fishing logs. I didn't go for 100% till the DLC came out. Played both DLCs after completion of base game. Blackstone Key was a 1 minute interaction, Pale Reach took about 2 hours. I absolutely love this game and would buy more DLC like Pale reach or Dredge 2 in a heart beat. I had to look up hidden achievements to get all of them.

[h1]Lovecraftian Horror + Fishing[/h1]

Let me start by saying this, [b]this game is not for everyone[/b] but for my time playing it I could not put my mouse and keyboard down. From start to finish this game had me hooked, from the atmospheric world to the music. It presents itself as simple fishing game, where you the player character explores the sea and completing your journal of fish entries and helping out others in need. Bringing me a sense of calm and serenity as I navigate the ocean.

Where the game really got me was the horror elements that were involved, while not necessarily scary at all times it provides you with a subtle sense of dread and weariness. This game reignited a fear I have always had which is the fear of the unknown.

Imagine this, you are boating at night looking for some fish that only come out then and you enter a weird red mist and pass on through like nothing happened but then the music begins to become more creepy and eerie, heightening your senses. You see the lights of another ship in the distance and think to say hello to a fellow sailor, you approach the boat and see a huge [spoiler]ANGLER FISH DISGUISING ITSELF AS A BOAT forcing you to flee in terror[/spoiler]. Waking up in Greater Marrow to do it all again.

A slight criticism of mine would have to be the lack of engagements with the enemies of the game. I would have liked some harpoon system that allowed the player to fight some enemies on the sea itself instead of just banishing them. Collecting their carcasses as a side quest to have as trophies on the ship perhaps. This doesn't bring the game down for me but I think it would have been a welcome addition.

What Black Salt Games accomplished with this title is superb and I look forward to their next outing in the indie game world. I have 100% the achievements and will happily do another playthrough in the future.

A tranquil title about fishing, conservation, and finance management. The biggest threat in the game is the fog that rolls in during the night, making navigation difficult. You meet a variety of characters, from sodden old men to sodden old men with hats. The main mechanic, fishing, is comprised of various little timing-based minigames, which prove challenging to those with poor reaction time. Your boat, of course, can be customized and improved, even allowing for you to hang pirate flags from it. Just be sure to avoid the whales, if they brush by you they [i]will[/i] scrape up your boat.

The lovecraftian fishing game!?

As a massive fan of lovecrafts stories I am allways looking for a game that truly captures what his horror style is all about.
Games like "Call of Cthulhu" or "The Sinking City" were promising, but fell flat in the end.

Enter "Dredge".
 I am amazed how this game pulled off everything lovecraftian horror is all about. A sense of wonder. Curiosity. Things we are unable to comprehend. It manages to capture everything masterfully. It is clear to me that the developers are not only fans of lovecrafts works, but understand it.

The story is told in a way that just keeps pushing me forward. It managed to keep me hooked from beginning to end. I was even more surprised when I learned, that there are multiple ending. And both of them are, again, incredibly lovecraftian.
I am currently on my 2nd playthrough and it is well worth your time, because you will pick up on clues that you did not catch during your first time playing.

The gameplay loop is incredibly simple. Go out fishing, sell the fish, upgrade your ship and get back out there. At first it seemed like nothing special, but it is very addicting. Pretty much every time I play the game, the feeling of "just one more fishing trip" is allways present. Often preventing me from turning off the game.

The music and sounddesign is superb. From cozy and relaxing tracks, to adventures tunes and scores that will make you feel uneasy, everything is there. 

I had/still have an absolute blast playing "Dredge". This is easily the 2nd best lovecraftian horror game I have ever played. It is second only to Bloodborne and that says a lot. 
Still, I have to mention, this is not a horror-game in the traditional sense. You will not find any jumpscares or classic horror elements like demons, murderers or something along those lines. All the tension and unease is created by atmosphere alone. If that is not your cup of tea, I do not recommend this game to you.
For everyone else, pick it up and give it a try. You might be surprised what you can find.
This game deserves all the praise it has gotten. 
I will follow Black Salt Games future releases with great interest. And ofcourse I am allways looking forward to more "Dredge" content.

Final Score for "Dredge" is the strongest 9/10 I can give. I only wish the main story was ever so slightly longer.

A decent descent into madness. A perfect gateway for someone's first dive into Lovecraftian horror tied up in an adorable bow. You go out into the world, fish for critters and treasure, sometimes pulling up more than you've been hunting for and scoot from island cluster to island cluster. Each with a biome, and terror special to it. The game is gorgeous and knows how to set a scene. The depth of the game is a little lacking as I found myself wanting more out of timing mini games and fetch quests but the game loop of profit and upgrade had me hooked, and the story albeit, predictable was still a worthwhile time. Far from my GOTY but still a worthy get from the depths.

A fishing game with really enjoyable fishing mechanics, material dredging mechanics, and a fun world to explore. Catching all the fish types (including the abberations) can feel really satisfying if you're a "collect them all" kind of Gamer‚Ñ¢.

 The Lovecraftian essence of the game is simultaneously alongside the fishing and boat mechanics, but also doesn't feel like the main draw of the game. And I'm not saying this as a bad thing! I had a good time with the game, and a fun time interacting with the various Lovecraftian mechanics, story, monsters, and NPCs. But this is a "horror light" version of that style, with scary moments and nighttime that can be stressful and scary, but there is not an "oppressive atmosphere" of Lovecraftian horror that pervades the whole game.

They also dropped a DLC recently, and is supposed to be "the first" one, so there's more stuff coming! I haven't played the DLC yet so I can't comment on it at all tho.

This game scratches a VERY particular itch, and I love just about everything it has to offer. The visuals of this world are beautiful (yes, even the horrors, SPECIALLY the horrors), the sound design is amazing, The OST is very moody and melancholic, and it very gradually turns the player into a lovecraftian-esk protagonist doing increasingly dangerous things just to learn more about what's going on.

I'd highly recommend getting the full bundle if anything I wrote sounds like your cup of tea.
A lovely fishing game with a beautiful art style and aesthetic that welcomes you to get lost in its world. But watch out.

I wish steam had a ranking system rather than a Positive or negative review because its tough. TLDR: Its a game to buy on a sale. Its a good game, good starting point for a new IP but that's about it. 

Longer reasons:

1) Price - I can't describe my review the best way I can unless I start with its price and comparing it to another phenomenal game. Based on the content of this game it was priced way too high for me. In my local currency PHP, this game is at 900 pesos and I believe it should be sold at around 500 at best. I guess I'm just too salty on buying this game at this price and had high expectations that it failed to deliver. For me pricing it at that high I would have loved to see more depth in the game. More on point 2

2) Content - Its a repetitive game with a gimmick. I loved the first few hours of this game with the hidden dangers, the whole buy and sell, upgrades etc. Again I don't mind it, because I thought there was something deeper to it. Honestly I would've love that I would have become mayor in some of the towns, try to improve the cities, build ships, try to create trade routes, MAYBE even battle the horrors. But it all ended there. Its the same thing one after the other. Each town having its own gimmick and that's it. No deeper evolution to the fishing mechanic etc. Side quests are all pathetic, essentially fetch quests that aren't even far from each other, like it was just tacked on to check a box. 

Also the thrill of the chase part will wear off when you've upgraded and this is a sign of a bad mechanic.

3) Comparison to another fishing game - Dave the diver. I bought Dave the diver roughly for the price and the content of that game quadruples what Dredge has. Sure it had the buy and sell thing. No problem but it had a compelling story to tell. Sure it had different sections which are all gimmicky, but each section had its own unique charm. It had better side quests with some of them unlocking another piece of the game. It had a lot of other game mechanics to fill up the time. 

In the end that's what i felt about the game. I felt that it was overpriced and there's a better alternative. I would recommend it if it was sold for 50% or even 75% of its original price. 

Improvements (?):
1) add more to the gameplay - Maybe add like an option for First person, imagine having to walk around your deck and exploring underwater parts in this universe. I know it'd be like subnautica but at least its added gameplay. Imagine diving and opening treasure boxes, or imagine brinigng up a plank to fit a broken part of the ship, and you have to find the exact shape or you have the option to cut the shape into what's needed. Something like that. something to give more depth into the despair and the dread of the game. 

Imagine like your sailing your boat for hours then when you look at your map, you BARELY moved or you DIDNT move at all from your original position.then you find out a monster is doing this and in order for you to finally get away from it is to swim down and blind its eye or something. or since this is a lovecraftian inspired game. Maybe do a ritual or drink some drug to free you from its influence.

Something more than just sail away.

I've been playing indie game a lot lately but i have to say that this is absolutely my favorite, It's very simple in idea, it's just fishing. The thing is that even though it's just fishing it feels like it's much more. Take for example that there are several ways to fish along with the feeling of tetras when you go to put items in your ship. I love discovering all the different fish and the alterations to them especially in the new DLC with things like the goblin shark.

Fun game with interesting concepts and an engaging enough story to make you wanna see the end, really short though, and pretty easy, you can quickly get bored as although there are tons of different fish to catch in the game, the act of catching the fish is really simple and gets pretty repetitive rather fast.
great atmosphere of dread and the unknown and oddly calming then turns to very tense suddenly but never for long and then it's back to fishing in lovely weather
This game has infected my brain, and I hope you let it infect yours too. 11/10
gone fishin
If you keep making more content, I'll keep buying it.

It might take a little time to figure out all of the mechanics, but the game doesn't penalize you for keeping things simple. There are plenty of upgrades to take you from the slow, cramped dinghy you start with to a speedy, spacious, ocean-faring vessel: it's fun to start over and realize just how far you will ultimately go. You can take your time exploring and uncovering lore, or you can race through the game itself -- both routes are fun and rewarding. The game has solid replay value and can be tackled in as little as 15 minutes at time.
I love this craft, would recommend.

A pretty good addition to the game. Having played it on an endgame save with a fully upgraded ship, it was a complete breeze. Clearly intended for midgame for difficulty, a bit odd for a DLC made so far after release.

The monster that chases you in this region isn't really that scary, it lacks the eldritch creepiness that, say, the gale cliffs one has and seems oddly out of place to me in this world's idea of creepy monsters. I feel like it should've been a mutated giant squid, or an Orca with a massive set of creepy eyes or something. The area and the monster there feel very vanilla and kinda empty to me. The only exception being the 'middle' of the icy peninsula where something lurks but there's no real danger with that thing.

While this DLC is fun and the price tag is mostly fair, I can't help but feel the devs were... uninspired? Not massively motivated? It's hard to explain. The island fits in perfectly with the other ones in terms of the amount of fish you can find there (about 11 excluding aberrations which is more than some of the original island's fish counts)  but it really does just feel like that, another island. It has 3 NPCs, two being re-used from previous content and the one new one is the same art for 4 different guys. It does add 'Ice blocks' which can help your fish last but once you've already finished the game there's little use for it.

The only exception to that feeling of 'vanilla / emptiness' I mentioned is the lurking thing stuck in the middle of the island, it looks great and is just as eldritch and creepy as I would want, but it doesn't really do anything and quickly loses that creepiness once you've met it once since you realise it is simply trapped and not much of it is visible. I also enjoyed the story of this creature found in the humming stones dotted around the island but it really is only a few sentences of backstory though it is meant to be a mystery I suppose.

Anyway, rambling aside, here's my summary:

The DLC is pretty good. The new region is somewhat interesting and the eldritch thing in the middle is cool but it really does just feel like more of the same. There's no real world changing story here, the monster doesn't do anything particularly new or change how you play. The region is more like a side quest / side content meant purely to supplement the original game. 
I would recommend this DLC if you plan to play the game for the first time which feels wrong to say for a DLC (This isn't a paradox interactive game, after all) or plan to play through again to 100% the game. If you've already played and finished the game before and don't want to play through the game again; I would say decide whether you actually want to get this DLC as it doesn't really have that sense of dread and unease that some of the main content has, gale cliffs is still my favourite part of the game and this icy isle simply doesn't compare too well against it for a first visit.
Simple and fun.  Great for a solid ten hours without DLC

If you take it at face value it looks like a normal fishing game about sailing the sea and catching what ever bites your hook. But let me tell you it is anything but, the pace of the progression system nice and makes sure that you get one thing have your fun with it and once you're ready for something new it's ready for you to use. 

The kinda hidden story/lore is also amazing if you start to dig into it and the ending to the base game story had me on the edge of my seat and still managed to throw a twist. The pale reach DLC adds some really interesting stuff to explore and find. at the time of posting this review I have yet to do more digging into the DLC story. 

Over all its a solid 10/10 and I heavily recommend this game to anyone looking to have a relaxed experience playing or if you like looking for hidden puzzle pieces to put the story together.

[b]My Score:[/b] 9/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
Deep sea fishing, such a relaxing activity with the warmth of the sun, the smells and sounds of the sea, while waiting for a fish to bite the line. Unless you like the protagonist of our story, an old fisherman who, reading the newspaper, found an advertisement, from an archipelago formed by five isolated islands in the world, in search of a fisherman. Soon, he took his equipment and boat and left for the islands, only to receive the "Welcome", in the form of an ominous and thick fog that appears from nowhere, which makes him not notice a group of stones near the only lighthouse of the islands, ending up sinking his boat. ^^

Fortunately our protagonist survives, but now he has to start over from scratch, with a small and old boat that was available in the port, with old equipment that still works. All he need to start fishing and get money and materials to improve the boat to be able to go further, visit the other islands of the archipelago, to catch the various species of fish unique to each island, as well as doing jobs in exchange for money. But always have to be careful, because something that is not of this world lives and swims through the dark waters of the ocean, and this thing loves not only to modify the fish in sinister ways, but also to go out, especially at night, in search of the next meal. ^^

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ A game that made a combination that I found very interesting and fun, mixing fishing with supernatural mystery.
+ The fishing part I found very relaxing and pleasant, navigating in search of places where to catch each of the seventy-eight species of fish and crabs, with all of them with at least one anomalous version, totally "natural".
+ Each of the archipelago's islands is quite unique, not only in appearance, climate and terrain, but also in the species that can be fished, as well as in the surprises.
+ Each of the islands has its own "nice" surprise, which won't miss any chance to try to dine the player, with boat and all.
+ A curious time system that I liked, where time only passes when the boat moves or fishing, but beware that those who want to dinner the protagonist are not affected by this.
+ I liked the art of the game, it matched the mood that there is something, unnatural swimming in the waters.
+ Good soundtrack, relaxing in moments of tranquility, and tense, when the fisherman becomes the fishing.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- It is always unpleasant, when of all the places that can be reached when the boat takes damage, the damage is exactly in one of the parts of the engine or fishing equipment.

[h1] Game mechanics[/h1]
This is how a new life begins in this small, sinister and isolated from the rest of the world archipelago, going out to fish for the various species of fish, including some specimens with totally "natural" anomalies without "anything" sinister, each of them living on an specific island and depth, requiring the appropriate equipment. Once caught, the fish can be sold, to get money, buy improvements and go to the farthest islands, and find new people who will not only tell you more about the sinister history of this archipelago, but also provide missions, in exchange for money, equipment and other interesting things. ^^

The problem is that all this is best done during the day, because even though it is possible to sail at night and some of the fish can only be found at night, it's not just the protagonist's boat and some nocturnal fish sailing over the darkness of the night, but also sinister beings, some big enough to catch the protagonist like a fish, because they are big enough to make the boat look like a toy boat. It will be up to the player to decide what is worth more, the risk of sailing under the light of the moon or the riches that can only be found at night, after all, not all threats hunt only at night. ^^

[h1] Art and sound[/h1]
Produced by the New Zealand studio Black Salt Games, I liked the artistic part, combining in a way to show the beauty of each of the islands, and their various and diverse types of fish, as well as showing, mainly in the people and the "natural" anomalies of the fish, that there is something wrong and unnatural swimming in the waters between these islands. As for the soundtrack, I was also very satisfied, I liked the music used as well as the sound effects, and I also liked that in several moments they only use silence, while we listen to the relaxing sounds of the sea, while we explore the ocean and fishing for fish. ^^

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
Dredge was a game I'd had my eye on for some time, having played it since the first demo, when we could only explore one of the islands, being interested ever since. So I was pleased when the game was released and I saw that the wait was worth it, with much more to explore, discover and fishing, while enjoying the beauty of the islands and the creatures that swim through their waters, and running away from others. Anyway this is a game that I recommend so much for those who like fishing games, for those who like supernatural mysteries and who knows, for those who like both like me, while trying to discover the mysteries of the islands, at the same time trying to catch that fish that's still missing, or running away so as not to become something's dinner. ^^

Have thoroughly enjoyed this game just sailing around and fishing. Is a short game with a little story to it and some weird magic. The new DLC 'Pale Reach' added around 2 hours of game time to the base game's 20 odd hours.
Dredge is everything I want in a "cozy" sim game: gorgeous art, objectives to complete that don't require me to hoard and stockpile items, fish, and freaky monsters. I just wish there was more of it.

Very fun and enjoyable game!  Worth every penny!

Dredge wasn't particularly spooky (or even super Lovecraftian?), but it did have some moments. It succeeded far more in the charming and relaxing parts. Fishing is extremely simple but fun. Though the compositions were fine, I found the MIDI instrumentation in the music grating, which was the worst part of the game for me. I turned the music volume down super low and enjoyed the ambient noises far more. Overall, I think it may have been overhyped, but I enjoyed it enough to finish it and would recommend it on sale.

A phenomenal game that on the surface is centered around fishing, but slowly uncovers and reveals the darker side of the world that lurks beneath. Genuinely a super pleasant time, each area is terrifying at first and then much more relaxing as you get used to the nuances of their threats. I'd consider this game a perfect length for more casual players
fun, easy to get lost in, great story

This is one of the best, calming, relaxing, and also unsettling fishing games I've ever played. I love it to death, I keep coming back to do more fishing and fill up my Encyclopedia. The devs knew exactly the amount to tell the player, and the amount to just leave unsaid and its great.

10/10, this game is the perfect mix of cozy and horrifying wrapped into a fishing game. The story was intriguing and mysterious, and came together in the most satisfying way possible at the end. I only wish this game was longer and it's obvious the amount of love & hard work that went into its creation. Really hope we see more like this again in the future :)

Dredge is what a true indie game should be:
- original idea (it's a fishing game with mysteries)
- lovely graphics (just look at it!)
- interesting story (who are these people!)
- a lot of things to do (discovering islands, all sea species and... all the weird things)
- runs PERFECTLY on Steam Deck (don't be afraid to limit the power to achieve that sweet long battery life)

For me,  it is a Game of the Year. At the time of writing the review, the first DLC is about to be released and I can't wait. 51 minutes to go!

I love how it was made in New Zealand, so it truly puts NZ on the map for gaming.

The art, the gameplay, the story, the fish, and the fact it's loosely lovecraftian.

There's something in the water

Love the mostly peaceful, but at times spooky atmosphere. Feels like a kid's game with difficulty, but that can be refreshing for everyone.

I've cleared the game and done both endings - found myself just from exploring. I didn't do absolutely everything, but simply fishing and selling at the fish market is a satisfying loop with with sounds and slippery feel of the sea creatures.

Days are shockingly short - it seems like maybe 2-5 minutes long and then you'll go back to a dock to sell fish and upgrade as well as sleeping. Sometimes it was laughable how I would go an extremely short distance from the dock, fish 2 things and it would be night again! And in the early game, you almost have to go back constantly, because you're slow and have no defense.

Time only increases when you move, turn or fish, but jumps up a lot after a fishing action I think and will go forwards 2-6 hours roughly when installing a new piece of equipment.
Music is great especially when exploring, art style is nice and it's mostly peaceful, though the danger grows for night adventuring and is mostly an expensive annoyance, though you later unlock abilities to speed away or launch a kind of distraction flare.

The unlocks are fun, but there's not much to do after ~10-15 hours when you unlock everything - though the research points are hard to find, so it seems like you basically just 1 path of the upgrade tree to pursue. 

Only a few boss-like / patrol monsters of each area can kill you, but you respawn typically 5 minutes before. And venturing to map edge has a massive leviathan entity that will cause damage.
It's a good and relaxing game. If you like fishing and wanna relax playing with some mystery buy this game. Of course there is some cons about the game but they'll improve it next games!

[h2]Intriguing story with engaging and focused gameplay. Definitely worth the buy![/h2]

[h3]Pros:[/h3]
-good writing, not fatiguing even for a lazy reader ([spoiler]me[/spoiler])
-varied fishing minigames
-hands-on inventory management
-meaningful upgrades to work towards 
-basic yet motivating customization system

[h3]Cons:[/h3]
-money making is too easy and requires virtually no planning
-player is not pressured enough, almost infinite time
-too few dangers and generally too easy, no penalty for playing extremely safe
-story structure works, but ending is too abrupt and not quire rewarding enough (both endings)
-dredging minigame gets old [i]fast[/i] and doesn't change (even though it's in the goddamn title haha)

Genuinely a really fun game.  I love that if you wanted to, you can change the difficulty WHENEVER. ended up playing the name "normally" but then I wanted the achievements to catch all the fish, so I went into passive mode so I can fish more at night without fear.

I definitely felt misled by the hype for this game.  It feels very repetitive with a single simple game mechanic.  I know people are suckers for lovecraft adjacent stories, but I never felt attached to the main character at all.  It's good for 5-10 hours of gameplay.  In hindsight, I would been a lot happier if I got this during a big discount sale.

A fishing game meets HP Lovecraft is what Dredge attempts to be and quite frankly succeeds. During the day you set out on a normal fishing adventure while also uncovering clues to what has brought about the mysterious fog. The player travels across 5 different island areas separated by ocean with each having their own unique types of fish, equipment requirements and a number of not too overwhelming sidequests.

But when the sun sets, swirling clouds of red fog grip a hold of the player's ship causing panic and hallucinations. Shadows from the deep come alive and players are left scrambling for the safety of docks as evil chases them through the fog. Normal everyday fish you catch during the day turn into diseased and corrupted monstrosities, complete with errant fangs and protruding bones at night known as "aberrations" which catch a higher price at the fish markets dotted across the islands. All of this is to raise money to purchase upgraded equipment which is researched from the components of wrecked ships which the player dredges in a rush to get back to port before sunset.

Happy "fishing"!

So first of all, I want to preface this review by writing that, this game definitely is not for everyone.  It is a highly eclectic mix of:

Exploration
Fishing
Adventure (in the narrative-driven, puzzle-solving sense)
RPG (in the upgrade trees and equipment sense)
Inventory Management
Horror (more atmospheric than anything else)
Pokemon (in the gotta fish them all sense)

... genres, and yet somehow just works.  None of these genres are implemented deeply, but as a design decision, I think it was wise because you wrap up the game before anything gets stale (ha-ha).  Only potential drawback (for some, I think) is that it does not last very long.

Exploration-wise, you get access to 5 groups of islands, each with its own personality and perils.  Scattered about the ocean between them, you will find even more islands and secrets strewn all over.  The map seems pretty big at first, but becomes noticeably smaller once you upgrade your ship engines and can zip around.

Fishing and dredging are basically just rhythm mini games.  The fun part is trying to quickly get all the new fish to fit in your boat, before a peril smashes into it.  I wish I learned about RMB = Rotate even earlier.

Adventure-wise, this game has a fairly short story that becomes really obvious if you are talking to everyone, pay attention, and put the puzzle pieces together.  Still enjoyable though.

There are several RPG elements: An upgrade tree to your equipment, upgrade tree to your boat, and collectible books that grant permanent bonuses.  None are too deep, but enjoyable as-is.

The horrors are mostly just random atmospheric things that mainly come out at night.  Spooky the first time around, but you quickly get over it.

Finally, I very quickly gave up trying to catch all fish, as it doesn't appear to do anything except for a few achievements.

In total, you will spend around 15 hours exploring the islands while dredging, fishing, upgrading your stuff, and checking off quest objectives.  All the while taking in the atmosphere and pondering  just what the heck is going on.  To be honest, I think the length is just right -- in our current world of GaaS products that just want us to grind grind and grind some more until we all become numb, it's nice to see a much more focused experience.  By not going too deep into any one genre, everything still tastes fairly fresh by the time you finish.

tldr; Great game if you want a fun, focused experience brimming with personality.  Don't buy if you "value" a game by hours playable divided by asking price.

Its tough to leave a negative, the team that made this game did some fantastic work, but the storyline is super simple for a lovecraft inspired horror. It also leans heavy into fetch questing, and the horror aspect is there but its hard to suspend disbelief. I felt more like a fisherman that was dropping acid at night but knew he had another 5 hours before his shift was over. In other words, I didn't feel any existential dread and I was really let down when I found out that most choices don't seem to matter. It would of been interesting if the dev had more of a sliding scale of choice. Like there are a few items you get that should have buffs but be untainted, making you want to play "Clean" vs using the maw crab trap for example. Some of the positives of this game tho are that the boat upgrading is fun, fishing is okay, the madness at night is great ( but once again the rest of the game makes it feel detached ) and I did not have any glitches. If you like fetch quest games and collecting, 100% you should buy this, if your looking to have a psychological horror experience, were you are worried about the choices you'd made, eh not so much.

A game about fishing and exploration. 

Now the biggest negative about this game is the grind. When you first start off there is a tech tree to get through as well as a bunch of upgrades to purchase. Doing side missions helps alleviate this quite a lot and as you progress the main story you unlock abilities to help.

Now onto the positives we have the Tetris style inventory system. I personally love these while other people like a simple inventory with just weight management. 

Exploration is fantastic. The more I uncovered the more I wanted to see and know. Even while finishing the last sidequest I saw events like a whale fighting a giant tentacle that I didn‚Äôt even know was in the game. 

The game is rather short, about 12-13 hours to get both endings and do the side missions. This felt like a very lite version of Subnautica / Sunless Sea / Sunless Skies.

The story is pretty straightforward (if you get both endings) although some of the special fish the player catches do have lore attached to them. I also enjoy the use of a lot of real life fish in the game.

Music is ok. Atmospheric but nothing too catchy.

Great indie, looking forward to the DLC.

When I think about this game, I mostly think about its wasted potential. DREDGE sort of feels half-finished, like it should be an early-access game. This game [i]could[/i] be really, [i]really[/i] good and it's honestly astonishing that it's received mostly glowing reviews. The fishing is fairly fun for about two hours before it becomes repetitive busywork. The atmosphere is fairly fun until you realize the game isn't going to do anything interesting with it. I get scared easily ‚Äì I literally jump every time my toast is done in the morning ‚Äì and I don't remember being even mildly spooked. There's some mutated fish you can catch and sometimes a big fish will bump into your boat at night, and that's pretty much it. And if you think the plot or the side-quests are going anywhere, don't worry: they don't. The ending made me laugh irl with how absurd and random it felt. To make a long review short: DREDGE is... fine. It's okay. I can't say I recommend it though.

Embark on an addictive journey across the high seas! I personally loved upgrading my boat and immersing myself in its mysterious atmosphere. However, a few drawbacks caught my attention:

* DLC: While sounding like extra stories, only grants basic loot access without adding significant depth to the gameplay.
* Locked Achievements: Eight achievements remain locked, preventing players like myself from achieving 100% completion and leaving completionists like me wanting for more.
* Unbalanced Economy: The in-game economy starts with a challenging gear acquisition phase but quickly transitions into an unbalanced system, making you rich way too fast in later stages.

Despite these minor issues, the game's core mechanics and atmosphere make it a worthwhile adventure!

Rarely does one think of fishing when one thinks of Eldrich horror, yet Dredge features the unlikely duo. In a similar combination, Dredge also features horror elements whilst being a cozy and chill game. 

Your player character is a Fisherman and captain of a ship that winds up crashed in a mysterious archipelago. Your immediate goal is to pay off your debt incurred by your ship's repairs which you do by fishing around the archipelago. Fishing in this game is rhythm minigames with forgiving windows of opportunity. While your character fishes, you cash in the fish to buy boat upgrades to explore, go further and catch more fish and find more upgrades. It's a pleasant gameplay loop. 

But where's the horror? The horror starts sneaking its way in when you catch fish that look...not exactly you expect. Or when your sanity meter at the top of the screen starts to waver if you have gone long without sleeping and you start to see rocks suddenly appear to dash your ship upon in the midnight hours. Or when a Leviathan of the depths charges you, damaging your ship's hull. Here there be a few jumpscares.

Ok, fine. Horror elements, but how is this cozy? It may be difficult to truly explain but the minigames are strangely soothing and piloting your vessel along a vast ocean has this sense of calm, even if there are deep sea fangly beasts below. The cadence of the daily work routine of going out to fish, catching fish, selling them, improving your ship and resting when needed is strangely relaxing in a way I have not experienced outside another nautical game I adore, Spiritfarer. Granted, the sea monsters in those game genuinely wished to be your friend and not eat you as they do in Dredge, but my point stands. There is also a cozy mode to turn off the sea monsters of the depth if that is your pleasure. I did not, but can appreciate the option being available.

The artwork and atmosphere in this game is unparalleled and the uniqueness of the gameplay loop is a breath of fresh air. I can admit that one could power through the main path of this game in roughly 6 hours, but the calm experienced by just voyaging the ocean makes me believe few people will do that. I have spent double that time in my current file and I am still discovering new fish and quests.  While the nature of this game may not be to everyone's liking, it's my catch of the day.

Dredge was a game I randomly found on the store page, thanks to the discovery queue. I had never heard about this game anywhere else. I loved the artwork, from how the oceans looked to the sky, and the characters were pleasing to look at. The gameplay was pretty fun; I'm happy they spiced up the fishing mechanics with some of the fish, but I wish there were more mini-games. The music was great; it made me really feel like I was chugging along in the middle of the ocean. I caught myself not using a second monitor at all because I felt sucked into the game. Sadly, the biggest problem I have is the story. It felt right on pace when you're in the Marrow, but once the story has you leave, it gets into a very obvious loop of going to a new island, completing 2 or 3 missions for one person, and then getting the relic. On the next island, it felt very empty in a way, not the kino of lonely fisherman, but more like someone who shows up in town, and there's old Joe sitting on a rocking chair, and he is the whole town. You meet the same merchant lady at all places, so you only meet 1 or 2 new people on an island and have little dialogue with them. I wish there were more side quests that would open the world and expand the lore. Instead, you get to the end of a side quest, and it's like, 'Oh, that's it.' I liked the good ending. That being said, I did enjoy the game, especially at the discount I got it at. I will be picking up the Pale Reach to see how that goes."

I hate to give [i]Dredge[/i] a Not Recommended. It's a good game, fun and perfectly fine. Unfortunately, I can only give a [i]limited[/i] recommendation, and there's no option for that.

[b]If you want an easy, cosy fishing and exploration game, with a thin paint of Lovecraft, then [i]Dredge[/i] is perfect. If not, well...[/b]

[i]Dredge[/i] [b]is[/b] a good game. And it has all the right ingredients to be more than good. The gameplay mechanics are simple and fun, there's a satisfying amount of content, the art and UI are well polished. But it lacks [i]ambition[/i]. There's a decent variety of gameplay systems and mechanics, but eventually you realise they barely interact with each other, or change in any meaningful way as you progress through the game.

For example, the upgrade tree. It's reasonably extensive, and feels satisfying to unlock new content at first. But as you progress, you notice how little the new content actually changes anything. Almost no upgrades are required to reach new areas or content. By the time you're halfway through the tree, you barely have any motivation to unlock the rest.

Similarly, there's a kind of sanity / fear meter. It seems important and intimidating at first... and then you realise it barely has an impact on anything, and barely interacts with any other systems. The real threats in the game have nothing to do with sanity - they'll wreck you whether you're sane or not. No significant new mechanics are ever introduced. It's just there, and you quickly learn to ignore it.

There are plenty of other examples where the game sets up a promising looking system or quest, and you enjoy it for a while. But eventually there's that disappointment when it doesn't really go anywhere or try anything new. Fishing 15 minutes in is the same as fishing 15 hours in. There's an interesting setup for the plot, but almost no development after the setup. It's disappointing, mostly because it feels like [i]Dredge[/i] already has everything it needs to succeed. Just a few tweaks the systems, a few minor changes as you progress...

So, yeah. A good, fun game, that nevertheless left me feeling underwhelmed. By way of fishing analogy, [i]Dredge[/i] is like catching a reasonable haul, but letting the prize-winning fish slip through your fingers.

DREDGE is more of an atmospheric adventure game than a game about fishing. There are some neat set pieces in the game, but the mechanics rarely encourage you to play around in them. It also doesn't take long before the mechanics get a bit stale. That said, the game's strong suite is in its relatively minimalistic narrative expressed through the game's eerie atmosphere and tone. Overall, I think I would have enjoyed the game more if it had fleshed out more its narrative component, allowing us to explore more of the world it had constructed. This isn't to say the game is bad, but it somehow feels like it's both too short while also overstaying its welcome.

PSA game developers, high contrast text is extremely bad for peoples vision, which is to say white text on a black background in unreadable for anyone with any kind of neural or visual impairment. If you want people to play your game, black on white always works, if you want white text please pick another color for the background like blue-grey or something. Accessibility matters.

Had this game on my wishlist for a long time. It went on sale and I finally bought it and... meh. I personally do not get the appeal. It's a fine game, but I didn't connect with it personally. I enjoyed finding all the cool looking fish and upgrading my ship, but several things made me give up and not complete this game.
I was rather disappointed by the Lovecraftian horror element. Early on when you don't know what's out there it's really fun, but you soon realize there's not much to be afraid of. There's usually a single enemy chasing you, and a bunch of obstacles. I wish there was more diverse hazards: Areas of the water that become infested with skeletal piranhas at night. Fog clouds that teleport you to another part of the map. The town's people becoming corrupted as you sell them mutated fish. Don't get me wrong, the existing hazards are fun, but I wanted more. I wanted the night to be SCARY, and for a REASON.
Maybe it would've been fun if you didn't see your ship on the map, adding some challenge with sea-navigation, especially at night. Would've also made the central lighthouse a lot more significant.
The NPCs are another area that could've been fleshed out a lot more. The starting area has a ton of characters, both quest givers and shop owners. But all the other areas usually only have 2-3 NPCs. The wandering trader is nice, but it rather feels like the devs didn't have the time/money to flesh out vendors for each area.
My final gripe with the game is that the progression system felt rather unintuitive to me. By the time I realized the fish I was looking for could only be caught by nets, I had explored the entire map and fully upgraded my ship. I didn't even realize that a single NPC quest was preventing me from progressing, since most NPC missions are optional. 
Overall, the game is fine, but not for me.

The story and characters are great and revealed through pieces of scattered information in Lovecraftian style. The wonderful artwork made the amount of fishing required to finish this story easier.  Must like the mini-games in fishing!  Surprisingly, I did not find this scary at all but a story of intrigue and persistence.  Like with each crazy-looking fish, I was just impressed with the imagination. Every strange thing the inhabitants did, I was like, well!  Ok.  Maybe I've read too much Lovecraft.  It's all a metaphor of our own internal horrors.  

'O the mind, mind has mountains; cliffs of fall
Frightful, sheer, no-man-fathomed ...' 

from the poem, 'No worst, there is none. Pitched past pitch of grief', by Gerard Manley Hopkins when he was succumbing to his depression.  I believe Lovecraft and Hopkins were from the same era. 

If you look up that brilliant poem and it gets you down, too, then read Hopkins 'Windhover' poem.  It's the happier side of his life.  Hopkins felt sadness and happiness deeply.  

On that note, in the game, wouldn't it have been great if in a DLC you have the option to fix the other lighthouse and fix that most messed up area?  I know it would probably be rendered meaningless by the end game and would then not be Lovecraftian, but I like to fix things.

This is a well done little game that is two-parts fishing, one part light horror game.

The gameplay, overall, is pretty relaxed, only attacking you with creepy monstrosities when you get careless or take risks.  The 'time only passes when you move or fish' behavior is the right balance of mechanic that keeps that steady pressure of 'need to watch the clock or get caught in the dark' and 'I can walk away for any reason and it'll still be where I left it when I get back.'  

The fishing/dredging minigame is simple, but can be more difficult than you expect, and the variations of the minigame 'puzzle' as you catch different fish keep it from stagnating five minutes in.

The horror elements are enough to make you go 'uh oh' when things start to happen, but don't even remotely approach 'Alien Isolation' levels of terror.  

Graphics are a nice style of pseudo cell-shaded 3D rendering that's pleasant to look at, and feels okay for this game.  And there are some rather pretty sections that will make you smile even as an abyssal horror tries to eat you (or not, if you're paying enough attention to avoid it).

The audio works nicely.  As the anecdote might suggest, if you don't notice it, it's at least NOT bad.  The music is fitting, a slow, melancholy mix with an undertone of creepy that makes you wonder (at least the first few times) if you're triggering an event flag, or if it just kicks on at random.  The sound effects are crisp, fit what they're assigned too, and little 'I caught a new thing!' jingles come with twisted versions for those times when...  Well, you'll see.

Story progression is all up to you.  Take as much time as you need/want.  And the twist near the end will leave you guessing all the way up until that moment.  

Overall, a little arcade-ey, a little puzzle game-ey, a little resource management...  ... -ey.

Pleasant, if that fits.  Which is funny...  Because it's supposed to be horror lite.

This game is probably my first ever finished game and pursuing every ending. The gameplay and the mechanics though is simple,keeps the game enjoying. I don't know about other people, but for me this game is worth for everyone interested in it.

Overall an excellent experience : The art, music and narration all set the atmosphere at just the right balance between chill and disturbing, the gameplay has just enough grind to keep you going, but enough variety to not get boring - and all in all the game can be completed in 10-20h tops (depending on whether you want to complete your fish encyclopedia or just go through the story).

It's also one of the best UX I've seen in a game, ever! The game smoothly guides you through the different mechanics and zones, there's a ton of small tips and guidance cleverly nestled in the narration (for instance, the Painter's dialogue has an extra line when you have collected all the flags), enemies approach is signaled with sound, FX, a change in hue...really a masterclass in the matter, big kudos to the devs. 
Oh, and there are a good deal of accessibility options, too, including an automatic mode for completing minigames and a mode that disables enemies attacks if you really just want to fish and chill.

I'll be getting the DLC and 100% recommend it.

Trawling the depths of a shattered world fishing for monstrous aberrations, dredging salvage and lost treasures to upgrade my boat, bartering with mad prophets to unseal ancient temples... these are a few of my favorite things... Even rescued a dog!

Although I was a little late getting to Dredge, I'm incredibly glad I did. Dredge is a phenomenal indie game. It eases you into the gameplay and setting well enough, seemingly mundane. Its artstyle, looks, and music are all punching way above their weight class for an indie game though, which establish a high quality threshold and immerse setting from second one. Then it quickly starts building, first dipping its toes into an ocean of subtle eldritch horror with the first grotesque aberrations and eerie bumps in the night, then wholeheartedly taking the plunge.

Dredge really makes the most of everything at its disposal as it shifts from the chill fishing and engaging exploration of daytime to the nerve-wracking risks and encounters of dark, foggy nights on the sea. The fish to catch, the locales to delve into, the puzzles and inventory management, the story to piece together, all conspire to make time pass in the blink of an eye while you're playing it. I found my eyes so glued to the screen at times that they'd sting when I finally got the chance to close them after narrowly making it in to port. And when all was said and done, I wanted to play more to finish off the leftover fish, even though I'm not typically a completionist.

If I had any criticisms, I guess I'd like there to be more upgrades. At a certain point I'm just drowning in money with nothing to spend it on, and progress you've built up (literally building your boat up) over the game just stops dead. And naturally I'd like more of it, since the game's about ten hours long, but I'm also glad the game never felt like it was overstaying its welcome. In a year of great games, Dredge is an incredibly good one. I'm sure every media site has said 'Dredge has me HOOKED from start to finish', but in the end I've have to agree.

Had a great time with Dredge, love the art style and theme and was genuinely spooked at times. I would have liked to see more story and character development, with some deeper lore and storylines for certain characters to really make the most of the Lovecraftian theme.  The game left me wanting more by the end, and I was a little disappointed at how it did end as a result.  Looking forward to checking out new expansion The Pale Reach in a couple of weeks!

This game has a story that slowly reveals itself as you play, there was a good amount of mystery that made me want to keep hunting for items. The Lovecraftian horror element has been very well done. A generally relaxing fishing game with some unnerving elements to keep you on your toes.  Visually really nicely done.  Has some RPG feel to some elements.  Definitely a nice one to try out, especially for the Halloween season.

good game

While this was a great game and I enjoyed it very much, I can't help but say I was disappointed. I remember seeing the demo on YT a very long time ago, and ever since it came out I've wanted to play it. The core gameplay loop, the story, and the style are all fantastic. That being said I couldn't help but feel kinda bored as I got closer to the end of the game, it just felt like to much of the same thing I had been doing for the whole rest of the game. 
I would've liked to see some kind of ramp up in difficulty, or more game changing mechanics (outside of the ability wheel). Getting the dredging equipment t the start of the game, and then MAYBE unlocking the trawling net a little bit later feel like the only big mechanics introduced. I would've liked something to change in the core gameplay for each of the 4 island cities, not just "don't let x creature catch you". I would've liked to FEEL more progression as I got each relic, like the ocean gets angrier with you each time you remove one from the water, which makes your life harder in some way. Make the fishing/dredging faster or more difficult somehow, have some kind of "boss fight" with the Lovecraftian horror at each island, trying to prevent you from returning the relic to the collector utilizing the fishing minigame or something.
I also thought the ending was super lackluster. [spoiler]The game warns you TWICE that you cant save after this point before going into a whopping single 20-second cutscene into credits. Why am I worried about saving if there's nothing I would even WANT to save? What am I gonna drive halfway to the cutscene point and call it a night? And then also care about not having to do that again? Are there multiple endings and I just got the really short one?[/spoiler] More on the boss fight idea, I think that would've been a great way to make the ending feel less sudden and anticlimactic. Make you use ALL the minigames. Throw all of the abominations at you. Make you have to steer through rocks at night with the light constantly going out and something following you. Have the ocean throw hell itself at you to avoid you doing what needs to be done.
Complaining aside, I really do want to repeat that I genuinely did love this game. It was so much fun and for 10 hours I couldn't get enough of it. Which is why I'm so sad that it didn't really live up to its potential. Regardless, I would highly recommend this game to anyone, and I can't wait to play the DLC when it comes out.

As someone who has lived their entire life far away from the sea, this game has simultaneously made me want to become a fisherman and filled me with even more terror for the ocean. Very Lovecraftian. Has fishing mechanics. Great game.

Dredge is fun and relaxing game with good story and side quests, only reason I don't recommend the game is that it's too expensive compared to gameplay duration. It takes you about 6 hours to complete the main quest and another 2 hours for side quests. Sure, you can fish and explore the world and take it slow and go for 100%, but then again there is still too little to do for the price you pay.
It's a fun game, not a long game but still fun.

Executes a lovecraftian atmosphere perfectly, leaving much to be speculated and little to be known. The graphics were gorgeous, fishing minigames not too laborious, music was enjoyable, and I especially appreciated the manner in which the descriptions for aberrations were written. If DREDGE had a second game, I'd buy it in a heartbeat.
